verse.text: The [note]1[/note]former account I have made, O [note]2[/note]Theophilus, concerning all the [note]3[/note]things that Jesus began both to do and to teach,
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].
See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].
See note [link]1[sup]4[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].

verse.text: Until the day on which He was [xref]a[/xref]taken up, after He had given [xref]b[/xref]commandment through the Holy [note]1[/note]Spirit to the [xref]c[/xref]apostles whom He chose;
verse.note: The resurrected Christ had become the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), yet in resurrection He still did things through the Holy Spirit ([link]John 20:22[/link]).

verse.text: To whom also He [note]1[/note]presented Himself alive after His suffering by many irrefutable proofs, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]appearing to them through [i]a period of[/i] [note]3[/note]forty days and speaking the things concerning the [note]4[/note]kingdom of God.
verse.note: This was to train the disciples to practice and enjoy the Lord's invisible presence. See note [link]26[sup]3[/sup] in John 20[/link].

The resurrected Christ dwelt in the disciples, because He had breathed Himself as the Spirit into them on the day of His resurrection ([link]John 20:22[/link]). His appearing does not mean that He had ever left them; it simply means that He made His presence visible to them, training them to realize and enjoy His invisible presence all the time.
Forty days is a period of trial and testing (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link]).

This proves that the kingdom of God would be the main subject of the apostles' preaching in their commission that was to come after Pentecost ([link]8:12[/link]; [link]14:22[/link]; [link]19:8[/link]; [link]20:25[/link]; [link]28:23[/link], [link]31[/link]). It is not a material kingdom visible to human sight but a kingdom of the divine life. It is the spreading of Christ as life to His believers to form a realm in which God rules in His life. See notes [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link], [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 4[/link], and [link]43[sup]2[/sup] in Luke 4[/link].

verse.text: And as He [note]1[/note]met together with [i]them,[/i] He charged them not to depart from Jerusalem, but to wait for the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]promise of the Father, which, [i]He[/i] [xref]b[/xref][i]said,[/i] You heard from Me;
verse.note: Or, ate together.
See note [link]49[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 24[/link]; cf. note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in John 14[/link].

verse.text: For John [xref]a[/xref]baptized with [note]1[/note]water, but you shall be [note]2[/note]baptized in the Holy Spirit not many days from now.
verse.note: See notes [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link] and [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

This was accomplished in two sections: (1) all the Jewish believers were baptized in the Holy Spirit on the day of Pentecost ([link]2:4[/link]); and (2) all the Gentile believers were baptized in the house of Cornelius ([link]10:44-47[/link]; [link]11:15-17[/link]). In these two sections all genuine believers in Christ were baptized in the Holy Spirit into the one Body of Christ once for all universally ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: So the ones who came together asked Him, saying, Lord, are You at this [xref]a[/xref]time [xref]b[/xref]restoring the [note]1[/note]kingdom to Israel?
verse.note: The kingdom of Israel, for which the apostles and other devout Jews were looking, was a material kingdom, unlike God's kingdom of life, which is mentioned in [link]v. 3[/link] and which Christ is building up through the preaching of His gospel. See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup][/link].

verse.text: But He said to them, It is not for you to know [xref]a[/xref]times or seasons which the Father has set by His own authority.

But you shall [note]1[/note]receive [xref]a[/xref]power when the Holy [xref]b[/xref]Spirit comes [note]2[/note]upon you, and you shall be My [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]witnesses both in Jerusalem and in all [xref]d[/xref]Judea and [xref]e[/xref]Samaria and unto the [xref]f[/xref]uttermost part of the earth.
verse.note: This is to be baptized in the Holy Spirit ([link]v. 5[/link]) for the fulfillment of the promise of the Father ([link]v. 4[/link]).

Different from [i]in you[/i] ([link]John 14:17[/link]). The Holy Spirit was breathed into the disciples on the day of the Lord's resurrection ([link]John 20:22[/link]) to be the Spirit of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]) to them essentially. The same Holy Spirit would come upon the disciples on the day of Pentecost to be the Spirit of power to them economically. See note [link]49[sup]3[/sup] in Luke 24[/link].

Lit., martyrs; those who bear a living testimony of the resurrected and ascended Christ in life, differing from preachers who merely preach doctrines in letters. In His incarnation Christ carried out His ministry on the earth by Himself, as recorded in the Gospels, to sow Himself as the seed of the kingdom of God only in the Jewish land. In His ascension He would carry out His ministry in the heavens through these martyrs, in His resurrection life and with His ascension power and authority, as recorded in the Acts, to spread Himself as the development of the kingdom of God from Jerusalem, as a beginning, unto the uttermost part of the earth, as the consummation of His ministry in the New Testament. All the apostles and disciples in the Acts were His martyrs, His witnesses, of this kind (reference 8[sup]c[/sup]). See notes [link]11[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 23[/link] and [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 26[/link].

verse.text: And when He had said these things, while they were looking on, He was lifted up, and a cloud [xref]a[/xref]took Him away from their sight.
And while they were looking intently into heaven as He went, behold, [xref]a[/xref]two men in [xref]b[/xref]white clothing stood beside them,

Who also said, [note]1[/note]Men of [xref]a[/xref]Galilee, why do you stand looking into heaven? This Jesus, who has been taken up from you into [note]2[/note]heaven, will [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]come in the [note]4[/note]same way as you [note]5[/note]beheld Him going into heaven.
verse.note: Lit., Men, Galileans. More dignified and solemn than simply "Galileans."

Luke's Gospel ends with the Lord's ascending into heaven ([link]Luke 24:51[/link]), and his Acts begins with it. His Gospel is a narrative of the ministry of the incarnated Jesus on earth; his Acts is a record of the continuing ministry of the resurrected and ascended Christ in heaven, carried out through His believers on earth. In the Gospels His ministry on earth, carried out by Himself, only sowed Himself as the seed of the kingdom of God into His believers, with no church being built up yet. In the Acts His ministry in heaven, carried out through His believers in His resurrection and ascension, spread Him as the development of the kingdom of God for the building up of the church ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link]) throughout the entire world to constitute His Body, which is His fullness ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]) for His expression, and which is even the fullness of God ([link]Eph. 3:19[/link]) for God's expression.

The Lord's ascension points to His coming back. Between these two events is the dispensation of grace that He, as the pneumatic Christ, the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), might apply His all-inclusive redemption to God's chosen people for their full salvation, that He might produce and build up the church as His Body for the establishing of the kingdom of God on earth.

Christ ascended into heaven from Mount Olivet ([link]v. 12[/link]), being taken up by a cloud, in a way that was visible to human sight. He will return to the same mount ([link]Zech. 14:4[/link]), coming on a cloud ([link]Matt. 24:30[/link]), in the same visible way.

This vision of Christ's ascension into heaven strengthened the disciples' faith in Him and in what He had done for them through His death and resurrection. It broadened their view of God's heavenly economy, which had brought them into cooperation with Christ's ministry in the heavens for the carrying out of God's New Testament economy on the earth. The believers should have such a vision concerning Christ's ascension.

verse.text: Then they returned to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem from the mount called [xref]b[/xref]Olivet, which is near Jerusalem, a [note]2[/note]Sabbath day's journey away.
verse.note: The disciples returned to Jerusalem to keep the Lord's words in [link]Luke 24:49[/link] and [link]1:4[/link] of this book, that they might receive the Spirit of power economically as promised by the Father. They were all Galileans ([link]v. 11[/link]). For them to stay in Jerusalem, especially under the Jewish leaders' threatening, meant that they were risking their lives.
According to Jewish tradition, a Sabbath day's journey equaled about three-quarters of a mile.

verse.text: And when they entered, they went up to the [xref]a[/xref]upper room where they were residing, [xref]b[/xref]Peter and John and James and Andrew, Philip and Thomas, Bartholomew and Matthew, James [i]the son[/i] of Alphaeus and Simon the [note]1[/note]Zealot and Judas [i]the[/i] [note]2[/note][i]brother[/i] of James.
verse.note: The Zealots, a Galilean sect, were excessively zealous in striving for their religion, and in particular for the Mosaic law. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].
Or, son.

verse.text: These all [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]continued steadfastly [note]2[/note]with [xref]b[/xref]one accord in [note]3[/note]prayer, together with the [xref]c[/xref]women and [note]4[/note]Mary the [xref]d[/xref]mother of Jesus, and with His brothers.
verse.note: Before the Lord's death the disciples had no interest in praying for spiritual things ([link]Luke 22:40[/link], [link]45-46[/link]); rather, they contended among themselves as to which of them was considered to be greatest ([link]Luke 22:24[/link]). But after the Lord's resurrection and ascension, their spiritual condition changed radically. They did not contend among themselves but were burdened to continue steadfastly with one accord in prayer, even before the day of Pentecost, when they would receive the outpoured Spirit of power economically ([link]ch. 2[/link]). This is a strong sign and proof that they had received the indwelling Spirit of life essentially on the day of the Lord's resurrection ([link]John 20:22[/link]). This is also evidence that they had been strengthened in God's New Testament economy by the vision of the Lord's ascension.
Or, with one mind.

The disciples might have prayed to be clothed with the Spirit of power, the promise of the Father, for which the Lord had charged them to remain in Jerusalem ([link]Luke 24:49[/link]; [link]Acts 1:4[/link]), and might also have prayed for the commission given to them by the Lord in [link]Luke 24:47-48[/link] and [link]1:8[/link] of this book to bear His testimony to the uttermost part of the earth.[br][br]God wanted to pour out His Spirit for the carrying out of His New Testament economy and had promised to do it. Yet He still needed His chosen people to pray for this. As God in heaven, He needs men on earth to cooperate with Him for the carrying out of His plan. The one hundred twenty disciples' praying for ten days met this need of God's.
Here Mary is mentioned for the last time in the New Testament.

verse.text: And in those days [xref]a[/xref]Peter stood up in the midst of the [xref]b[/xref]brothers and [note]1[/note]said (there was a group of persons [i]gathered[/i] together, about a hundred and twenty),
verse.note: Before the Lord's death Peter often spoke nonsensically ([link]Matt. 16:22-23[/link]; [link]17:24-26[/link]; [link]26:33-35[/link]). But now, after the Lord's resurrection, he could expound the Old Testament prophecies properly in their correct significance ([link]vv. 16-20[/link]). This too is proof that the disciples, before they received the Spirit of power economically on the day of Pentecost, had received the Spirit of life essentially on the day of the Lord's resurrection.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Men, brothers, the [xref]a[/xref]Scripture had to be fulfilled, which the Holy Spirit spoke before through the mouth of David concerning [xref]b[/xref]Judas, who became a guide to those who seized Jesus;
verse.note: More dignified and solemn than simply "brothers."

verse.text: For he was [xref]a[/xref]numbered among us and was allotted his portion of [note]1[/note]this [xref]b[/xref]ministry.
verse.note: Mentioned also in [link]v. 25[/link]; referring to the ministry that bears the testimony of Jesus ([link]v. 8[/link]). Though the apostles were twelve in number, their ministry was uniquely one — [i]this ministry,[/i] a corporate ministry in the principle of the Body of Christ. All the apostles carried out the same ministry to bear the testimony not of any religion, doctrine, or practice but uniquely of the incarnated, resurrected, and ascended Jesus Christ, who is the Lord of all.

verse.text: (Now this man acquired a piece of [xref]a[/xref]land with the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]wages of unrighteousness; and falling headlong, he burst in the middle, and all his inward parts gushed out.
verse.note: Or, reward.

verse.text: And it became known to all those dwelling in Jerusalem, so that that piece of land was called in their own dialect, [note]1[/note]Akeldamach, that is, Field of [note]2[/note]Blood.)
verse.note: Aramaic.
Signifying a bloody death ([link]Matt. 27:5-8[/link]).

verse.text: For it is written in the book of Psalms, [xref]a[/xref]"Let his habitation become desolate, and let no one dwell in it"; and, [xref]b[/xref]"His overseership let another take."
It is necessary therefore that of the men who accompanied us all the time in which the Lord Jesus [xref]a[/xref]went in and went out [note]1[/note]among us,
verse.note: Or, before.

verse.text: Beginning from the baptism of [xref]a[/xref]John until the day on which He was [xref]b[/xref]taken up from us, one of these should become a [xref]c[/xref]witness of His [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]resurrection with us.
verse.note: The Lord's resurrection was the focus of the apostles' testimony. It points back to His incarnation, humanity, human living on the earth, and God-ordained death ([link]2:23[/link]), and points forward to His ascension, ministry and administration in heaven, and coming back. Thus, the apostles' testimony of Jesus Christ, the Lord of all, was all-inclusive, as depicted in the whole book of Acts. They preached and ministered the all-inclusive Christ as He is revealed in the entire Scripture.

verse.text: And they proposed two, Joseph, called [xref]a[/xref]Barsabbas, who was surnamed [xref]b[/xref]Justus, and Matthias.
And they [xref]a[/xref]prayed and said, You Lord, Knower of the [xref]b[/xref]hearts of all, show [i]us[/i] clearly the one whom You have chosen of these two
To take the place of this ministry and [xref]a[/xref]apostleship, from which Judas turned aside to [xref]b[/xref]go to his own place.
And they cast [note]1[/note]lots for them, and the lot fell on Matthias; and he was counted with the eleven apostles.
verse.note: After the Lord's ascension and before the day of Pentecost the apostles were in a transitional period, as shown by the way they sought the Lord's guidance. They had received the indwelling Spirit on the day of the Lord's resurrection ([link]John 20:22[/link]) and had been trained by the Lord for forty days before His ascension to practice and become accustomed to His invisible presence ([link]v. 3[/link]). Yet it was still difficult for them to drop the old, traditional way of seeking God's leading by casting lots ([link]Lev. 16:8[/link]; [link]Josh. 14:2[/link]; [link]1 Sam. 14:41[/link]; [link]Neh. 10:34[/link]; [link]11:1[/link]; [link]Prov. 16:33[/link]). They were still not accustomed to the leading and guidance of the indwelling Spirit ([link]Rom. 8:14[/link]), unlike the apostle Paul later, in [link]16:6-8[/link]. They were still in the initial stage of God's New Testament economy before the day of Pentecost.

verse.text: And as the day of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Pentecost was being fulfilled, they were all together in the same place.
verse.note: Meaning [i]fiftieth.[/i] It was the fiftieth day from the Lord's resurrection, there being seven weeks in between, counting from the second day (the first day of the week — [link]Luke 23:54-24:1[/link]) after the Passover on which the Lord was crucified ([link]John 19:14[/link]). It was the fulfillment of the Feast of Weeks ([link]Deut. 16:10[/link]), which was also called the Feast of Harvest ([link]Exo. 23:16[/link]), and was counted from the day of the offering of a sheaf of the firstfruits of the harvest, to the day after the seventh Sabbath ([link]Lev. 23:10-11[/link], [link]15-16[/link]). The sheaf of the firstfruits offered before God was a type of the resurrected Christ offered to God on the day of His resurrection ([link]John 20:17[/link]), which was the day after the Sabbath ([link]John 20:1[/link]). From that day to the day of Pentecost there were exactly fifty days (cf. [link]1:3[/link]). The Feast of Harvest typifies the enjoyment of the rich produce brought in by the resurrected Christ. This rich produce is the all-inclusive Spirit of the processed Triune God, given by Him to His chosen people as the blessing of the gospel ([link]Gal. 3:14[/link]) that they may enjoy the all-inclusive Christ (the very embodiment of the Triune God) as their good land. This signifies that the believers, by receiving the bountiful Spirit on the day of Pentecost, not only have entered into the good land but also have participated in the bountiful riches of the all-inclusive Christ ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]) in His resurrection and ascension, as God's full allotment in His New Testament economy.

verse.text: And suddenly there was a sound out of heaven, as of a rushing violent [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wind, and it [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]filled the whole house where they were sitting.
verse.note: In the Lord's resurrection the Spirit of resurrection life is likened to breath, breathed into the disciples ([link]John 20:22[/link]) for their spiritual being and living essentially. In the Lord's ascension the Spirit of ascension power, poured upon the disciples, is symbolized here by the wind and is for the disciples' ministry and move economically. The essential Spirit of resurrection life is for the believers to live Christ; the economical Spirit of ascension power is for them to carry out His commission.
Gk. [i]pleroo,[/i] to fill inwardly, as the wind filled the house.

verse.text: And there appeared to them [note]1[/note]tongues as of [note]2[/note]fire, which were distributed; and it [note]3[/note]sat on each one of them;
verse.note: A symbol of speaking, symbolizing that God's economical Spirit of power is mainly for speaking. He is the speaking Spirit.
Symbolizing burning power for purging and motivating in God's economical move.
The verb is singular, indicating that one tongue sat on each of them.

verse.text: And they were [note]1[/note]all [note]2[/note]filled with the Holy Spirit and began to [xref]a[/xref]speak in different [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]tongues, even as the [xref]c[/xref]Spirit gave to them to [note]4[/note]speak forth.
verse.note: [i]All[/i] modifies only [i]filled[/i] in the first clause, not [i]began to speak[/i] in the second clause. It cannot be used as evidence that all the disciples who were filled with the Holy Spirit began to speak in tongues.

Gk. [i]pletho[/i] (used also in [link]4:8[/link], [link]31[/link]; [link]9:17[/link]; [link]13:9[/link]; [link]Luke 1:15[/link], [link]41[/link], [link]67[/link]), to fill outwardly. According to its usage in this book, [i]pleroo[/i] denotes the filling of a vessel within, as the wind filled the house inwardly in [link]v. 2[/link], and [i]pletho[/i] denotes the filling of persons outwardly, as the Spirit filled the disciples outwardly in this verse. The disciples were filled ([i]pleroo[/i]) inwardly and essentially with the Spirit ([link]13:52[/link]) for their Christian living, and were filled ([i]pletho[/i]) outwardly and economically with the Spirit for their Christian ministry. The inward filling Spirit, the essential Spirit, is in the disciples ([link]John 14:17[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:11[/link]), whereas the outward filling Spirit, the economical Spirit, is upon them ([link]1:8[/link]; [link]2:17[/link]). Every believer in Christ should experience both aspects of the Holy Spirit. Even Christ as a man experienced the same thing: He was born of the Holy Spirit essentially ([link]Luke 1:35[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:18[/link], [link]20[/link]) for His being and living, and He was anointed with the Holy Spirit economically ([link]Matt. 3:16[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18[/link]) for His ministry and move. The essential Spirit was within Him and the economical Spirit was upon Him.[br][br]The outward filling of the poured out Spirit was the ascended Head's baptizing of His Body into the Spirit. On the day of Pentecost the Jewish believers, the first part of His Body, were baptized; in the house of Cornelius the Gentile believers, the second part of His Body, were baptized in the same way ([link]10:44-47[/link]). By these two steps He baptized once for all His entire Body into the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]), who is the application and realization of Himself. His baptizing His Body into the Spirit was His baptizing it into Himself. This was the accomplishment of the baptism in the Holy Spirit promised in [link]1:5[/link] by Christ, the Head of the Body.

Dialects ([link]vv. 6[/link], [link]8[/link]). The disciples were Galileans ([link]v. 7[/link]), yet they spoke the different foreign dialects of the attendants who came from various parts of the world. This is strong proof that tongue-speaking must be an understandable language, not merely a voice or sound uttered by the tongue.
"A peculiar word, and purposely chosen to denote the clear, loud utterance" (Vincent).

verse.text: Now there were dwelling in Jerusalem [note]1[/note]Jews, devout men, from every nation under heaven.
verse.note: The devout Jews who came from their dispersion to Jerusalem to keep the Feast of Pentecost.

verse.text: And when this sound occurred, the multitude came together and was confounded because each one heard them [xref]a[/xref]speaking in his own dialect.
And they were [xref]a[/xref]amazed and marveled, saying, Behold, are not all these who are speaking [xref]b[/xref]Galileans?
And how [i]is it that[/i] we each hear [i]them[/i] in our own dialect in which we were born?

Parthians and [xref]a[/xref]Medes and [xref]b[/xref]Elamites and those dwelling in [xref]c[/xref]Mesopotamia, both in Judea and [xref]d[/xref]Cappadocia, in [xref]e[/xref]Pontus and [xref]f[/xref]Asia,

Both in [xref]a[/xref]Phrygia and [xref]b[/xref]Pamphylia, in [xref]c[/xref]Egypt and the parts of [xref]d[/xref]Libya around [xref]e[/xref]Cyrene, and the sojourning of Rome, both Jews and [note]1[/note]proselytes,
verse.note: Gentiles who were converted to Judaism ([link]6:5[/link]; [link]13:43[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Cretans and [xref]b[/xref]Arabians, we hear them speaking in our [note]1[/note]tongues the magnificent [i]works[/i] of God?
verse.note: Gk. [i]glossa,[/i] used for two things in this chapter: the speaking organ in [link]v. 3[/link], and dialects in this verse and [link]v. 4[/link], referring to the dialect in [link]vv. 6[/link] and [link]8[/link]. This evidence leaves no ground for saying that tongue-speaking may be merely a voice or sound uttered by the tongue, the speaking organ; it must be a dialect, because what the disciples spoke in tongues ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]11[/link]) were all different dialects ([link]vv. 6[/link], [link]8[/link]). In this sense, tongues and dialects are synonymous, used interchangeably in these verses.

verse.text: And they were all [xref]a[/xref]amazed and perplexed, saying to one another, What does this mean?
But others [xref]a[/xref]jeered and said, They are full of [note]1[/note]new wine!
verse.note: Lit., sweet. Since it was sweet wine, it must still have been new wine.

verse.text: But Peter, standing with the [note]1[/note]eleven, lifted up his voice and spoke forth to them: [note]2[/note]Men of Judea, and all who are dwelling in Jerusalem, let this be known to you, and give ear to my words.
verse.note: This indicates that Matthias, who was chosen in [link]1:26[/link], was recognized as one among the twelve apostles.
Lit., Men, Jews. More dignified and solemn than simply "Jews."

verse.text: For these men are not [xref]a[/xref]drunk, as you suppose, for it is the [note]1[/note]third hour of the day;
But this is what is spoken through the prophet Joel:

[xref]a[/xref]"And it shall be in the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]last days, says God, [i]that[/i] I will [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]pour out [note]3[/note]of My Spirit [note]4[/note]upon [note]5[/note]all flesh, and your sons and your daughters shall [note]6[/note][xref]d[/xref]prophesy, and your young men shall see [xref]e[/xref]visions, and your old men shall dream [i]things[/i] in dreams;
verse.note: Beginning from Christ's first coming ([link]1 Pet. 1:20[/link]).

This differs from the breathing of the Spirit into the disciples out of the mouth of Christ after His resurrection ([link]John 20:22[/link]). The pouring out of God's Spirit was from the heavens in Christ's ascension. The former is the essential aspect of the Spirit in His being breathed into the disciples as life for their living; the latter is the economical aspect of the Spirit in His being poured upon them as power for their work. The same Spirit is within them essentially and upon them economically.[br][br]The pouring out of the Spirit in Christ's ascension was the descension of the resurrected and ascended Christ as the all-inclusive Spirit to carry out His heavenly ministry on the earth to build up His church ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link]) as His Body ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]) for God's New Testament economy.
Or, from (also in [link]v. 18[/link]).

[i]Upon[/i] is economical, different from the essential [i]in[/i] in [link]John 14:17[/link]. [i]In[/i] is related to the intrinsic essence for life; [i]upon[/i] is related to the outward element for power.
All fallen human beings, without distinction of sex, age, or status.
Prophecies, visions, and dreams are outward expressions and are not related to the inner life.

verse.text: And indeed upon My slaves, both men and women, I will pour out of My [xref]a[/xref]Spirit in those days, and they shall prophesy.
And I will [note]1[/note]show wonders in heaven above and signs on the earth below, blood and fire and vapor of smoke.
verse.note: Lit., give. [link]Verses 19[/link] and [link]20[/link], quoted from Joel's prophecy, are not related to the things that occurred on the day of Pentecost but to the calamities of the judgment day of the Lord in the future.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before the [xref]b[/xref]great and notable [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]day of the Lord comes.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in 2 Pet. 3[/link].

verse.text: And it shall be that everyone who [note]1[/note]calls on the [note]2[/note]name of the Lord shall be [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]saved."
verse.note: Calling on the name of the Lord is not a new practice that began with the New Testament. Rather, it began with Enosh, the third generation of mankind, in [link]Gen. 4:26[/link]. It was continued by Job ([link]Job 12:4[/link]; [link]27:10[/link]), Abraham ([link]Gen. 12:8[/link]; [link]13:4[/link]; [link]21:33[/link]), Isaac ([link]Gen. 26:25[/link]), Moses and the children of Israel ([link]Deut. 4:7[/link]), Samson ([link]Judg. 15:18[/link]; [link]16:28[/link]), Samuel ([link]1 Sam. 12:18[/link]; [link]Psa. 99:6[/link]), David ([link]2 Sam. 22:4[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 16:8[/link]; [link]21:26[/link]; [link]Psa. 14:4[/link]; [link]17:6[/link]; [link]18:3[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]31:17[/link]; [link]55:16[/link]; [link]86:5[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]105:1[/link]; [link]116:4[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]118:5[/link]; [link]145:18[/link]), the psalmist Asaph ([link]Psa. 80:18[/link]), the psalmist Heman ([link]Psa. 88:9[/link]), Elijah ([link]1 Kings 18:24[/link]), Isaiah ([link]Isa. 12:4[/link]), Jeremiah ([link]Lam. 3:55[/link], [link]57[/link]), and others ([link]Psa. 99:6[/link]), all of whom practiced this in the Old Testament age. Isaiah charged the seekers of God to call upon Him ([link]Isa. 55:6[/link]). Even the Gentiles knew that the prophets of Israel had the habit of calling on the name of God ([link]Jonah 1:6[/link]; [link]2 Kings 5:11[/link]). The Gentile raised up by God from the north also called upon His name ([link]Isa. 41:25[/link]). It is God's commandment ([link]Psa. 50:15[/link]; [link]Jer. 29:12[/link]) and desire ([link]Psa. 91:15[/link]; [link]Zeph. 3:9[/link]; [link]Zech. 13:9[/link]) that His people call on Him. This is the joyful way to drink from the fountain of God's salvation ([link]Isa. 12:3-4[/link]) and the enjoyable way to delight oneself in God ([link]Job 27:10[/link]), that is, to enjoy Him. Hence, God's people must call upon Him daily ([link]Psa. 88:9[/link]). Such a jubilant practice was prophesied by Joel ([link]Joel 2:32[/link]) concerning the New Testament jubilee.[br][br]In the New Testament, calling on the name of the Lord was first mentioned by Peter, here, on the day of Pentecost, as the fulfillment of Joel's prophecy. This fulfillment is related to God's outpouring of the all-inclusive Spirit economically upon His chosen people that they may participate in His New Testament jubilee. Joel's prophecy and its fulfillment concerning God's New Testament jubilee have two aspects: on God's side, He poured out His Spirit in the ascension of the resurrected Christ; on our side, we call on the name of the ascended Lord, who has accomplished all, attained unto all, and obtained all. Calling on the Lord's name is vitally necessary in order for us, the believers in Christ, to participate in and enjoy the all-inclusive Christ with all He has accomplished, attained, and obtained ([link]1 Cor. 1:2[/link]). It is a major practice in God's New Testament economy that enables us to enjoy the processed Triune God for our full salvation ([link]Rom. 10:10-13[/link]). The early believers practiced this everywhere ([link]1 Cor. 1:2[/link]), and to the unbelievers, especially the persecutors, it became a popular sign of Christ's believers ([link]9:14[/link], [link]21[/link]). When Stephen suffered persecution, he practiced this ([link]7:59[/link]), and his practice surely impressed Saul, one of his persecutors ([link]7:58-60[/link]; [link]22:20[/link]). Later, the unbelieving Saul persecuted the callers ([link]9:14[/link], [link]21[/link]) by taking their calling as a sign. Immediately after Saul was caught by the Lord, Ananias, who brought Saul into the fellowship of the Body of Christ, charged him to be baptized, calling on the name of the Lord, to show others that he too had become such a caller. By his word to Timothy in [link]2 Tim. 2:22[/link], Paul indicated that in the early days all the Lord's seekers practiced such calling. Undoubtedly, he was one who practiced this, since he charged his young co-worker Timothy to do this that Timothy might enjoy the Lord as he did.[br][br]The Greek word for [i]call on[/i] is composed of [i]on[/i] and [i]call[/i] (by name); thus, it is to call out audibly, even loudly, as Stephen did ([link]7:59-60[/link]).
The name denotes the person. Jesus is the Lord's name, and the Spirit is His person. When we call, "Lord Jesus," we receive the Spirit.

This is the conclusion of the quotation of Joel's prophecy, which began in [link]v. 17[/link], indicating that the issue of God's pouring out of His Spirit upon all flesh is their salvation through calling on the name of the Lord. God's outpouring of His Spirit is the applying of the Lord's salvation to His chosen people. To be saved is to receive this Spirit, who is the blessing of the gospel in God's New Testament economy ([link]Gal. 3:2[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]14[/link]). This Spirit is the Lord Himself as the breath ([link]John 20:22[/link]) and the living water ([link]John 4:10[/link], [link]14[/link]) to us. To breathe Him in as our breath and drink Him as our living water, we need to call on Him. [link]Lamentations 3:55-56[/link] indicates that our calling on the Lord is our breathing, and [link]Isa. 12:3-4[/link] indicates that our calling on the Lord is our drinking. After we believe in the Lord, we need to call on Him that we may not only be saved but also enjoy His riches ([link]Rom. 10:12-13[/link]). When we exercise our spirit to call on Him, breathe Him in, and drink Him, we enjoy His riches; this is the real worship to God. The Lord connected such worship ([link]John 4:24[/link]) to the drinking of the living water given by Him ([link]John 4:14[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Men of Israel, hear these words: Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene, a [note]2[/note]man [note]3[/note]shown by God to you to be approved by works of power and wonders and [xref]b[/xref]signs, which God did through Him in your midst, even as you yourselves know —
verse.note: Lit., Men, Israelites. More dignified and solemn than simply "Israelites."

The first message of the apostles' preaching of the gospel was focused on a man. In his Gospel, Luke presented to his readers this man, from His conception, through His birth, youth, life on earth, death, and resurrection, to His ascension. Here, in this book, Luke went on to tell us that this man was preached by the apostles as the God-ordained Savior.
Lit., pointed out, exhibited, displayed; i.e., proved by showing, thus bringing about an approval.

verse.text: This man, [xref]a[/xref]delivered up by the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]determined counsel and [note]2[/note]foreknowledge of God, you, through the hand of [note]3[/note]lawless men, [xref]c[/xref]nailed to [i]a[/i] [note]4[/note][i]cross[/i] and [xref]d[/xref]killed;
verse.note: This counsel must have been determined in a council held by the Divine Trinity before the foundation of the world ([link]1 Pet. 1:20[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:8[/link]), indicating that the Lord's crucifixion was not an accident in human history but a purposeful fulfillment of the divine counsel determined by the Triune God.
See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Pet. 1[/link].

Including Judas Iscariot ([link]Luke 22:3-6[/link]), the chief priests, the officers of the temple, the elders ([link]Luke 22:52-53[/link]), the high priest, the Jewish Sanhedrin ([link]Luke 22:54[/link], [link]66-71[/link]), Pilate, Herod, and the Roman soldiers ([link]Luke 23:1-25[/link]) — mainly the Jewish religionists with their deputies and the Gentile politicians with their subordinates. This indicates that Jesus was killed by all mankind.
See notes [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link] and [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in John 18[/link].

verse.text: Whom [note]1[/note]God has [xref]a[/xref]raised up, having loosed the pangs of [xref]b[/xref]death, since it was [note]2[/note]not possible for Him to be held by it.
verse.note: Here and in [link]v. 32[/link] Peter said that God raised up Jesus. In [link]10:40-41[/link] he said the same thing again but added, "He rose from the dead." Regarding the Lord as a man, the New Testament tells us that God raised Him from the dead ([link]Rom. 8:11[/link]); considering Him as God, it tells us that He Himself rose from the dead ([link]1 Thes. 4:14[/link]). This proves His dual status — human and divine.

The Lord is both God and resurrection ([link]John 1:1[/link]; [link]11:25[/link]), possessing the indestructible life ([link]Heb. 7:16[/link]). Since He is such an ever-living One, death is not able to hold Him. He delivered Himself to death, but death had no way to detain Him; rather, death was defeated by Him, and He rose up from it.

verse.text: For David says regarding Him, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"I saw the [note]2[/note]Lord continually before me, because [note]3[/note]He is on my right hand, that I may not be shaken.
verse.note: This is the declaration of Christ in His resurrection.
Referring to God.

When Christ is held by God (as in [link]Isa. 41:13[/link]; [link]42:6[/link]), God is on His right hand; when He is exalted by God, He is sitting at the right hand of God ([link]v. 33[/link]; [link]Psa. 110:1[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:20-21[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore my heart was made glad and my [note]1[/note]tongue exulted; moreover, also my flesh will [note]2[/note]rest in hope,
verse.note: This is a quotation from [link]Psa. 16:9[/link] in the Septuagint. But in the original Hebrew text the word for [i]tongue[/i] is [i]glory,[/i] which is a synonym of [i]soul,[/i] according to [link]Gen. 49:6[/link] and [link]Psa. 7:5[/link]. Because Christ trusted in God, His heart was made glad and His soul exulted while He was in Hades ([link]v. 27[/link]).
Or, dwell, reside, pitch its tent. After Christ died on the cross, while His soul was in Hades exulting, His flesh (His body) was in a tomb resting in hope, because He trusted in God.

verse.text: Because You will not abandon my soul to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hades, nor will You permit Your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Holy One to see [note]3[/note]corruption.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].
See note [link]75[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].
Corruption of the body in the tomb ([link]v. 31[/link]).

verse.text: You have made known to me the [note]1[/note]ways of life; You will make me full of gladness with Your [note]2[/note]presence."
verse.note: The ways to come out of death into resurrection.
Indicating that Christ was resurrected into God's presence, especially in His ascension ([link]v. 34[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:3[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Men, brothers, I can say to you plainly concerning the patriarch [xref]a[/xref]David that he both deceased and was buried, and his [xref]b[/xref]tomb is among us until this day.
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Therefore, being a prophet and knowing that God had [xref]a[/xref]sworn with an oath to him to seat [i]One[/i] from the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]fruit of his loins upon his [note]2[/note]throne,
verse.note: See note [link]42[sup]2[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].
This was declared also to Mary by the angel at the conception of Christ ([link]Luke 1:32-33[/link]).

verse.text: He, seeing [i]this[/i] beforehand, spoke concerning the resurrection of the Christ, that neither was He abandoned to Hades, nor did His flesh see [xref]a[/xref]corruption.
This Jesus [note]1[/note]God has [xref]a[/xref]raised up, of [note]2[/note]which we all are [xref]b[/xref]witnesses.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup][/link].

Or, whom. The apostles were witnesses of the resurrected Christ, not only in word but also by their life and action, especially bearing witness of His resurrection ([link]4:33[/link]). Bearing witness of Christ's resurrection is the crucial point, the focus, in carrying out God's New Testament economy. See note [link]8[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Therefore having been [xref]a[/xref]exalted to the [xref]b[/xref]right hand of God and having received the [note]1[/note]promise of the Holy [xref]c[/xref]Spirit from the Father, He has [xref]d[/xref]poured out this which you both see and hear.
verse.note: Not the promise given by the Holy Spirit but the promise given by the Father in [link]Joel 2:28[/link], quoted by Peter in [link]v. 17[/link] and referred to by the Lord in [link]Luke 24:49[/link] and in [link]1:4[/link] of this book, concerning the Holy Spirit. The exalted Christ's receiving of the promise of the Holy Spirit was actually His receiving of the Holy Spirit Himself. Christ was conceived of the Spirit essentially for His existence in humanity ([link]Luke 1:35[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:18[/link], [link]20[/link]) and was anointed with the Spirit economically for His ministry among men ([link]Matt. 3:16[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18[/link]). After His resurrection and ascension, He still needed to receive the Spirit economically again that He might pour Himself out upon His Body to carry out His heavenly ministry on earth for the accomplishing of God's New Testament economy.

verse.text: For David did [note]1[/note]not [xref]a[/xref]ascend into the heavens, but he himself says, [xref]b[/xref]"The [note]2[/note]Lord said to my Lord, Sit at My [note]3[/note]right hand
verse.note: This proves that up to the time of Pentecost, David still had not ascended into the heavens. Furthermore, his tomb was still among the disciples on the day of Pentecost ([link]v. 29[/link]). This fact annuls the inaccurate teaching that says, based on [link]Eph. 4:8-10[/link], that when Christ was resurrected, He brought Paradise, with all the Old Testament saints, from Hades into the heavens (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Cor. 12[/link]).
The first [i]Lord[/i] refers to God and the second, to Christ, whom David called "my Lord" ([link]Matt. 22:45[/link] and note 1).
The position of glory, honor, and power ([link]Exo. 15:6[/link]; [link]1 Kings 2:19[/link]; [link]Mark 14:62[/link]).

verse.text: Until I [note]1[/note]set Your enemies as a footstool for Your feet."
verse.note: This indicates that after Christ's ascension God is still working to defeat Christ's enemies that Christ may come back to reign in the universal kingdom of God ([link]1 Cor. 15:25[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore let all the house of Israel know assuredly that God has made Him both [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Lord and [xref]b[/xref]Christ, this Jesus whom [note]2[/note]you have [xref]c[/xref]crucified.
verse.note: As God, the Lord was the Lord all the time ([link]Luke 1:43[/link]; [link]John 11:21[/link]; [link]20:28[/link]). But as man, He was made the Lord in His ascension after He brought His humanity into God in His resurrection. And as God's sent and anointed One, He was Christ from the time that He was born ([link]Luke 2:11[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:16[/link]; [link]John 1:41[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:16[/link]). But as such a One, He was also officially made the very Christ of God in His ascension.[br][br]The Lord was made Lord, the Lord of all, to possess all; and He was made Christ, God's Anointed ([link]Heb. 1:9[/link]), to carry out God's commission.
[i]You[/i] here is emphatic.

verse.text: And when they heard [i]this,[/i] they were [xref]a[/xref]pricked in their heart, and they said to Peter and the rest of the apostles, [xref]b[/xref]What should we do, [note]1[/note]brothers?
verse.note: Lit., men, brothers. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And Peter said to them, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Repent and each one of you be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]baptized [note]3[/note]upon the [note]4[/note]name of Jesus Christ for the [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the [note]6[/note][xref]d[/xref]gift of the Holy [note]7[/note]Spirit.
verse.note: See notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link] and [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].
See notes [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link], [link]19[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 28[/link], [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in Mark 1[/link], and [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 16[/link].

The New Testament uses three different prepositions to describe baptism's relationship to the Lord:[br][br](1) [i]En,[/i] in ([link]10:48[/link]). To be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ is to be baptized in the sphere of the name of Jesus Christ, within which is the reality of the baptism.[br][br](2) [i]Eis,[/i] into ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]; [link]Acts 8:16[/link]; [link]19:5[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:3[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]). To be baptized into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, or into the name of the Lord Jesus, is to be baptized into a spiritual union with the all-inclusive Christ, who is the embodiment of the Triune God. See notes [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and [link]19[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 28[/link].[br][br](3) [i]Epi,[/i] upon, or on ([link]v. 38[/link]). To be baptized upon the name of Jesus Christ is to be baptized upon the ground of what the name of Jesus Christ stands for. It stands for all that the person of Jesus Christ is and all that He has accomplished, both of which constitute the belief (the faith) of God's New Testament economy. It is on this ground that the believers in Christ are baptized.
The name denotes the person.

Forgiveness of sins is based on the redemption of Christ, which was accomplished through His death ([link]10:43[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:7[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:3[/link]); it is the initial and basic blessing of God's full salvation. Based on it the blessing of God's full salvation goes forward and consummates in the receiving of the gift of the Holy Spirit.

Not any gift distributed by the Spirit, such as is mentioned in [link]Rom. 12:6[/link], [link]1 Cor. 12:4[/link], and [link]1 Pet. 4:10[/link], but the gift that is the Holy Spirit Himself, given by God to the believers in Christ as the unique gift that produces all the gifts mentioned in [link]Rom. 12[/link], [link]1 Cor. 12[/link], and [link]1 Pet. 4[/link]. Those gifts are the abilities and capacities for the service of God, and they come from this unique gift, the Holy Spirit.

The all-inclusive Spirit of the processed Triune God in His New Testament economy, both essential for life and economical for power, given to the believers at the time of their believing in Christ ([link]Eph. 1:13[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:2[/link]), as the all-inclusive blessing of God's full gospel ([link]Gal. 3:14[/link]) that they may enjoy all the riches of the Triune God ([link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]).[br][br]The apostles preached and ministered Christ, but when their hearers repented and believed in Him, they received this wonderful Spirit of the Triune God. This implies that this Spirit is just the resurrected and ascended Christ Himself. The receiving of the Spirit here is both essential and economical, in a general and all-inclusive sense, differing from the receiving of the Spirit in [link]8:15-17[/link] and [link]19:2-6[/link], which is particularly the receiving of the Spirit in His falling upon the believers economically.

verse.text: For to [note]1[/note]you is the [note]2[/note]promise and to your children, and to all [note]3[/note]who are [xref]a[/xref]far off, [note]4[/note]as many as the Lord our God [xref]b[/xref]calls to [i]Himself.[/i]
verse.note: Referring to the Jews.
Referring to the Holy Spirit (see note [link]33[sup]1[/sup][/link]).
Referring to the Gentiles, who are included in [i]all flesh[/i] ([link]v. 17[/link]).
Referring to those chosen and predestinated by God in eternity ([link]Eph. 1:4-5[/link]) and called by Him in the New Testament age ([link]Rom. 1:7[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:2[/link]).

verse.text: And with many other words he solemnly [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]testified and exhorted them, saying, [note]2[/note]Be saved from this [xref]b[/xref]crooked [note]3[/note]generation.
verse.note: Testifying requires experiences of seeing and enjoyment concerning the Lord or spiritual things. It is different from merely teaching.

[i]Be[/i] is active, and [i]saved[/i] is passive; hence, [i]be saved[/i] is in the active-passive voice. Salvation is to be carried out by God, but man needs to be active to receive what God intends to do. At the time of Pentecost, everything concerning God's full salvation had been prepared, and the Holy Spirit was poured out as the application and full blessing of God's salvation, ready for man to receive. In this matter God is waiting for man, and man needs to take the initiative. Man, be saved!

At the conclusion of his message Peter did not say, "Be saved from God's condemnation," or "from eternal perdition," but, "Be saved from this crooked generation." The crooked generation refers to the perverted Jews in that age, who rejected God's Christ ([link]v. 36[/link]) and were considered by God as the "present evil age" ([link]Gal. 1:4[/link]). For the crooked Jews to be saved from their present evil age required a genuine repentance concerning their crookedness toward God and a real turn to God. This indicates that they needed to turn to God not only from their sins but also from their generation, their Jewish society, including their Jewish religion. The result of such a salvation was not their entering into heaven but their entering into a new generation — the church. Thus, the saved ones were separated from the Jewish society into the church. Being saved in this way implies being saved from God's condemnation and eternal perdition unto God's eternal purpose and His pleasure ([link]Eph. 3:11[/link]; [link]1:9[/link]).

verse.text: Those then who received his word were [note]1[/note]baptized, and there were [xref]a[/xref]added on that day about three [xref]b[/xref]thousand souls.
verse.note: By water ([link]10:47-48[/link]). See notes [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link], [link]19[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 28[/link], and [link book="1 Pet." chapter="3"]20[sup]3[/sup][/link], [link]21[sup]1[/sup][/link], and [link]21[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Pet. 3[/link].

verse.text: And they continued steadfastly in the [note]1[/note]teaching and the fellowship of the apostles, in the [xref]a[/xref]breaking of bread and the [xref]b[/xref]prayers.
verse.note: The first group of believers produced through the apostles' preaching and ministering of Christ on the day of Pentecost continued steadfastly in four things: teaching, fellowship, breaking of bread, and prayers. Teaching is the unveiling of God's New Testament economy concerning Christ and the church; fellowship is the communion and communication between the believers in their communion and communication with God the Father and Christ the Son; breaking of bread is the remembrance of the Lord in His accomplishing of God's full redemption; and prayer is cooperation with the Lord in heaven for the carrying out of God's New Testament economy on earth. The first two, teaching and fellowship, conjoined by [i]and[/i] to be one group, are of the apostles, but breaking of bread and prayers are not, indicating that besides the teaching and fellowship of the apostles, the believers in Christ should not have any other teaching and fellowship. In God's New Testament economy there is only one category of teaching revealed and recognized by God — the teaching of the apostles — and only one category of fellowship that is of God and is acceptable to Him — the fellowship of the apostles, which is with the Father and the Son, Jesus Christ ([link]1 John 1:3[/link] and note 3), and which is the unique fellowship of the unique church, the Body of Christ. The last two, the breaking of bread and prayer, also conjoined by [i]and[/i] to be another group, are practices of the believers in their Christian life and are not related directly to God's economy for the keeping of the oneness of the church, the Body of Christ. Hence, they are not of the apostles, who brought in God's New Testament revelation and His fellowship among all the believers in Christ.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]fear was upon every soul; and many [note]1[/note]wonders and [xref]b[/xref]signs took place through the apostles.
verse.note: Wonders and signs are not part of God's central testimony, which is the incarnated, crucified, resurrected, and ascended Christ; neither are they part of His full salvation. They are only evidences that what the apostles preached and ministered and the way they acted were absolutely of God, not of man ([link]Heb. 2:3-4[/link]).

verse.text: And all those who believed were together and had all things [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]common;
verse.note: Also in [link]4:32[/link]. Having all things common was not a sign of love but of Christ's dynamic salvation, which saved the believers from greediness and selfishness. It was practiced for only a short time at the initiation of God's New Testament economy; it did not continue for the long run as a practice of legality (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link]) in the church life during Paul's ministry, as proved by his words in [link]2 Cor. 9[/link] and other places.

verse.text: And they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sold their properties and possessions and [xref]b[/xref]divided them to all, as anyone had need.
verse.note: This too was an evidence of the Lord's dynamic salvation, which caused the believers to overcome earthly possessions, which occupy, possess, and usurp all fallen mankind ([link]Matt. 19:21-24[/link]; [link]Luke 12:13-19[/link], [link]33-34[/link]; [link]14:33[/link]; [link]16:13-14[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 6:17[/link]).

verse.text: And day by day, continuing steadfastly with [xref]a[/xref]one accord in the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]temple and [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]breaking bread from [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]house to house, they partook of [i]their[/i] food with exultation and [note]4[/note]simplicity of heart,
verse.note: In the initiation of God's New Testament economy, the early believers and even the first group of apostles were not clear that God had forsaken Judaism with its practices and facilities, including the temple (see [link]Matt. 23:38[/link] — "your house," referring to the God-forsaken temple). Hence, according to their tradition and habit, they still went to the temple for their New Testament meeting.
The early believers remembered the Lord by breaking bread daily in their houses; this showed their love and enthusiasm toward the Lord.

Or, at home; in contrast to [i]in the temple.[/i] Meeting in homes as the Christian way of meeting together is fitting to God's New Testament economy. This way differs from the Judaic way of meeting in the synagogues ([link]6:9[/link]). It became a continual and general practice in the churches (cf. [link]Rom. 16:5[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 16:19[/link]; [link]Col. 4:15[/link]; [link]Philem. 2[/link]).
Or, singleness; describing the heart's being simple, single, and plain, having one love and desire and one goal in seeking after the Lord.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Praising God and [note]1[/note]having grace with all the people. And the Lord [xref]b[/xref]added [note]2[/note]together [xref]c[/xref]day by day those who were being [xref]d[/xref]saved.
verse.note: They lived a life that expressed God's attributes in human virtues, as Jesus, the Man-Savior, did ([link]Luke 2:52[/link]).

This indicates that from the very beginning of their Christian life the early believers were brought into the corporate church life; they did not live individualistically as Christians separated from one another.

verse.text: Now Peter and John were going up into the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]temple at the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]ninth-hour prayer;
verse.note: See note [link]46[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]. It was not only the early believers who were not clear concerning God's New Testament economy in relation to the Judaic temple; even the early apostles did not have a clear vision concerning God's abandoning of the Judaic things. Hence, even after God poured out the Spirit upon them on the day of Pentecost to initiate a new dispensation, they still would not separate themselves from the Judaic temple. At the initial stage God tolerated their ignorance in this matter. But this led to a mixture of the church with Judaism, which was not condemned by the early church in Jerusalem (cf. [link]21:20-26[/link]). Eventually, the temple was destroyed by Titus with his Roman army in A.D. 70, as prophesied by the Lord in [link]Matt. 23:38[/link] and [link]24:2[/link]. That destruction cleared up the religious mixture.

verse.text: And a certain man who had been [xref]a[/xref]lame from his mother's womb was being carried [i]there,[/i] whom they had laid day by day at the door of the temple which is called Beautiful to ask alms from those entering into the temple.
[i]And[/i] he, seeing Peter and John about to go into the temple, began to ask to receive alms.
And Peter, gazing at him with John, said, Look at us!
And he turned his attention to them, expecting to receive something from them.

But Peter said, [note]1[/note]Silver and gold I do [xref]a[/xref]not possess, but what I have, this I give to you: In the [xref]b[/xref]name of Jesus Christ the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Nazarene [note]3[/note]rise up and walk.
verse.note: Peter did not possess silver and gold, but St. Peter's Cathedral in Rome was constructed with a superabundance of gold. He did not have silver and gold, but he had the name, the person, of Jesus Christ. He was poor in silver and gold but rich in Christ. The Roman Church is filled with gold but not with the person of Christ. She is rich in gold but poor in Christ.
Indicating the One despised by the Jewish leaders ([link]John 1:45-46[/link]; [link]Acts 22:8[/link]; [link]24:5[/link]).
Some MSS omit, rise up and.

verse.text: And he seized him by the right hand and raised him up; and instantly his feet and ankles were made strong.
And [xref]a[/xref]leaping up and about, he stood and began to walk, and he entered with them into the temple, walking and leaping and [xref]b[/xref]praising God.
And all the [xref]a[/xref]people saw him walking and praising God,
And they recognized him, that he was the one who had been sitting for alms at the temple's Beautiful Gate; and they were filled with amazement and astonishment at what had happened to him.
And while he was holding on to Peter and John, all the people ran together toward them at the [xref]a[/xref]portico called Solomon's, greatly amazed.

And when Peter saw [i]this,[/i] he replied to the people, [note]1[/note]Men of Israel, why are you marveling at this? Or why are you gazing at us, as though by our own power or godliness we have made him walk?
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]God of Abraham and [note]2[/note]Isaac and Jacob, the God of our fathers, has [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]glorified His [xref]c[/xref]Servant Jesus, whom you [xref]d[/xref]delivered up and [xref]e[/xref]denied in the presence of [xref]f[/xref]Pilate, when he had decided to [xref]g[/xref]release [i]Him.[/i]
verse.note: The Triune God, Jehovah the great I Am ([link]Exo. 3:14-15[/link]).
Some MSS add [i]the God of[/i] before [i]Isaac[/i] and before [i]Jacob.[/i]
Through His resurrection and in His ascension ([link]Luke 24:26[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:9[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:20-22[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:9-11[/link]).

verse.text: But you denied the [xref]a[/xref]holy and [xref]b[/xref]righteous One and [xref]c[/xref]asked that a man [i]who was[/i] a murderer be granted to you;
And the [note]1[/note]Author of [xref]a[/xref]life you [xref]b[/xref]killed, whom [note]2[/note]God has [xref]c[/xref]raised from the dead, of [note]3[/note]which we are [xref]d[/xref]witnesses.
verse.note: The Greek word here means [i]author, origin, originator, chief leader, captain[/i] (see note [link]10[sup]4[/sup] in Heb. 2[/link]). Here it denotes Christ as the origin or Originator of life, hence the Author of life, in contrast to [i]a murderer[/i] in the previous verse.
See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See note [link]32[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]upon faith in His [xref]a[/xref]name, His [note]2[/note]name has made this man strong, whom you behold and know; and the faith which is through Him has given him this wholeness [i]of health[/i] before you all.
verse.note: I.e., on the ground of faith in His name.
Denoting the person. The person is the reality of the name; hence, the name is powerful.

verse.text: And now, brothers, I know that you acted in [xref]a[/xref]ignorance, as also your rulers did;
But the things which God [note]1[/note]announced beforehand through the mouth of all the prophets, that [xref]a[/xref]His Christ would [xref]b[/xref]suffer, He has thus fulfilled.
verse.note: First, the redeeming death of Christ was determined by God in eternity ([link]2:23[/link]) and announced beforehand through the prophets in the Old Testament time. This proves again that Christ's death was not a historical accident but an act planned by God according to the purpose of His good pleasure and announced beforehand through the prophets.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Repent therefore and turn, that your sins may be [xref]b[/xref]wiped away,
So that seasons of [note]1[/note]refreshing may come from the presence of the [note]2[/note]Lord and that He may send the Christ, who has been previously [xref]a[/xref]appointed for you, Jesus,
verse.note: Lit., cooling, reviving; hence, relieving, refreshing. The seasons of refreshing denote a time of revival of all things with joy and rest, referring to the times of restoration of all things in [link]v. 21[/link], which will be brought in by the coming of the Messiah in His glory, as taught and prophesied by the Savior in [link]Matt. 19:28[/link] (see note 1 there). It seems that Peter's word skips over the church age and goes directly from the time of Pentecost to the millennium. This may indicate that Peter did not have a clear vision concerning the church age in God's New Testament economy. The entire New Testament reveals that before the seasons of refreshing, the church occupies a considerable period of time in God's dispensation.
Referring to God.

verse.text: Whom heaven must indeed receive until the [note]1[/note]times of the [xref]a[/xref]restoration of all things, of which God spoke through the mouth of His holy [xref]b[/xref]prophets [note]2[/note]from of old.
verse.note: The times of restoration in the millennium, as prophesied in [link]Isa. 11:1-10[/link] and [link]65:18-25[/link], and referred to by Christ in [link]Matt. 17:11[/link] and [link]19:28[/link]. It will be brought in by His coming back.
Or, from the foundation of the world.

verse.text: Moses said, [xref]a[/xref]"A [note]1[/note]Prophet will the Lord your God [xref]b[/xref]raise up unto you from your brothers, like me; Him shall you [xref]c[/xref]hear in whatever things He speaks to you.
verse.note: Referring to the Lord Jesus.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And it shall be [i]that[/i] every soul who does not hear that Prophet shall be utterly [xref]b[/xref]destroyed from among the people."
And also all the prophets, from [xref]a[/xref]Samuel and those in succession after [i]him,[/i] as many as spoke, also announced these days.

You are the sons of the prophets and of the covenant which God covenanted with your fathers, saying to Abraham, "And [xref]a[/xref]in your [note]1[/note]seed shall all the families of the earth be blessed."
verse.note: Referring to Christ ([link]Gal. 3:16[/link]).

verse.text: To you [xref]a[/xref]first, God, having [xref]b[/xref]raised up His [xref]c[/xref]Servant, has sent [note]1[/note]Him to bless you in [xref]d[/xref]turning each [i]of you[/i] away from your wicked deeds.
verse.note: God sent back the ascended Christ first to the Jews by pouring out His Spirit on the day of Pentecost. Hence, the very Spirit whom God poured out is the very Christ whom God raised and exalted to the heavens. When the apostles preached and ministered this Christ, the Spirit was ministered to people.

verse.text: And as they were speaking to the people, the priests and the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]captain of the temple and the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Sadducees came upon them,
verse.note: I.e., the captain of the temple guard.
See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

verse.text: Being greatly disturbed because they were teaching the people and announcing [note]1[/note]in Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]resurrection from the dead.
verse.note: I.e., in the power (with the nature and character) of.

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]laid their hands on them and placed [i]them[/i] in custody until the next day, for it was already evening.
But many of those who heard the word believed; and the number of men came to about five [xref]a[/xref]thousand.
And on the next day their rulers and elders and scribes were [note]1[/note]gathered together in Jerusalem,
verse.note: This was a gathering of the Jewish Sanhedrin ([link]v. 15[/link]). In the four Gospels this Sanhedrin, composed of the Jewish leaders, became the strongest opponent of the Lord Jesus and His ministry and condemned Him to death ([link]Matt. 26:59[/link]). Now, in this book, the same Sanhedrin, with the same constituents, began the persecution of the apostles and their ministry ([link]5:21[/link]; [link]6:12[/link]; [link]22:30[/link]). This indicates that Judaism had fallen into the hand of God's enemy, Satan the devil, and was being used by him in his attempt to frustrate and even destroy God's move in His New Testament economy for the carrying out of His eternal purpose, that is, to bring His kingdom to the earth by establishing and building up the churches through the preaching of the gospel of Christ.

verse.text: As well as Annas the high priest and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Caiaphas and [note]2[/note]John and Alexander and as many as were of high-priestly descent.
verse.note: A high priest ([link]Luke 3:2[/link]).

John and Alexander might have been the kindred of the high priest. In any case, they must have been dignitaries among the Jews, since they are named with the leaders of the Jewish Sanhedrin ([link]v. 15[/link]).

verse.text: And they stood them in the midst and inquired, [note]1[/note]By what power or in what name did you do this?
verse.note: Lit., By what kind of power or in what kind of name...

verse.text: Then Peter, [note]1[/note]filled with the Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit, said to them, Rulers of the people and elders,
verse.note: Filled outwardly and economically (see note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]).

verse.text: If we today are being examined regarding a good deed [i]done[/i] to a [xref]a[/xref]sick man, by what means this man has been [note]1[/note]healed,
verse.note: Lit., saved.

verse.text: Let it be known to you all and to all the people of Israel that in the [xref]a[/xref]name of Jesus Christ the [note]1[/note]Nazarene, whom [note]2[/note]you [xref]b[/xref]crucified [i]and[/i] whom [note]3[/note]God has [xref]c[/xref]raised from the dead, in this [i]name[/i] this man stands before you in good health.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
[i]You[/i] here is emphatic.
See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: This is the [note]1[/note]stone which was [note]2[/note]considered as nothing by you, the builders, which has become the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]head of the corner.
verse.note: This word was spoken by the Lord in [link]Matt. 21:42[/link] (see note 1 there), quoted from [link]Psa. 118:22[/link]. It unveiled the Jewish leaders' rejection of Him and God's honoring of Him for the building of His habitation among His people on the earth. By this word Peter learned to know the Lord as the precious stone held in honor by God, as he expounded concerning Him in his first Epistle ([link]1 Pet. 2:4-7[/link]). Peter's quoting of this word indicates that he preached Christ not only as the Savior for the sinners' salvation but also as the stone for God's building. It is such a Christ who is the unique salvation to sinners, and it is in His unique name under heaven, a name despised and rejected by the Jewish leaders but honored and exalted by God ([link]Phil. 2:9-10[/link]), that sinners must be saved ([link]v. 12[/link]) not only from sin ([link]Matt. 1:21[/link]) but also to participate in God's building ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]).
Or, rejected. Implying to despise, to consider as nothing (cf. [link]Mark 9:12[/link]).
See note [link]42[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 21[/link].

verse.text: And there is salvation in no other, for neither is there another [xref]a[/xref]name under heaven given among men in which we must be [xref]b[/xref]saved.

And as they beheld the [xref]a[/xref]boldness of Peter and John and perceived that they were [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]uneducated men and [note]2[/note]laymen, they marveled and they recognized them, that they had been with Jesus.
verse.note: Lit., unlettered.
Referring to one without professional knowledge.

verse.text: And seeing the man who had been healed standing with them, they had nothing to say against [i]it.[/i]
But they ordered them to go away outside the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin and conferred with one another,
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]6[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: Saying, What shall we do to these men? For that indeed a notable [xref]a[/xref]sign has occurred through them is manifest to all who dwell in Jerusalem, and we cannot deny [i]it.[/i]
But in order that this would not be spread further among the people, let us threaten them that they no longer speak based upon this name to anyone.
And when they called them, they charged [i]them[/i] [xref]a[/xref]not to utter [i]anything[/i] at all nor teach based upon the name of Jesus.
But Peter and John answered and said to them, Whether it is right in the sight of God to listen to you [xref]a[/xref]rather than to God, you judge;
For we cannot but speak the things which we have [xref]a[/xref]seen and heard.

And when they had further threatened [i]them,[/i] they released them, finding no way that they could punish them on account of the [xref]a[/xref]people, because they all were glorifying God for what had happened;
For the man on whom this sign of healing had occurred was more than forty years old.
And when they had been released, they went to their [note]1[/note]own [i]people[/i] and reported all that the chief priests and the elders had said to them.
verse.note: Referring to the church people, who were made distinct and separate from the Jews by calling on the name of Jesus ([link]9:14[/link]). All the brothers and sisters in the Lord are the believers' own people.

verse.text: And when they heard [i]this,[/i] they lifted up [i]their[/i] voice with [xref]a[/xref]one accord to God and said, [note]1[/note]Sovereign Master, You are the One who has [xref]b[/xref]made heaven and earth and the sea and all things in them,
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]Sovereign Master[/i] denotes a master (of a slave), one who has absolute sovereign power, as in [link]Luke 2:29[/link]; [link]Jude 4[/link]; [link]Rev. 6:10[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 6:1-2[/link].

verse.text: Who, through the Holy Spirit, [i]through[/i] the mouth of our father David Your servant, has said, [xref]a[/xref]"Why did the Gentiles [note]1[/note]rage, and the peoples devise vain things?
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to snort like a horse;[/i] i.e., to be haughty, insolent.

verse.text: The kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers were gathered together against the Lord and against [xref]a[/xref]His Christ."

For truly in this city there were [xref]a[/xref]gathered together against Your holy [xref]b[/xref]Servant Jesus, whom You [xref]c[/xref]anointed, both Herod and [xref]d[/xref]Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles and the peoples of Israel,
To [xref]a[/xref]do what Your hand and Your counsel [note]1[/note]predestined to take place.
verse.note: Cf. [i]determined[/i] in [link]2:23[/link] and note 1.

verse.text: And now, Lord, look upon their threatenings and grant Your slaves to speak Your word with all [xref]a[/xref]boldness,
While [xref]a[/xref]stretching out Your hand to heal, and that [xref]b[/xref]signs and wonders may take place through the [xref]c[/xref]name of Your [xref]d[/xref]holy Servant Jesus.

And when they had [i]so[/i] besought, the place in which they were gathered was [xref]a[/xref]shaken, and they were all [note]1[/note]filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak the word of God with [xref]b[/xref]boldness.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]heart and [xref]b[/xref]soul of the multitude of those who had believed was one; and [note]1[/note]not even one said that any of his possessions was his own, but all things were [note]2[/note]common to them.
verse.note: See note [link]45[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See note [link]44[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And with great [xref]a[/xref]power the apostles gave [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]testimony of the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and great [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]grace was upon them all.
verse.note: See note [link]32[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See notes [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in John 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link].

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]neither was anyone among them in need; for as many as were owners of lands or of houses [note]1[/note]sold [i]them[/i] and brought the proceeds of the things which were sold
verse.note: See note [link]45[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And placed [i]them[/i] at the [xref]a[/xref]feet of the apostles; and it was [xref]b[/xref]distributed to each, as anyone had need.
And Joseph, who was surnamed [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Barnabas by the apostles (which is translated, Son of encouragement), a [xref]b[/xref]Levite, a [xref]c[/xref]Cyprian by birth,
verse.note: Aramaic, meaning [i]son of prophecy,[/i] applied figuratively to one who speaks to encourage, exhort, and console people.

verse.text: Who possessed a field, sold [i]it[/i] and brought the sum of money and placed [i]it[/i] at the feet of the apostles.
But a certain man named Ananias, with Sapphira his wife, sold a piece of property
And put aside for himself some of the proceeds, his wife also being aware of it. And he brought some part [i]of it[/i] and laid [i]it[/i] at the [xref]a[/xref]feet of the apostles.
But Peter said, Ananias, why has [xref]a[/xref]Satan filled your heart to deceive the [note]1[/note]Holy [xref]b[/xref]Spirit and to put aside for yourself some of the proceeds of the land?
verse.note: Ananias lied apparently to the apostles but actually to the Holy Spirit, who is God ([link]v. 4[/link]). In the apostles' work for the Lord, the Holy Spirit and the apostles were one. See note [link]32[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: While it remained, [note]1[/note]was it not your own? And when it was sold, [note]1[/note]was it not under your authority? Why [i]is it[/i] that you have [note]2[/note]contrived this thing in your heart? You have not lied to men but to [note]3[/note]God.
verse.note: These words indicate that to sell property and distribute the proceeds to others was not considered by the apostles to be a practice of legality.
Or, placed, fixed.
This proves that the Holy Spirit, mentioned in [link]v. 3[/link], is God.

verse.text: And when Ananias heard these words, he [xref]a[/xref]fell down and [note]1[/note]expired; and great [xref]b[/xref]fear came upon all those who heard [i]this.[/i]
verse.note: Lit., gave up his soul, or, breathed out his soul (so also in [link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: And the young men arose and wrapped him up; and carrying [i]him[/i] out, they buried [i]him.[/i]
And it happened that after an interval of about three hours, his wife, not knowing what had happened, came in.
And Peter answered her, Tell me whether you have sold the land for this much? And she said, Yes, for this much.

And Peter [i]said[/i] to her, Why [i]is it[/i] that it was [note]1[/note]agreed between you [i]two[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]test the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit of the [note]2[/note]Lord? Behold, the feet of those who have buried your husband are at the door, and they will carry you out.
verse.note: Wives should be subject to their husbands ([link]Eph. 5:24[/link]), but they should not agree with their husbands to commit sins.
The Holy Spirit in [link]v. 3[/link], God in [link]v. 4[/link], and the Lord in this verse are all one, especially in the experience of the believers.

verse.text: And she [xref]a[/xref]fell down instantly at his feet and expired. And the young men came in and found her dead; and carrying [i]her[/i] out, they buried [i]her[/i] with her husband.
And great [xref]a[/xref]fear came upon the whole [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]church and upon all those who heard these things.
verse.note: Gk. [i]ekklesia,[/i] composed of [i]ek,[/i] out, and a derivative of [i]kaleo,[/i] called; hence, the called out (congregation), the assembly. It is the first time that the church is mentioned here in Acts as a local church (see notes [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and [link]17[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 18[/link]).

verse.text: And through the hands of the apostles many [note]1[/note]signs and wonders took place among the people; and they were all with one [xref]a[/xref]accord in the [xref]b[/xref]portico of Solomon.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And none of the rest dared to join themselves to them, but the [xref]a[/xref]people magnified them.
And believers were all the more being added [xref]a[/xref]to the Lord, [xref]b[/xref]multitudes of both men and women,

So that they even carried the sick out into the [xref]a[/xref]streets and placed [i]them[/i] on cots and mats, in order that when Peter came, at least his shadow might [xref]b[/xref]overshadow some of them.
And the multitude from the cities surrounding Jerusalem also came together, carrying the [xref]a[/xref]sick and those troubled by unclean spirits, for such ones were all being healed.
And the high priest and all those with him, the local [xref]a[/xref]sect of the [xref]b[/xref]Sadducees, rose up and were filled with [xref]c[/xref]jealousy;
And they [xref]a[/xref]laid their hands on the apostles and put them in public custody.
But during the night an [xref]a[/xref]angel of the Lord [xref]b[/xref]opened the doors of the prison, and leading them out, said,
Go and stand in the temple and speak to the people all the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]words of [note]2[/note]this life.
verse.note: The Greek word refers to instant words.

The divine life preached, ministered, and lived by Peter that overcame the Jewish leaders' persecution, threatening, and imprisonment. This word indicates that Peter's life and work made the divine life so real and present in his situation that even the angel saw it and pointed it out.

verse.text: And when they heard [i]this,[/i] they entered about daybreak into the temple and began to teach. And the [xref]a[/xref]high priest and those with him came up and called together the [xref]b[/xref]Sanhedrin, [note]1[/note]even all the council of elders of the sons of Israel, and sent [i]men[/i] to the prison for them to be brought.
verse.note: Or, and.

verse.text: But when the officers arrived, they did not find them in the prison; and they returned and reported,
Saying, The prison we found locked with all security, and the guards standing at the doors; but when we opened [i]the doors,[/i] we found no one inside.
Now when they heard these words, both the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]captain of the temple and the chief priests were utterly perplexed concerning them [i]as to[/i] what this would come to.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: And someone came up and reported to them, Behold, the men whom you put in the prison are standing in the temple and teaching the people.
Then the captain with the officers went away and brought them without violence, for they feared the [xref]a[/xref]people, lest they would be [xref]b[/xref]stoned.
And having brought them, they stood [i]them[/i] in the [xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin. And the high priest questioned them,
