Saying, We [note]1[/note]strictly charged you [xref]a[/xref]not to teach based upon this name; and behold, you have filled Jerusalem with your teaching and intend to bring this man's [xref]b[/xref]blood upon us.
verse.note: Lit., charged you with a charge.

verse.text: But Peter and the apostles answered and said, It is necessary to obey God [xref]a[/xref]rather than men.
The [note]1[/note]God of our [xref]a[/xref]fathers has [xref]b[/xref]raised Jesus, whom you slew by hanging [i]Him[/i] on a [xref]c[/xref]tree.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: This One God has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]exalted to His [xref]b[/xref]right hand as [note]2[/note]Leader and [xref]c[/xref]Savior, to [note]3[/note]give [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]repentance to Israel and [xref]e[/xref]forgiveness of sins.
verse.note: Jesus' incarnation made Him a man, His human living on earth qualified Him to be man's Savior, His crucifixion accomplished full redemption for man, His resurrection vindicated His redemptive work, and His exaltation inaugurated Him to be the ruling Leader that He might be the Savior. This exalting of Him was the ultimate step in His being perfected to be the Savior of man ([link]Heb. 2:10[/link]; [link]5:9[/link]).

Or, Prince; the same Greek word as for [i]Author[/i] in [link]3:15[/link]. See note 1 there. God exalted the man Jesus, who had been rejected and killed by the Jewish leaders, as the highest Leader, the Prince, the Ruler of the kings to rule over the world ([link]Rev. 1:5[/link]; [link]19:16[/link]), and the Savior to save God's chosen people. [i]Leader[/i] is related to His authority, and [i]Savior[/i] to His salvation. He rules sovereignly over the earth with His authority that the environment might be fit for God's chosen people to receive His salvation (cf. [link]17:26-27[/link]; [link]John 17:2[/link]).

To give repentance and forgiveness of sins to God's chosen people requires Christ to be exalted as a ruling Leader and Savior. His sovereign ruling causes and leads God's chosen people to repent, and His salvation, which is based on His redemption, affords them forgiveness of sins.

Repentance is for forgiveness of sins ([link]Mark 1:4[/link]). On God's side, forgiveness of sins is based on Christ's redemption ([link]Eph. 1:7[/link]); on man's side, forgiveness of sins is through man's repentance.

verse.text: And we are [xref]a[/xref]witnesses of these [note]1[/note]things, and [i]so is[/i] the Holy [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Spirit, whom God has given to those who [note]3[/note]obey Him.
verse.note: Lit., words; referring to instant words.
The Holy Spirit was one with the apostles. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Obedience is the way and the condition for one to receive and enjoy the Spirit of God.

verse.text: But when they [xref]a[/xref]heard [i]this,[/i] they were [note]1[/note]exasperated and intended to do away with them.
verse.note: Lit., sawn through; a strong figurative expression for being exasperated.

verse.text: But a certain [note]1[/note]Pharisee in the [xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin named [xref]b[/xref]Gamaliel, a [xref]c[/xref]teacher of the law honored by all the people, stood up and commanded that they put the men outside for a little while.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].

verse.text: And he said to them, Men of Israel, take heed to yourselves, with regard to these men, in what you are about to do.

For before these days Theudas rose up, saying that he was somebody, with whom a number of men, about four hundred, took sides. And he was done away with, and all who were persuaded by him were dispersed and came to nothing.

After him Judas the Galilean rose up in the days of the [xref]a[/xref]enrollment and drew away [i]a group of[/i] people after him. And that man perished, and all who were persuaded by him were scattered.
And now I say to you, withdraw from these men and leave them alone; for should this [xref]a[/xref]counsel or this work be of men, it will be overthrown;
But if it is of God, you will not be able to overthrow them, lest you be found to be even [xref]a[/xref]fighters against God.

And they were persuaded by him. And having called the apostles to [i]them,[/i] they [xref]a[/xref]beat [i]them[/i] and charged [i]them[/i] [xref]b[/xref]not to speak based upon the name of Jesus; and they released [i]them.[/i]
So they went from the presence of the [xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin, [xref]b[/xref]rejoicing that they were counted worthy [note]1[/note]to be dishonored on behalf of the [xref]c[/xref]Name.
verse.note: I.e., to suffer shame. It is a real honor to be dishonored on behalf of the Name, the very name of the man-dishonored but God-honored Jesus. Hence, the dishonored ones rejoiced that they were counted worthy to be dishonored on behalf of the Name.

verse.text: And every day, in the [note]1[/note]temple and from [note]2[/note]house to house, they did not cease teaching and [xref]a[/xref]announcing the gospel of [note]3[/note]Jesus [i]as[/i] the [xref]b[/xref]Christ.
verse.note: See note [link]46[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See note [link]46[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
Lit., the Christ Jesus.

verse.text: And in these days, as the disciples were [xref]a[/xref]multiplying [i]in number,[/i] a murmuring of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Hellenists against the [note]2[/note]Hebrews occurred, because their [xref]c[/xref]widows were being overlooked in the daily [xref]d[/xref]dispensing.
verse.note: Jews who spoke Greek. At the very beginning of the practice of the church life, trouble was caused by language differences; proper care was taken to solve this.
Jews who spoke Hebrew.

verse.text: And the twelve called the multitude of the disciples to [i]them[/i] and said, It is not [note]1[/note]fitting for us to forsake the word of God and serve tables.
verse.note: Or, pleasing.

verse.text: But brothers, look for seven [xref]a[/xref]well-attested men from among you, [note]1[/note]full of the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit and of [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]wisdom, whom we will appoint over this need.
verse.note: Gk. [i]pleres,[/i] an adjective form of [i]pleroo,[/i] according to the usage in this book here and in [link]v. 5[/link]; [link]7:55[/link]; [link]11:24[/link]; and in [link]Luke 4:1[/link]. Being full of the Spirit is the condition after one has been filled with the Spirit inwardly and essentially, as mentioned in [link book="Acts"]13:52[/link]. This refers to life, not to work.
This is proof that to be full of the Spirit is for life, as in [link]Luke 2:52[/link].

verse.text: But we will continue steadfastly in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prayer and in the [xref]b[/xref]ministry of the word.
verse.note: To pray is not only to entreat the Lord to do things for His move but also to cause our spirit to be exercised and strengthened. Hence, prayer should precede the ministry of the word, just as the apostles practiced. Without such prayer the ministry of the word will not be enlivened and empowered.

verse.text: And the word pleased all the multitude; and they chose Stephen, a man full of [xref]a[/xref]faith and of the Holy [xref]b[/xref]Spirit, and [xref]c[/xref]Philip and Prochorus and Nicanor and Timon and Parmenas and Nicolas, a [note]1[/note]proselyte of Antioch,
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: Whom they set before the apostles; and when they had [xref]a[/xref]prayed, they [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]laid their hands on [note]2[/note]them.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]4[/sup] in 1 Tim. 4[/link].

Since they were chosen to serve tables, they can be considered deacons, like those whom Paul and his co-workers appointed later in the churches ([link]Rom. 16:1[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:1[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:8[/link]).

verse.text: And the word of God [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grew, and the number of the disciples in Jerusalem [xref]b[/xref]multiplied greatly; and a large number of the priests [xref]c[/xref]obeyed the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]faith.
verse.note: [i]Grew[/i] refers to growth in life, indicating that the word of God is a matter of life that grows as a seed sown into man's heart ([link]Mark 4:14[/link]).

The objective faith, referring to what the believers believe in concerning Christ (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in 1 Tim. 1[/link]). The entire revelation of the New Testament concerning the person of Christ and His redemptive work is the faith of God's New Testament economy ([link]Rom. 16:26[/link]).

verse.text: And Stephen, full of grace and [xref]a[/xref]power, did great [note]1[/note]wonders and signs among the people.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: But some of those of the [note]1[/note]synagogue which is called the [i]synagogue[/i] of the [note]2[/note]Libertines and of the Cyrenians and of the Alexandrians and of those from Cilicia and Asia rose up and disputed with Stephen;
verse.note: Indicating that in Jerusalem there were a number of synagogues composed of the returned Jews according to the respective languages they had acquired in their dispersion (cf. [link]2:9-11[/link]). See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link].
I.e., Freedmen; those who were liberated from their status as slaves.

verse.text: Yet they were not able to [xref]a[/xref]withstand the wisdom and the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit with which he spoke.
Then they instigated some men to [xref]a[/xref]say, We have heard him speaking blasphemous words against Moses and God.
And they stirred up the people and the elders and the scribes, and they came upon [i]him[/i] and seized him and led [i]him[/i] to the [note]1[/note]Sanhedrin.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: And they set up [xref]a[/xref]false [xref]b[/xref]witnesses, saying, This man does not cease speaking words [xref]c[/xref]against this holy [note]1[/note]place and the law,
verse.note: The temple ([link]Matt. 24:15[/link] and note 4).

verse.text: For we have heard him saying that this Jesus the Nazarene will [note]1[/note]destroy this place and will change the [xref]a[/xref]customs which Moses delivered to us.
verse.note: This indicates that words must have been circulating among the believers concerning the destruction of the temple, as prophesied by the Lord in [link]Matt. 23:37-39[/link] and [link]24:2[/link], and concerning the termination of the dispensation of law, as spoken by the Lord in [link]Matt. 11:13[/link]. The opposing Jews twisted the believers' words, just as in [link]Matt. 27:40[/link], when they crucified the Lord, they twisted the word that the Lord spoke in [link]John 2:19[/link]. Undoubtedly, the Jews' opposition was instigated by Satan to frustrate God's New Testament economy. But the ground used by Satan for his instigation was the change of dispensation, which contradicted the Judaic traditions. God's New Testament economy is to have a new dispensation absolutely separated from Judaism. This offended the Jews by touching the traditions they had inherited for generations, and it stirred up their opposition, which began with the Lord's ministry in the Gospels and grew more fierce at the time of the apostles' ministry in this book, during which the Lord's New Testament move was passing through a transitional period. According to Luke's narration in Acts, the church among the Jews, including the early apostles, did not pass through this transition successfully, because of the remaining influence of their Judaic background and the entangling opposition from their Jewish kinsmen. This problem returned to trouble them again and again in this book ([link]11:1-3[/link]; [link]15:1-5[/link]; [link]21:18-26[/link]). Even the apostle Paul was in danger of being brought back to the Judaic practices in his last visit to Jerusalem ([link]21:20-26[/link]). See notes [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link] and [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in James 1[/link].

verse.text: And all those sitting in the Sanhedrin looked intently at him and saw his face as though [i]it were[/i] the [note]1[/note]face of an angel.
verse.note: Signifying a heavenly appearance. Stephen was a man on earth, but he bore a heavenly appearance while being persecuted.

verse.text: And the high priest said, Are these things so?

And he said, [note]1[/note]Men, [xref]a[/xref]brothers and fathers, listen. The God of [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]glory appeared to our father Abraham while he was in [xref]c[/xref]Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in [xref]d[/xref]Haran,
verse.note: More dignified and solemn than simply "brothers and fathers."

It might have been visible glory (cf. [link]v. 55[/link]), as when the cloud and the fire appeared to Israel ([link]Exo. 16:10[/link]; [link]24:16-17[/link]; [link]Lev. 9:23[/link]; [link]Num. 14:10[/link]; [link]16:19[/link]; [link]20:6[/link]; [link]Deut. 5:24[/link]) and filled the tabernacle and the temple ([link]Exo. 40:35[/link]; [link]1 Kings 8:11[/link]). It was the God of such glory who appeared to Abraham and called him. His glory was a great attraction to him. It separated (sanctified) him from the world unto God ([link]Exo. 29:43[/link]) and was a great encouragement and strength that enabled him to follow God ([link]Gen. 12:1[/link], [link]4[/link]). In the same principle, God calls the New Testament believers by His invisible glory ([link]2 Pet. 1:3[/link]).

verse.text: And said to him, [xref]a[/xref]"Come out from your land and from your relatives, and come into the land which I will show you."

Then he [xref]a[/xref]came forth from the land of the [xref]b[/xref]Chaldeans and dwelt in Haran. And from there, after his father [xref]c[/xref]died, He [note]1[/note]removed him into this land, in which you now dwell.
verse.note: Apparently Abraham journeyed into Canaan ([link]Gen. 12:4-5[/link]), but actually God removed him into the good land.

verse.text: Yet He did not give him an inheritance in it, not even a place to set his foot on; and He [xref]a[/xref]promised to give it to him for a possession and to his [xref]b[/xref]seed after him, while he had [xref]c[/xref]no child.

And God spoke in this way that his seed would be a [xref]a[/xref]sojourner in a [note]1[/note]foreign land, and [note]2[/note]they would [xref]b[/xref]enslave them and mistreat [i]them[/i] [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]four hundred years.
verse.note: I.e., Egypt ([link]Exo. 1:1[/link]).
I.e., the Egyptians ([link]Exo. 1:11[/link], [link]13-14[/link]).
See note [link]17[sup]3[/sup] in Gal. 3[/link].

verse.text: "And whatever nation they will [xref]a[/xref]serve as slaves I will judge," said God, "and after these things they will come forth and [xref]b[/xref]serve Me as priests in this place."

And He gave to him a [xref]a[/xref]covenant of circumcision; and thus [i]Abraham[/i] begot [xref]b[/xref]Isaac and circumcised him on the eighth day; and Isaac, [xref]c[/xref]Jacob; and Jacob, the [xref]d[/xref]twelve patriarchs.
And the patriarchs became [xref]a[/xref]jealous of Joseph and [xref]b[/xref]sold [i]him[/i] into Egypt; yet God was [xref]c[/xref]with him
And rescued him out of all his afflictions and granted him favor and wisdom before Pharaoh, king of Egypt; and he [xref]a[/xref]appointed him governor over Egypt and over all his house.
And a [xref]a[/xref]famine came over all Egypt and Canaan as well as great affliction; and our fathers could find no [note]1[/note]sustenance.
verse.note: Or, fodder (for their cattle).

verse.text: But when Jacob heard that there was [xref]a[/xref]grain in Egypt, he sent our fathers out the first time.
And during the second time Joseph was [xref]a[/xref]made known to his brothers, and Joseph's race became manifest to [xref]b[/xref]Pharaoh.
And Joseph sent [i]word[/i] and called for Jacob his [xref]a[/xref]father and all his family, [note]1[/note]seventy-five souls in all.
verse.note: Compare with seventy in [link]Gen. 46:27[/link] and [link]Exo. 1:5[/link]. Stephen quoted this number from the Septuagint, which mentions five additional descendants of Joseph in [link]Gen. 46:20[/link]. Hence, the number he mentioned of the house of Jacob who came to Egypt was seventy-five instead of seventy.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Jacob went down into Egypt; and he [xref]b[/xref]ended [i]his days,[/i] he and our fathers.
And they were carried over to Shechem and placed in the tomb which Abraham had [xref]a[/xref]bought for a sum of silver from the sons of Hamor in Shechem.
But as the time of the [xref]a[/xref]promise which God had assured to Abraham drew near, the people grew and were [xref]b[/xref]multiplied in Egypt,
Until [note]1[/note]another [xref]a[/xref]king rose up over Egypt who did not know of Joseph.
verse.note: Or, different (in character). Not only another king, but a king of different character.

verse.text: This one dealt [xref]a[/xref]craftily with our race and mistreated our fathers, so that they threw out their [xref]b[/xref]babies in order that they would not be kept alive.
At this time [note]1[/note]Moses was born and was [note]2[/note]lovely to God. And he was nurtured [xref]a[/xref]three months in his father's house.
verse.note: From [link]v. 20[/link] through [link]v. 44[/link] Stephen purposely gave a long narration in the most positive way concerning Moses. He did this to vindicate himself before his opposers, who had accused him of blaspheming Moses ([link]6:11[/link]).
Lit., fair to God. A Hebraism denoting fair in the sight of God; hence, exceedingly fair.

verse.text: And when he was [note]1[/note]thrown out, Pharaoh's [xref]a[/xref]daughter took him up and nurtured him as a son for herself.
verse.note: Or, put out (to die).

verse.text: And Moses was educated in all the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wisdom of the Egyptians, and he was powerful in his words and works.
verse.note: I.e., wisdom in learning.

verse.text: But when he was approaching forty years of age, it came into his heart to visit his [xref]a[/xref]brothers, the sons of Israel.
And when he saw one [i]of them[/i] being wronged, he defended [i]him,[/i] and he avenged him who was being oppressed by striking the Egyptian dead.
And he supposed that his brothers understood that God through his hand was giving salvation to them; but they did not understand.
And on the following day he appeared to them as they were [xref]a[/xref]fighting and tried to reconcile them in peace, saying, [note]1[/note]Men, you are brothers. Why are you wronging one another?
verse.note: A dignified and solemn form of address.

verse.text: But the one who was wronging his neighbor pushed him away, saying, [xref]a[/xref]"Who appointed you a ruler and a judge over us?
Do you want to do away with me the same way you did away with the Egyptian yesterday?"
And Moses [xref]a[/xref]fled at this word and became a sojourner in the land of Midian, where he begot two [xref]b[/xref]sons.
And when forty years had been fulfilled, an [note]1[/note]Angel appeared to him in the wilderness of Mount Sinai in the flame of a [xref]a[/xref]thornbush fire.
verse.note: Here and in [link]vv. 35[/link] and [link]38[/link] the Angel (Messenger) in the Old Testament was Christ the Lord, who is Jehovah, the Triune God ([link]Exo. 3:2-16[/link]; [link]Judg. 6:12-24[/link]; [link]Zech. 2:6-11[/link]). This is proved by [i]the Lord[/i] and [i]God[/i] in the following verses.

verse.text: And when Moses saw [i]it,[/i] he marveled at the vision; and as he approached to examine [i]it,[/i] there came the voice of the [note]1[/note]Lord:
verse.note: The Lord and God in [link]vv. 31-35[/link] are the Angel (Messenger) in [link]vv. 30[/link], [link]35[/link], and 38.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]"I am the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham and Isaac and Jacob." And Moses trembled and dared not [note]1[/note]examine [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: Or, take notice of; hence, examine.

verse.text: And the Lord said to him, [xref]a[/xref]"Untie the sandals from your feet, for the place on which you stand is holy ground.

[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]I have surely seen the ill-treatment of My people who are in Egypt and have [xref]b[/xref]heard their groaning, and I have come down to [xref]c[/xref]rescue them. And now, come, I will send you into Egypt."
verse.note: Lit., Having seen I saw. A Hebraism.

verse.text: This Moses, whom they refused, saying, [xref]a[/xref]Who appointed you a ruler and a judge? this one God has sent as both a ruler and a redeemer, along with the hand of the [xref]b[/xref]Angel who [note]1[/note]appeared to him in the thornbush.
verse.note: Or, was seen by him.

verse.text: This man led them [xref]a[/xref]out, doing [xref]b[/xref]wonders and signs in the land of Egypt and in the [xref]c[/xref]Red Sea and in the [xref]d[/xref]wilderness for [xref]e[/xref]forty years.
This is the Moses who said to the sons of Israel, [xref]a[/xref]"A Prophet will God raise up unto you from your brothers, like me."

This is the one who was in the assembly in the wilderness with the [xref]a[/xref]Angel who spoke to him in [xref]b[/xref]Mount Sinai and [i]with[/i] our fathers, [i]and[/i] who received living [xref]c[/xref]oracles to give to us.
To him our fathers were not willing to become obedient, but thrust [i]him[/i] away and [xref]a[/xref]turned in their hearts to Egypt,
Saying to Aaron, [xref]a[/xref]"Make gods for us who will go before us; for this Moses, who has led us out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him."
And they made a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]calf in those days and brought up a sacrifice to the idol and were glad with the works of their hands.
verse.note: Or, young bull.

verse.text: But God turned and [xref]a[/xref]delivered them up to [note]1[/note]serve the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]host of heaven, even as it is written in the [note]3[/note]book of the prophets, [xref]c[/xref]"Did you offer slain beasts and sacrifices to Me for [xref]d[/xref]forty years in the wilderness, O house of Israel?
verse.note: I.e., star worship.
I.e., heavenly bodies.
Probably referring to the twelve books of the minor prophets, from Hosea through Malachi, counting them as one book.

verse.text: And you took up the [note]1[/note]tabernacle of [xref]a[/xref]Moloch and the star of your god [note]2[/note]Rompha, the images which you made to worship. And I will carry you away beyond Babylon."
verse.note: I.e., the portable tent-temple of the god, to be carried in procession (Vincent).
The Coptic name for Saturn.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]Tabernacle of the [xref]b[/xref]Testimony was with our fathers in the wilderness, even as He who spoke to Moses instructed [i]him[/i] to make it, according to the [xref]c[/xref]pattern which he had seen.

This [i]tabernacle[/i] our fathers, having in their turn received, also brought in with [xref]a[/xref]Joshua when they took [xref]b[/xref]possession of the nations, whom God [xref]c[/xref]drove out before the face of our fathers until the days of [xref]d[/xref]David,
Who found favor before God and asked to find a [xref]a[/xref]habitation for the [xref]b[/xref]God of Jacob.
But Solomon [xref]a[/xref]built Him a house.
Yet the [note]1[/note]Most High does [note]2[/note]not [xref]a[/xref]dwell in that which is made by hands, even as the prophet says,
verse.note: Stephen called God "the God of glory" ([link]v. 2[/link]) and "the Most High" to vindicate himself before his opposers, who had accused him of blaspheming God ([link]6:11[/link]).

Implying that God would abandon the material temple of the Old Testament and initiate a new dispensation, that His people might worship Him in the spirit ([link]John 4:24[/link]), in which is God's spiritual habitation, the church ([link]Eph. 2:22[/link]).

verse.text: "Heaven is My throne, and the earth is a footstool for My feet. [note]1[/note]What kind of house will you build for Me, says the Lord, or what is the place of My rest?
verse.note: This quotation from [link]Isa. 66:1-2[/link] indicates that the Lord was seeking a spiritual habitation in man's spirit. This is proved by the unquoted part of [link]Isa. 66:2[/link] that says, "But to this kind of man will I look, to him who is poor and of a contrite spirit."

verse.text: Has not My hand made all these things?"

You [xref]a[/xref]stiff-necked and uncircumcised in [xref]b[/xref]hearts and [xref]c[/xref]ears, you always [note]1[/note]oppose the Holy [note]2[/note]Spirit; as your fathers [i]did,[/i] you also [i]do.[/i]
verse.note: A very strong expression.

Since Stephen was full of the Spirit ([link]v. 55[/link]) and was one with the Lord the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]), to oppose him was to oppose the Holy Spirit. Hence, the Lord indicated to Saul, one of Stephen's persecutors ([link]v. 58[/link]; [link]8:1[/link]), that he was persecuting Him ([link]9:4[/link]).

verse.text: Which of the [xref]a[/xref]prophets did your fathers not persecute? And they killed those who announced beforehand concerning the coming of the [xref]b[/xref]righteous One, whose betrayers and murderers you have now become,
You who received the [xref]a[/xref]law as [note]1[/note]ordinances of [xref]b[/xref]angels and did not keep [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: The Greek word is a noun; the verb form of the same word is used in [link]Gal. 3:19[/link] and is rendered [i]ordained[/i] there. The law of God was ordained through angels and became ordinances of angels.

verse.text: Now as they [xref]a[/xref]heard these things, they were [note]1[/note]exasperated and [xref]b[/xref]gnashed their teeth at him.
verse.note: See note [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: But being [note]1[/note]full of the Holy Spirit, he looked intently into heaven and saw the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory of God and Jesus [note]3[/note]standing at the [xref]b[/xref]right hand of God;
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
A great vindication and encouragement to the persecuted one.

The Lord in ascension is usually referred to as sitting at the right hand of God ([link]Matt. 26:64[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:3[/link], [link]13[/link]). But Stephen saw Him standing there. This indicates that the Lord was greatly concerned for His persecuted one.

verse.text: And he said, Behold, I see the [note]1[/note]heavens [xref]a[/xref]opened up and the [xref]b[/xref]Son of Man standing at the right hand of God.
verse.note: The earth rejected Stephen and was closed to him, but the heavens opened up to him, indicating that the heavens were with him and for him.

verse.text: But they cried out with a loud voice and covered their ears and rushed upon him with one accord.

And they threw [i]him[/i] [xref]a[/xref]outside of the city and [xref]b[/xref]stoned [i]him.[/i] And the [xref]c[/xref]witnesses laid down their garments at the feet of a young man called [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]Saul.
verse.note: Saul, who later became an apostle ([link]13:9[/link]), helped the persecutors in their slaying of Stephen.

verse.text: And they stoned Stephen as he [note]1[/note]called upon [i]the Lord[/i] and said, Lord Jesus, receive my [xref]a[/xref]spirit!
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]kneeling down, he cried out with a loud voice, Lord, do [note]1[/note]not hold this sin against them. And when he had said this, he fell [xref]b[/xref]asleep.
verse.note: Stephen prayed for his persecutors in the same way that his Lord, whom he loved and lived, had prayed for His ([link]Luke 23:34[/link]).

verse.text: And Saul [xref]a[/xref]approved of his killing. And there occurred in that day a great [xref]b[/xref]persecution against the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]church which was in Jerusalem; and all were [xref]d[/xref]scattered throughout the regions of [xref]e[/xref]Judea and Samaria, except the apostles.
verse.note: This was the first church established in a locality (see note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link]) within the jurisdiction of a city, the city of Jerusalem. It was a local church in its locality, as indicated by the Lord in [link]Matt. 18:17[/link]. It was not the universal church, as revealed by the Lord in [link]Matt. 16:18[/link], but only a part of the universal church, which is the Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link]). The record concerning this matter (the establishing of the church in its locality) is consistent throughout the New Testament ([link]13:1[/link]; [link]14:23[/link]; [link]Rom. 16:1[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 8:1[/link]; [link]Gal. 1:2[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:4[/link], [link]11[/link]).

verse.text: And devout men carried Stephen to his burial and made great lamentation over him.
But [xref]a[/xref]Saul was [xref]b[/xref]devastating the [xref]c[/xref]church, entering house after house; and dragging off men and women, he delivered [i]them[/i] to [xref]d[/xref]prison.
Those therefore who were scattered went throughout [i]the land[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]announcing the word as the gospel.
verse.note: It was sovereign of God that the scattering of the believers from Jerusalem to other localities through the persecution should carry out the spreading of the gospel for the fulfillment of the Lord's word in [link]1:8[/link] ([link]11:19[/link]).

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Philip [note]2[/note]went down to the city of [xref]a[/xref]Samaria and proclaimed the Christ to them.
verse.note: This was not the Philip among the apostles ([link]1:13[/link]) but the Philip among the seven appointed by the apostles to serve tables ([link]6:5[/link]). Through his ministry in preaching the gospel, as recorded in this chapter, he was manifested to be an evangelist ([link]21:8[/link]).

This was a further step in the Lord's evangelistic move. By this He spread Himself as the seed of the kingdom of God from the racially pure Jews to the racially mixed Samaritans for the fulfillment of His prophecy in [link]1:8[/link].

verse.text: And the crowds gave heed with one accord to the things said by Philip as they heard and saw the [xref]a[/xref]signs which he did.
For with many of those who had unclean spirits, [i]the spirits[/i] came out crying with a loud voice; and many who were paralyzed and lame were healed.
And there was much [xref]a[/xref]joy in that city.
And a certain man named Simon had previously been practicing [xref]a[/xref]magic in the city and had been [xref]b[/xref]amazing the people of Samaria, saying that he was someone great.
To him they all gave heed, from the least to the greatest, saying, This man is the power of [xref]a[/xref]God which is called Great.
And they gave heed to him because for a considerable time he had amazed them with his magic.

But when they believed Philip, who [note]1[/note]announced the gospel of the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God and of the name of [xref]b[/xref]Jesus Christ, they were [xref]c[/xref]baptized, both men and women.
verse.note: Philip announced the kingdom of God as the gospel just as the Lord had done ([link]Mark 1:14-15[/link]; [link]Luke 4:43[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: And even Simon himself believed, and once he had been baptized, he continued steadfastly with Philip. And as he beheld the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]signs and great works of power taking place, he was [xref]b[/xref]amazed.
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: Now when the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent to them Peter and John,
Who went down and prayed for them so that they might [note]1[/note]receive the Holy Spirit;
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]7[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: For He had [note]1[/note]not yet fallen upon any of them, but they had only been [xref]a[/xref]baptized [note]2[/note]into the [note]3[/note]name of the Lord Jesus.
verse.note: This does not mean that the believers in Samaria did not receive the Holy Spirit within them essentially when they believed in the Lord. According to the teaching of the New Testament in [link]Eph. 1:13[/link] and [link]Gal. 3:2[/link], they must have received the Holy Spirit essentially when they believed for their regeneration ([link]John 3:6[/link], [link]36[/link]). But they had not yet received the Spirit economically to identify them with the Body of Christ. The reason the Holy Spirit did not fall upon them outwardly and economically was so that the apostles, through whom the practical establishing of the church had been initiated in Jerusalem, might come to bring them into identification with the Body of Christ. This case is different from that of the ones in the house of Cornelius, who, when they believed in the Lord, received the Holy Spirit both essentially within them for regeneration and economically upon them for baptism into the Body of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]) and identification with the Body of Christ. That was because the gospel was preached then directly by Peter, who played the main role in the initiation of the practical establishing of the church.

Not [i]in the name[/i] but [i]into the name.[/i] The name denotes the person. To be baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus is to be baptized into the person of the Lord, to be identified with the crucified, resurrected, and ascended Christ, to be put into an organic union with the living Lord. See notes [link]38[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 2[/link] and [link]19[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 28[/link].[br][br]In [link]Matt. 28:19[/link] the Lord charged the disciples to baptize the believers into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit. But later, in practice, the believers were baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus, here and in [link]19:5[/link], and into Christ, in [link]Rom. 6:3[/link] and [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]. This indicates that (1) to be baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus is equivalent to being baptized into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, because the Lord Jesus is the Triune God, the embodiment of God Himself ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), and (2) to be baptized into the name of the Triune God or into the name of the Lord Jesus is equivalent to being baptized into the person of Christ.

Since the Samaritan believers had been baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus, that is, into the Lord Himself, they surely must have received the Spirit of life essentially within them that they might be not only born of the Lord but also joined to the Lord ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]), although they had not received the Spirit of power outwardly and economically.

verse.text: Then they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]laid their hands on them, and they [note]2[/note]received the Holy Spirit.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]4[/sup] in 1 Tim. 4[/link]. Peter and John were sent to Samaria not only to confirm the preaching of the gospel by Philip, one of the seven appointed to serve tables, but also to bring the church in Samaria, composed of Samaritans, with whom the Jews had no dealings, into identification with the Body of Christ by laying their hands on them. The Holy Spirit honored this laying on of hands and fell upon the Samaritans, signifying their identification with the Body of Christ. In this way the Samaritan believers received the Holy Spirit economically in addition to their having received the Holy Spirit essentially when they believed in the Lord Jesus.
See notes [link chapter="2"]4[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]17[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: But when Simon saw that through the laying on of the hands of the apostles the [note]1[/note]Spirit was given, he offered them [note]2[/note]money, saying,
verse.note: Some MSS add, Holy.
This indicates that Simon's practice of magic, which amazed people, was for money.

verse.text: Give me also this authority that on whomever I lay my hands he may receive the Holy Spirit.
But Peter said to him, May your silver go with you into [note]1[/note]destruction, because you thought that you would [xref]a[/xref]acquire the [xref]b[/xref]gift of God through money.
verse.note: Not eternal perdition but a punishment, as in [link]Heb. 10:39[/link] (see note 2 there) and [link]Matt. 7:13[/link] (see note 3 there). Simon had believed in the gospel and had been baptized ([link]v. 13[/link]); hence, he must have experienced salvation in its initial stage, but he had not been saved from his wicked thought and act concerning money. Therefore, he needed to repent of this wickedness that he might receive the Lord's forgiveness; otherwise, he would go with his silver into punishment.

verse.text: You have no part nor lot in [note]1[/note]this matter, for your [xref]a[/xref]heart is not straight before God.
verse.note: The gift of God ([link]v. 20[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Repent therefore from this wickedness of yours and beseech the Lord if perhaps the intent of your heart may be forgiven you;
For I see that you are in the gall of bitterness and in the bond of unrighteousness.
And Simon answered and said, You beseech the Lord on my behalf, so that none of the things which you have spoken may come upon me.

They therefore, having solemnly [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]testified and spoken the word of the Lord, returned to Jerusalem; and they [xref]b[/xref]announced the gospel to many villages of the Samaritans.
verse.note: To testify the word of the Lord is to witness according to personal experience of the Lord, and to speak the word of the Lord is to preach and teach according to the revelation of the Lord. See note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: But an [xref]a[/xref]angel of the Lord spoke to Philip, saying, Rise up and go south on the road that goes down from Jerusalem to [xref]b[/xref]Gaza. This is the desert [i]route.[/i]

And he rose up and went. And behold, an [note]1[/note]Ethiopian man, a [xref]a[/xref]eunuch, a man in power under Candace, queen of the Ethiopians, who was over all her [xref]b[/xref]treasure, had come to Jerusalem to [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]worship.
verse.note: Ethiopia is Cush ([link]Isa. 18:1[/link]), the land of the descendants of Cush, the son of Ham ([link]Gen. 10:6[/link]). The gospel had spread from the racially pure Jews to the racially mixed Samaritans through Philip and Peter and John ([link]vv. 5-25[/link]). Now the angel of the Lord directed Philip to contact an utter Gentile from Ethiopia. Through this the gospel spread southward to Africa.
Proving that the Ethiopian eunuch was seeking God (cf. [link]17:26-27[/link]).

verse.text: And he was returning and was sitting in his chariot and reading the prophet Isaiah.
And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit said to Philip, Approach and join this chariot.
verse.note: The mentioning of the Spirit here, as in [link]v. 39[/link]; [link]10:19[/link]; [link]13:2[/link]; and [link]16:6-7[/link], indicates that in this book the Lord's move in spreading His kingdom through the preaching of the gospel was by the Spirit's leading and directing, not by man's device and schedule. Hence, this move was not the act of man but the act of the Spirit. This is altogether different from today's degraded practice.

verse.text: And when Philip ran up, he heard him reading Isaiah the prophet and said, Do you really know the things that you are reading?
And he said, How could I [xref]a[/xref]unless someone guides me? And he entreated Philip to come up and sit with him.

Now the passage of Scripture which he was reading was this: "As a sheep [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]He was led to slaughter; and as a lamb before its shearer is dumb, so He does [xref]b[/xref]not open His mouth.
verse.note: Referring to Christ the Redeemer. It must have been sovereignly of the Spirit's leading that the eunuch opened to the passage concerning Christ as the sinners' redeeming Lamb, a passage good for gospel preaching.

verse.text: In His [xref]a[/xref]humiliation His judgment was taken away. Who shall declare His generation? For His life is taken away from the earth."
And the eunuch answered Philip and said, I beseech you, Concerning whom does the prophet say this? Concerning himself or concerning someone else?
And Philip opened his mouth, and beginning from this [xref]a[/xref]Scripture he [xref]b[/xref]announced Jesus as the gospel to him.
And as they were going along the road, they came upon some water, and the eunuch said, Look, [note]1[/note]water. What prevents me from being [xref]a[/xref]baptized?
verse.note: This indicates that Philip preached water baptism to the eunuch. In this gospel case, water baptism was particularly emphasized, but no mention was made of Spirit baptism. This should give us strong instruction that we must pay attention to water baptism, which signifies the believers' identification with Christ's death and resurrection ([link]Rom. 6:3-5[/link]; [link]Col. 2:12[/link]), as well as to Spirit baptism. Spirit baptism produces the reality of the believers' union with Christ in life essentially and in power economically, whereas water baptism is the believers' affirmation of the Spirit's reality. Both are needed (cf. [link]10:47[/link]), and neither can replace the other. All believers in Christ should properly have both, just as the children of Israel were baptized in the cloud (signifying the Spirit) and in the sea (signifying water) — [link]1 Cor. 10:2[/link]. See notes [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link], [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in John 3[/link], and [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in 1 John 5[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And Philip said, If you believe from all your heart, you will be saved. And he answered and said, I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.
verse.note: Many ancient MSS omit this verse.

verse.text: And he ordered the chariot to stand still, and they both went down into the water, Philip and the eunuch, and he [xref]a[/xref]baptized him.

And when they came up [xref]a[/xref]out of the water, the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit of the Lord [xref]c[/xref]caught Philip away; and the eunuch did not see him anymore, for he went on his way [xref]d[/xref]rejoicing.
But Philip was found in Azotus; and passing through, he [xref]a[/xref]announced the gospel to all the cities until he came to [xref]b[/xref]Caesarea.
But [xref]a[/xref]Saul, still breathing threatening and murder against the disciples of the Lord, went to the high priest

And asked for [xref]a[/xref]letters from him to Damascus for the [xref]b[/xref]synagogues, so that if he found any who were of the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Way, both men and women, he might bring [i]them[/i] bound to Jerusalem.
verse.note: Denoting the Lord's full salvation in God's New Testament economy. It is the way God dispenses Himself into the believers through Christ's redemption and the Spirit's anointing; it is the way the believers partake of God and enjoy God; it is the way the believers worship God in their spirit by enjoying Him and follow the persecuted Jesus by being one with Him; and it is the way the believers are brought into the church and built up into the Body of Christ to bear the testimony of Jesus (cf. notes [link book="2 Pet." chapter="2"]2[sup]2[/sup][/link], [link]15[sup]1[/sup][/link], and [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Pet. 2[/link]).

verse.text: And as he went, he [xref]a[/xref]drew near to Damascus, and suddenly a light from heaven flashed around him.
And he fell on the ground and heard a voice saying to him, Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Me?
verse.note: A corporate "Me," comprising Jesus the Lord and all His believers. Saul did not have this revelation. He thought that he was persecuting Stephen and other Jesus-followers, who were in the Way, which he considered heresy ([link]24:14[/link]). He did not know that when he persecuted these he persecuted Jesus, for they were one with Him by being united to Him through their faith in Him. He considered that he was persecuting people on earth, never thinking that he touched anyone in heaven. To his great surprise a voice from heaven told him that He was the One whom he was persecuting and that His name was Jesus. To him this was a unique revelation in the universe! By this he began to see that the Lord Jesus and His believers are one great person — the wonderful "Me." This must have impressed and affected him for his future ministry concerning Christ and the church as the great mystery of God ([link]Eph. 5:32[/link]) and laid a solid foundation for his unique ministry.

verse.text: And he said, Who are You, [note]1[/note]Lord? And He [i]said,[/i] I am Jesus, whom you persecute.
verse.note: Saul called Him "Lord," even without knowing Him (cf. [link]Rom. 10:13[/link]).

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]rise up and enter into the city, and it [note]1[/note]will be told to you [xref]b[/xref]what you must do.
verse.note: The Lord would not directly tell Saul immediately after his conversion what He wanted him to do. This was because he needed a member of His Body to initiate him into identification with the Body, for he had been saved and brought to the Lord directly by Him, not indirectly through any channel. Unless a member of His Body had been sent by the Lord to contact him, it would have been difficult for any member of the Body to receive Saul (cf. [link]v. 26[/link]). This is related to Saul's knowledge concerning the Body of Christ and to his ministry for the Body of Christ later ([link]Col. 1:24[/link]).

verse.text: And the men who journeyed with him stood speechless, [xref]a[/xref]hearing the voice but seeing no one.
And Saul rose from the ground; and though his eyes were open, he could see [note]1[/note]nothing. And they led him by the hand and brought him into Damascus.
verse.note: This was the Lord's dealing with Saul. Before this, Saul would have considered himself marvelously knowledgeable, as one who knew all things concerning man and God. Now the Lord made him blind so that he could see nothing until the Lord opened his eyes, especially his inner eyes, and commissioned him to open the eyes of others ([link]26:18[/link]).

verse.text: And he was three days without seeing, and he neither ate nor drank.
And there was a certain disciple in Damascus named [xref]a[/xref]Ananias; and the Lord said to him in a vision, Ananias. And he said, Behold, [xref]b[/xref]I [i]am here,[/i] Lord.

And the Lord [i]said[/i] to him, [xref]a[/xref]Rise up and [note]1[/note]go to the lane called Straight, and seek in the house of Judas a man from [xref]b[/xref]Tarsus named Saul; for behold, he is praying;
verse.note: The Lord sent Ananias, one member of His Body, to Saul that Saul might be initiated into identification with the Body of Christ. This too must have impressed Saul with the importance of the Body of Christ, helping him to realize that a saved believer needs the members of the Body of Christ.

verse.text: And he has seen in a [xref]a[/xref]vision a man named Ananias coming in and [xref]b[/xref]laying his hands on him so that he may [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]receive his sight.
verse.note: Or, regain. The blinded Saul's receiving of sight was his being saved in full. This was exceedingly important to him. It was especially important that his inner eyes were opened to see the things of God concerning His mysteries and His economy.

verse.text: But Ananias answered, Lord, I have heard from many concerning this man, how many evil things he has done to Your [xref]a[/xref]saints in Jerusalem;
And here he has [xref]a[/xref]authority from the chief priests to bind all who [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]call upon Your name.
verse.note: Indicating that in the early days calling upon the Lord's name was a sign of the Lord's followers ([link]1 Cor. 1:2[/link]). This calling must have been audible, so that others could hear; thus it became a sign.

verse.text: But the Lord said to him, Go, for this man is a [note]1[/note]chosen [xref]a[/xref]vessel to Me, to bear My [xref]b[/xref]name before both the [xref]c[/xref]Gentiles and [xref]d[/xref]kings and the sons of Israel;
verse.note: Because of this, Saul had been set apart from his mother's womb and called by the Lord ([link]Gal. 1:15[/link]). The Lord is sovereign and able, according to His choosing in eternity, to make the most fierce among His persecutors a vessel, a leading apostle, to carry out His commission in preaching the gospel and taking the way he had opposed and persecuted. Eventually, the opposing Saul became, in his victorious ministry of the gospel, Christ's vanquished captive in the triumphal procession celebrating Christ's victory over all His enemies ([link]2 Cor. 2:14[/link] and notes 1 and 2). The Lord's perfecting of His chosen vessels in such a way is excellent and glorious.

verse.text: For I will show him how [xref]a[/xref]many things he must suffer on behalf of My name.

And [xref]a[/xref]Ananias went away and entered into the house; and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]laying his hands on him, he said, Saul, brother, the Lord has sent me — Jesus, who appeared to you on the road on which you were coming — so that you may [xref]c[/xref]receive your sight and be [note]2[/note]filled with the Holy Spirit.
verse.note: Saul's case was a particular one also because, as the most significant persecutor, he had been saved directly by the Lord from heaven while on his way to persecute the believers. Hence, like the Samaritan believers ([link]8:14-17[/link] and note [link]17[sup]1[/sup][/link]) and the twelve disciples in Ephesus ([link]19:1-7[/link]), he needed a member of the Body of Christ to initiate him into identification with the Body of Christ by the laying on of hands.

Filled outwardly (see note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]). According to the principle of salvation in God's New Testament economy, Saul must have received the Holy Spirit of life essentially at the time of his conversion, prior to Ananias's coming and laying his hands on him. Before Ananias came, Saul was praying to the Lord ([link]v. 11[/link]), indicating that he had believed in the Lord and was calling on Him (cf. [link]Rom. 10:13-14[/link]) like those believers whom he had ravaged and was going to arrest ([link]vv. 21[/link], [link]14[/link]). But since he had not been saved through any member of the Body of Christ, the Holy Spirit did not fall upon him economically ([link]2:17[/link] and note 2) until Ananias came as the representative of the Body to identify him with the Body of Christ.

verse.text: And immediately there fell from his eyes something like scales, and he [note]1[/note]received his sight and rose up and was [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]baptized.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link].
By water (see notes [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 16[/link]).

verse.text: And once he had taken food, he was strengthened. And he was with the disciples in [xref]a[/xref]Damascus for some days.
And immediately he proclaimed Jesus in the [note]1[/note]synagogues, that this One is the [xref]a[/xref]Son of God.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link].

verse.text: And all who heard [i]him[/i] were amazed and said, Is this not the one who [xref]a[/xref]ravaged those who [xref]b[/xref]call upon this name in Jerusalem and came here for this, that he might bring them bound before the chief priests?
But Saul was all the more [xref]a[/xref]empowered, and he [xref]b[/xref]confounded the Jews dwelling in Damascus by proving that this One is the [xref]c[/xref]Christ.
And as a considerable number of days were being fulfilled, the Jews took counsel together to [xref]a[/xref]do away with him;
But their [xref]a[/xref]plot was made known to Saul. And they also [xref]b[/xref]watched the gates closely, both day and night, so that they might [xref]c[/xref]do away with him.
But his disciples took [i]him[/i] by night and [xref]a[/xref]let him down through the wall, [xref]b[/xref]lowering [i]him[/i] in a basket.
And when he arrived in [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, he tried to join himself to the disciples; yet all feared him, not believing that he was a disciple.

But [xref]a[/xref]Barnabas took hold of him and [xref]b[/xref]led [i]him[/i] to the apostles, and he related to them how [i]Saul[/i] had [xref]c[/xref]seen the Lord on the road, and that He had spoken to him, and how in Damascus he had spoken [xref]d[/xref]boldly in the name of Jesus.
And he was with them, [xref]a[/xref]going in and going out in Jerusalem, speaking boldly in the name of the Lord.
And he spoke and disputed with the [xref]a[/xref]Hellenists, but they attempted to [xref]b[/xref]do away with him.
But when the [xref]a[/xref]brothers realized [i]it,[/i] they brought him down to [xref]b[/xref]Caesarea and sent him forth to [xref]c[/xref]Tarsus.

So then the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]church throughout the whole of [xref]b[/xref]Judea and Galilee and Samaria had [note]2[/note]peace, [note]3[/note]being built up; and going on in the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]fear of the Lord and in the [note]5[/note]comfort of the Holy Spirit, it was [xref]d[/xref]multiplied.
verse.note: Since at that time the church had spread only to the regions of Judea, Galilee, and Samaria, and since the word [i]whole[/i] covers all the places where the church existed, [i]church[/i] in singular is used here in the universal sense, although there must have been churches in the local sense in a number of the cities of these three regions.

They had peace inwardly, although there was persecution outwardly. The church is afraid not of being persecuted outwardly but of not having peace inwardly, for only when there is peace can there be the building up.
The building up proceeded after the establishing of the church.

Not in the fear of men, although there were persecutions, but in the fear of the Lord lest the church offend the Lord by being put down or even subdued by the persecution, and lest she offend Him in other things.
Indicating that the church was suffering affliction through the persecutions, in which she feared the Lord and enjoyed the comfort of the Holy Spirit.

verse.text: Now as Peter was passing through all [i]those parts,[/i] he came down also to the [xref]a[/xref]saints dwelling at [note]1[/note]Lydda.
verse.note: A town about eleven miles southeast of Joppa, called Lod in the Old Testament ([link]1 Chron. 8:12[/link]; [link]Ezra 2:33[/link]).

verse.text: And he found there a certain man named Aeneas, who for eight years had been lying on a mat, [i]for[/i] he was [xref]a[/xref]paralyzed.
And Peter said to him, Aeneas, [xref]a[/xref]Jesus Christ heals you. [xref]b[/xref]Rise up and [note]1[/note]make up your own bed. And immediately he rose up.
verse.note: I.e., put in order.

verse.text: And all those dwelling in Lydda and [xref]a[/xref]Sharon saw him; and they [xref]b[/xref]turned to the Lord.
Now in [xref]a[/xref]Joppa there was a certain disciple named Tabitha (which, when translated, is [note]1[/note]Dorcas); this woman was full of [xref]b[/xref]good works and alms which she did.
verse.note: Meaning [i]gazelle.[/i]

verse.text: And in those days she became ill and died; and they bathed [note]1[/note]her body and laid [i]it[/i] in an [xref]a[/xref]upper room.
verse.note: Lit., her.

verse.text: Now because Lydda was near Joppa, the disciples heard that Peter was [note]1[/note]there, and they sent two men to him, entreating [i]him,[/i] Do not delay to come through to us.
verse.note: Lit., in it.

verse.text: And Peter rose up and went with them. When he arrived, they led him up into the upper room. And all the [xref]a[/xref]widows stood by him, weeping and showing [i]him[/i] [note]1[/note]tunics and garments, all of which Dorcas had made while she was with them.
verse.note: A shirt-like undergarment.

verse.text: And Peter put [i]them[/i] all [xref]a[/xref]outside; and [xref]b[/xref]kneeling down, he [xref]c[/xref]prayed; and he turned to the body and said, Tabitha, [xref]d[/xref]rise up. And she opened her eyes; and when she saw Peter, she sat up.
And giving her [i]his[/i] hand, he raised her up. And when he had called the saints and the widows, he [xref]a[/xref]presented her alive.
And it became known throughout all of Joppa and many [xref]a[/xref]believed on the Lord.
And he remained a considerable number of days in Joppa with a certain Simon, a [xref]a[/xref]tanner.
Now [i]there was[/i] in [xref]a[/xref]Caesarea a certain man named Cornelius, a centurion of what was called the [note]1[/note]Italian [note]2[/note]cohort,
verse.note: Here the Lord took a further step in His evangelistic work. By this He reached another utter Gentile, a man of Italy of the Roman Empire in Europe. Thus the door of the gospel was opened to all the Gentiles. It was difficult for the Jewish apostles and disciples, with their Jewish background and habit, to come near the Gentiles ([link]v. 28[/link]). Hence, this was an extraordinary move, needing the participation of an angel of God ([link]v. 3[/link]), just as when Philip approached the Ethiopian, a man from Africa, in [link]8:26[/link]. In the two cases the Spirit spoke to Philip and to Peter, respectively, in a particular way ([link]8:29[/link]; [link]10:19[/link]).
One of ten divisions of an ancient Roman legion. It was composed of six hundred men.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Devout and one who [xref]b[/xref]feared God with all his household, giving many alms to the people and beseeching God continually.
verse.note: Like the Ethiopian eunuch, Cornelius, the Roman centurion, was seeking God, as Paul mentioned in [link]17:27[/link].

verse.text: He saw clearly in a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vision around the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]ninth hour of the day an [xref]c[/xref]angel of God coming in to him and saying to him, Cornelius.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]3[/sup][/link].
I.e., 3:00 p.m. (so also in [link]v. 30[/link]).

verse.text: And he looked intently at him and became terrified and said, What is it, Lord? And he said to him, Your [xref]a[/xref]prayers and your alms have ascended as a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]memorial before God.
verse.note: Though Cornelius was part of fallen mankind, sinful and condemned before God like all others, God accepted his prayers and his alms, whereas He rejected Cain's ([link]Gen. 4:3[/link], [link]5[/link]). This must have been because of the fact that God, based on Christ's eternal redemption and in view of Cornelius's believing in Christ in the ensuing days, forgave him ([link]v. 43[/link]) according to His foreknowledge.

verse.text: And now send men to Joppa and send for a certain Simon, who is surnamed Peter;
This man is lodging with a certain Simon, a [xref]a[/xref]tanner, whose house is by the sea.
And when the angel who was speaking to him went away, he called two of his household servants and a devout soldier of those who waited on him;
And relating all things to them, he sent them to Joppa.
And on the next day as they were journeying and drawing near to the city, Peter went up on the [xref]a[/xref]housetop to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]pray around the [note]2[/note]sixth hour.
verse.note: Cornelius received a vision in prayer ([link]v. 30[/link]), and Peter also received a vision ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]19[/link]) in prayer, through which God's plan and move were carried out. Man's prayer is needed as a means of cooperating with God's move.
I.e., 12:00 noon (cf. [link]Psa. 55:17[/link]).

verse.text: And he became very [note]1[/note]hungry and wanted to [note]2[/note]eat. And while they were preparing, a [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]trance came upon him;
verse.note: Signifying seeking after the things of God ([link]Matt. 5:6[/link]). God fills the hungry with good things ([link]Luke 1:53[/link]).
A word usually rendered [i]taste.[/i]

The Greek word means [i]being put out of its place,[/i] referring to a state in which a man senses that he passes out of himself and from which he comes to himself (note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]), as in a dream but without sleep. It differs from a vision, as in [link]vv. 3[/link], [link]17[/link], and 19, in which definite objects are visible to human eyes. However, in this ecstasy, or trance, Peter saw a vision ([link]11:5[/link]).

verse.text: And he beheld [note]1[/note]heaven [xref]a[/xref]opened, and a certain [note]2[/note]vessel like a great sheet descending, being let down by four corners onto the earth,
verse.note: Indicating that the Lord's evangelistic move on earth is under His administration on the throne in heaven (cf. [link]Heb. 8:1[/link]; [link]Acts 7:56[/link]). All the apostles and evangelists were and still are carrying out the heavenly commission on earth for the spreading of the gospel of the kingdom of God.
The vessel that was like a great sheet symbolizes the gospel spreading to the four corners of the inhabited earth to collect all kinds of unclean (sinful) people ([link]Luke 13:29[/link]).

verse.text: In which were all the four-footed [note]1[/note]animals and reptiles of the earth and birds of heaven.
verse.note: Symbolizing men of all kinds ([link]vv. 15[/link], [link]28[/link], and notes).

verse.text: And a voice came to him: Rise up, Peter; slay and [note]1[/note]eat!
verse.note: In this sign, to eat is to associate with people ([link]v. 28[/link]).

verse.text: But Peter said, By no means, Lord, for I have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]never eaten anything [xref]b[/xref]common and [xref]c[/xref]unclean.
verse.note: As taught in [link]Lev. 11[/link]. Circumcision, Sabbath keeping, and a particular diet are the three strongest ordinances according to the law of Moses that make the Jews distinct and separate from the Gentiles, whom the Jews consider unclean. All these scriptural ordinances of the Old Testament dispensation became an obstacle to the spreading of the gospel to the Gentiles according to God's New Testament dispensation ([link]15:1[/link]; [link]Col. 2:16[/link]).

verse.text: And a voice [i]came[/i] to him again a second time: The [note]1[/note]things that God has [xref]a[/xref]cleansed, do not make common.
verse.note: Referring to people whom God has cleansed through the redeeming blood of Christ ([link]Rev. 1:5[/link]) and the renewing of the Holy Spirit ([link]Titus 3:5[/link]; [link]Acts 15:9[/link]).

verse.text: And this occurred three times; and immediately the vessel was taken up into heaven.

Now as Peter was utterly perplexed in himself [i]as to[/i] what the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vision which he had seen might be, behold, the men who were sent by Cornelius, having made diligent inquiry for Simon's house, stood at the gate.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]3[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And they called out and inquired whether Simon, who is surnamed Peter, was lodging there.
And while Peter was pondering over the vision, the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit said to him, Behold, [i]there are[/i] three men seeking you.
But rise up, go down and go with them, doubting nothing, because [note]1[/note]I have sent them.
verse.note: This indicates that Cornelius's sending of the three men was the Spirit's move and act through him even before his conversion.

verse.text: And Peter went down to the men and said, Behold, I am he whom you seek; what is the cause for which you have come?

And they said, Cornelius, a centurion, a righteous man and one who [xref]a[/xref]fears God and is [xref]b[/xref]well attested to by the whole nation of the Jews, was divinely instructed by a [xref]c[/xref]holy angel to send for you [i]to come[/i] to his house and hear [xref]d[/xref]words from you.
So he called them in and lodged [i]them.[/i] And on the next day he rose up and went away with them; and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]some of the brothers from Joppa accompanied him.
verse.note: In this strategic case Peter did not act individualistically but with some of the brothers, in the principle of the Body of Christ, that they might bear witness to the way in which God dealt with the Gentiles, that is, preaching the gospel to them through Peter's breaking of the Jewish tradition and habit ([link]11:12[/link]).

verse.text: And on the next day they entered into Caesarea. And Cornelius was awaiting them, having called together his relatives and intimate friends.
And when Peter entered, Cornelius met him, and [xref]a[/xref]falling at his feet, worshipped [i]him.[/i]
But Peter raised him up, saying, Rise up; I myself am also a [xref]a[/xref]man.
And as he talked with him, he entered and found many who had come together.

And he said to them, You understand that it is unlawful for a man [i]who is[/i] a Jew to join himself to or come near one of [xref]a[/xref]another race; yet God has shown me that I should not call any [note]1[/note]man [xref]b[/xref]common or unclean.
verse.note: This indicates that eventually Peter understood the significance of the vision he had seen in the trance ([link]vv. 11[/link], [link]17[/link], [link]19[/link]), that is, that the animals in the great sheet represented men.

verse.text: Hence, even without objection I came when I had been sent for. I ask therefore, For what reason have you sent for me?
And Cornelius said, Four days ago to this hour I was praying at the ninth hour in my house, and behold, a man stood before me [xref]a[/xref]in bright clothing,
And he said, Cornelius, your prayer has been [xref]a[/xref]heard and your alms have been [xref]b[/xref]remembered before God.
Send therefore to Joppa and call for Simon, who is surnamed Peter; this man is lodging in the house of Simon, a tanner, by the sea.
Therefore I sent [i]men[/i] at once to you, and you have done nobly in coming. Now therefore we all are present before God to hear all the things that have been commanded to you by the Lord.
And opening his mouth, Peter said, In truth I perceive that God is not a [xref]a[/xref]respecter of persons,
But in [xref]a[/xref]every nation he who [xref]b[/xref]fears Him and works [xref]c[/xref]righteousness is [note]1[/note]acceptable to Him.
verse.note: Those who fear God and work righteousness in every nation are still a part of fallen mankind. God accepts them in view of the redemption of Christ (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Outside of Christ, no fallen man is justified by his works ([link]Rom. 3:20[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:16[/link]).

verse.text: The word which He sent to the sons of Israel in announcing the gospel of [xref]a[/xref]peace through Jesus Christ (this One is [xref]b[/xref]Lord of [note]1[/note]all)
verse.note: Referring to men ([link]1 Tim. 2:4[/link]), not only Jews but also Gentiles.

verse.text: You yourselves know, [note]1[/note]the word which has been spoken throughout the whole of Judea, beginning from [xref]a[/xref]Galilee after the baptism which John proclaimed:
verse.note: Lit., the word which has taken place. The Greek word for [i]word[/i] here denotes instant words.

verse.text: Jesus, the One from [xref]a[/xref]Nazareth, how God [xref]b[/xref]anointed Him with the Holy [xref]c[/xref]Spirit and with [xref]d[/xref]power, who went about doing good and healing all those who were being [xref]e[/xref]oppressed by the devil, for God was [xref]f[/xref]with Him.

And we are [xref]a[/xref]witnesses of all the things which He did, both in the land of the Jews and in Jerusalem; whom also they [xref]b[/xref]did away with by hanging [i]Him[/i] on a [xref]c[/xref]tree.
This One, [note]1[/note]God [xref]a[/xref]raised on the [xref]b[/xref]third day; and He has made Him [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]manifest,
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
Lit., to become visible.

verse.text: Not to all the people, but to [xref]a[/xref]witnesses appointed beforehand by God, to us, ones who [xref]b[/xref]ate and drank with Him after [note]1[/note]He rose from the dead.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And He has [xref]a[/xref]charged us to proclaim to the people and solemnly [xref]b[/xref]testify that this is the One who was designated by God to be the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Judge of the [xref]d[/xref]living and the dead.
verse.note: At His coming back, before the millennium, the resurrected Christ will judge the living on His throne of glory ([link]Matt. 25:31-46[/link]). This is related to His second coming ([link]2 Tim. 4:1[/link]). After the millennium He will judge the dead on the great white throne ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]). See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link]. That will be the final clearance of the defiled old creation.

verse.text: To this One all the [xref]a[/xref]prophets testify that through His [xref]b[/xref]name everyone who [xref]c[/xref]believes into Him will receive [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]forgiveness of sins.
verse.note: This proves that even though Cornelius feared God and worked righteousness and his prayers and alms had been accepted by God, he still needed God's forgiveness of his sins through his believing into Christ, the Redeemer (see notes [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]35[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: While Peter was still speaking these words, the Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit [note]1[/note]fell upon all those [note]2[/note]hearing the word.
verse.note: Outwardly and economically (see note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]). In the case of the house of Cornelius, the Holy Spirit's entering into the believers essentially for life and falling upon them economically for power occurred simultaneously when they believed in the Lord. However, only His falling upon them economically is noted here, because it was outward and could be realized by others through their speaking in tongues and magnifying God ([link]v. 46[/link]). His entering into them occurred silently and invisibly. They received both aspects of the Holy Spirit directly from Christ the Head, without any mediatorial channel, before they were baptized in water by other members of the Body of Christ. This indicates emphatically that the spreading of the gospel of the kingdom of God to the Gentiles was of the Lord, and that the Head of the Body baptized the Gentile believers into His Body directly, without the laying on of hands of any member of His Body, in contrast to the cases of the Samaritan believers and Saul of Tarsus ([link]8:17[/link]; [link]9:17[/link]).
This included their believing into the Lord ([link]v. 43[/link]; [link]John 5:24[/link]; [link]Rom. 10:14[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:13[/link]).

verse.text: And the believers [i]who were[/i] of the [xref]a[/xref]circumcision, [xref]b[/xref]as many as had accompanied Peter, were amazed, because on the [xref]c[/xref]Gentiles also the [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]gift of the Holy Spirit had been [note]2[/note]poured out;
verse.note: The Holy Spirit Himself, not anything of the Holy Spirit given to the believers as a gift (see note [link]38[sup]6[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]).
By God from the all-inclusive, resurrected, and ascended Christ (see note [link]17[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]).

verse.text: For they heard them [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]speaking in tongues and [note]2[/note]magnifying God. Then Peter answered,
verse.note: Speaking in tongues was not the unique issue of receiving the Holy Spirit economically, because in this case the magnifying, that is, the praising, of God was also one of its issues, as was prophesying in the case of the twelve believers in Ephesus ([link]19:6[/link]). Hence, speaking in tongues is not the only evidence of receiving the Holy Spirit economically; neither is it the necessary evidence, because there is at least one case of the receiving of the Holy Spirit economically, the case of the Samaritan believers ([link]8:15-17[/link]), which does not mention speaking in tongues. In the case of Saul of Tarsus ([link]9:17[/link]) concerning this matter, there again is no mention of speaking in tongues, although he told us later, in [link]1 Cor. 14:18[/link], that he spoke in tongues.
The same expression as in [link]Luke 1:46[/link].

verse.text: Can anyone forbid the water so that these would not be [xref]a[/xref]baptized, who have received the Holy Spirit even [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]as we?
verse.note: Like the early apostles and the Jewish believers on the day of Pentecost ([link]2:4[/link]), the Gentile believers in the house of Cornelius received the Holy Spirit economically directly from the ascended Head. Only these two instances in the New Testament are considered the baptism in the Holy Spirit ([link]1:5[/link]; [link]11:15-16[/link]). By these two steps the Head of the Body baptized all His believers, both Jewish and Gentile, once for all into His one Body ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]). Hence, the baptism in the Spirit is an accomplished fact carried out by Christ in His ascension, on the day of Pentecost and in the house of Cornelius. None of the other cases — the Samaritan believers in [link]ch. 8[/link], Saul of Tarsus in [link]ch. 9[/link], and the twelve Ephesian believers in [link]ch. 19[/link] — are considered the baptism in the Holy Spirit according to the revelation of the New Testament. These other cases were merely the believers' experiences of the once-for-all-accomplished baptism in the Holy Spirit.[br][br]In this book, concerning the believers' receiving of the Holy Spirit economically, that is, the Holy Spirit's falling upon them, only five cases are mentioned. Two of them are for the accomplishing of the baptism in the Holy Spirit. These are the instances that occurred on the day of Pentecost and in the house of Cornelius. The other three — the cases of the Samaritan believers, Saul of Tarsus, and the twelve believers in Ephesus — are considered extraordinary, in that some members of the Body of Christ were needed to identify those believers with the Body by the laying on of hands. Besides these five cases, in many cases of conversion, such as the three thousand ([link]2:41[/link]), the five thousand ([link]4:4[/link]), the Ethiopian eunuch ([link]8:36[/link], [link]38-39a[/link]), the many who believed in Antioch ([link]11:20-21[/link], [link]24[/link]), the many instances in [link]chs. 13[/link] and [link book="Acts"]14[/link] under Paul's preaching ministry, Lydia in Philippi ([link]16:14-15[/link]), the jailer in Philippi ([link]16:33[/link]), the believers in Thessalonica ([link]17:4[/link]), the believers in Berea ([link]17:10-12[/link]), the believers in Athens ([link]17:34[/link]), the ruler of the synagogue and many other believers in Corinth ([link]18:8[/link]), and the believers in Ephesus ([link]19:18-19[/link]), there is no mention of the believers' receiving of the Holy Spirit economically — the Holy Spirit's falling upon the believers — because in all these cases the believers were brought into the Body of Christ in a normal way through their believing and had no particular need for a member of the Body of Christ to bring them into identification with the Body by the laying on of hands. According to the principle of God's New Testament economy, they all must have received the Holy Spirit essentially for life and economically for power in a normal way through their believing into Christ.

verse.text: And he charged them to be [note]1[/note]baptized [note]2[/note]in the [note]3[/note]name of Jesus Christ. Then they asked him to remain for some days.
verse.note: See note [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].
Cf. [i]into the name[/i] in [link]8:16[/link].

The name denotes the person (see note [link]19[sup]5[/sup] in Matt. 28[/link]). To be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ is to be baptized into the person of Christ ([link]Rom. 6:3[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]), which is also to be baptized into the sphere of His person (see note [link]38[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]).

verse.text: And the apostles and the [xref]a[/xref]brothers who were throughout Judea heard that the Gentiles also had received the word of God.
And when Peter went up to Jerusalem, those of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcision disputed with him,
verse.note: Circumcision was an outward ordinance inherited by the Jews from their forefathers, beginning from Abraham ([link]Gen. 17:9-14[/link]). It made them distinct and separate from the Gentiles. It became a dead, traditional formality, a mere mark on the flesh without any spiritual significance, and became a great obstacle to the spread of God's gospel according to His New Testament economy ([link]15:1[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:3-4[/link]; [link]6:12-13[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:2[/link]; see note [link book="Acts"]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link]).

verse.text: Saying, You went in to men who are uncircumcised and [xref]a[/xref]ate [xref]b[/xref]with them.
And Peter began, and he explained to them in sequence, saying,
I was in the city of Joppa [xref]a[/xref]praying, and I saw in a trance a vision, a certain vessel like a great sheet descending, being let down by four corners out of heaven; and it came unto me.
Looking intently into it, I examined [i]it[/i] and saw the four-footed animals of the earth and the wild beasts and the reptiles and the birds of heaven.
And I also heard a voice saying to me, Rise up, Peter; slay and eat!
But I said, By no means, Lord, for no common or unclean thing has ever entered into my mouth.
And a voice answered a second time out of heaven, The things that God has cleansed, do not make common.
And this occurred three times, and everything was drawn up again into heaven.
And behold, at that moment three men stood at the house in which we were, having been sent from Caesarea to me.
And the Spirit told me to go with them, [note]1[/note]doubting nothing. And [note]2[/note]these [xref]a[/xref]six brothers went with me also; and we entered into the man's house.
verse.note: Or, making no distinction.
The six brothers were present while Peter was speaking, as witnesses to his word.

verse.text: And he reported to us how he saw the angel standing in his house and saying, Send [i]men[/i] to Joppa and send for Simon, who is surnamed Peter,
Who will speak words to you by which you shall be saved, you and all your [note]1[/note]house.
verse.note: See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: And as I began to speak, the Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit fell on them just as also on us [xref]b[/xref]in the beginning.
And I remembered the word of the Lord, how He said, [xref]a[/xref]John baptized with water, but you shall be baptized in the Holy Spirit.
If therefore God has given to them the equal [xref]a[/xref]gift [xref]b[/xref]as also to us who have believed on the Lord Jesus Christ, [xref]c[/xref]who was I that I could have forbidden God?
And when they heard these things, they became silent and [xref]a[/xref]glorified God, saying, Then to the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles also God has given [xref]c[/xref]repentance unto [note]1[/note]life.
verse.note: Gk. [i]zoe,[/i] referring to the life of God ([link]Eph. 4:18[/link]), the eternal life ([link]1 John 1:2[/link]), the uncreated, indestructible life ([link]Heb. 7:16[/link]), which is Christ Himself ([link]John 14:6[/link]; [link]11:25[/link]; [link]Col. 3:4[/link]) as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), of which life the Spirit is ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]). This life is received by the believers through their believing into Christ ([link]John 3:15-16[/link]) after repentance, and issues in their full salvation ([link]Rom. 5:10[/link]). The gospel preached by Peter comprises the divine blessings not only of forgiveness ([link]5:31[/link]; [link]10:43[/link]) and salvation ([link]2:21[/link]; [link]4:12[/link]) but also of the Spirit ([link]2:38[/link]) and life. Forgiveness deals with people's sins, and life, with people's death ([link]John 5:24[/link]; [link]1 John 3:14[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:4[/link]).

verse.text: Those then who were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]scattered by the tribulation which took place on account of Stephen passed through as far as Phoenicia and Cyprus and Antioch, speaking the word to [note]2[/note]no one except Jews only.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].
