This indicates how strong the Jewish believers were in keeping their traditions. They would not come near the Gentiles ([link]10:28[/link]). This condition continued even after Peter's preaching to Cornelius, an Italian. It surely restricted the Lord's move in spreading His gospel according to God's New Testament economy.

verse.text: But there were some of them, [note]1[/note]men of Cyprus and Cyrene, who came to Antioch and [note]2[/note]spoke also to the [xref]a[/xref]Greeks, [xref]b[/xref]announcing the Lord Jesus as the gospel.
verse.note: They must have been from among the Jewish believers in dispersion (cf. [link]1 Pet. 1:1[/link]).

This was a further step of the Lord's move in spreading His gospel to the Gentiles after what happened in the house of Cornelius ([link]ch. 10[/link]) and before Paul's ministry to the Gentiles, which began in [link]ch. 13[/link].

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]hand of the Lord was with them, and a [xref]b[/xref]great number who believed [xref]c[/xref]turned to the Lord.
And the account concerning them was heard in the ears of the [xref]a[/xref]church which was in Jerusalem, and they [note]1[/note]sent out [note]2[/note]Barnabas to pass through as far as Antioch,
verse.note: The Greek word denotes being sent out (on a mission) as an authoritative representative. Barnabas was sent out from Jerusalem to visit the believers in other places; he was sent with authority from the apostles, not from the church, because the apostles were there in Jerusalem.

Saul was saved by the Lord directly without any preaching channel ([link]9:3-6[/link]) and was brought into identification with the Body of Christ through Ananias, a member of the Body of Christ ([link]9:10-19[/link]). However, he was introduced to practical fellowship with the disciples in Jerusalem through Barnabas ([link]9:26-28[/link]). Now Barnabas was sent from Jerusalem to go as far as Antioch to encourage the believers, and he went to Tarsus to bring Saul to Antioch ([link]vv. 25-26[/link]). This was a great step. It initiated Saul into the Lord's move in spreading the gospel of His kingdom to the Gentile world ([link]13:1-3[/link]; see note [link]25[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]).

verse.text: Who, when he arrived and saw the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of God, [xref]b[/xref]rejoiced and encouraged them all to [note]2[/note]remain with the Lord with [xref]c[/xref]purpose of heart;
verse.note: See notes [link]14[sup]6[/sup] in John 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link]. The grace that was seen by Barnabas must have been the Triune God received and enjoyed by the believers and expressed in their salvation, change in life, holy living, and the gifts they exercised in their meetings, all of which could be seen by others.
I.e., be persistently faithful to the Lord, cleave to Him, and live in close fellowship with Him.

verse.text: For he was a good man and [note]1[/note]full of the Holy Spirit and of faith. And a [xref]a[/xref]considerable [note]2[/note]number was [xref]b[/xref]added to the Lord.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
Or, crowd (also in [link]v. 26[/link]).

verse.text: And he went forth to [xref]a[/xref]Tarsus to search for Saul;

And when he found him, he brought him to [xref]a[/xref]Antioch. And it happened with them that for a whole year they were gathered in the [xref]b[/xref]church and taught a considerable number and that the disciples were first called [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Christians in Antioch.
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Pet. 4[/link]. That the disciples in Antioch were given such a nickname, a term of reproach, indicates that they must have borne a strong testimony for the Lord, a testimony that made them distinct and peculiar in the eyes of the unbelievers.

verse.text: And in these days [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prophets came down from Jerusalem to Antioch.
verse.note: See note [link]28[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Cor. 12[/link].

verse.text: And one of them named [xref]a[/xref]Agabus rose up and signified through the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit that there was about to be a great [xref]c[/xref]famine over the whole inhabited earth, which occurred during the time of [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]Claudius.
verse.note: A Caesar of the Roman Empire. In the fourth year of his reign, about A.D. 44, there was a famine in Judea and the neighboring countries.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]disciples, according to how one was [note]2[/note]prospered, determined, each one of them, to [xref]a[/xref]send [i]things[/i] [note]3[/note]for [xref]b[/xref]dispensing to the [xref]c[/xref]brothers dwelling in Judea,
verse.note: This verse shows that the believers' having all things in common ([link]2:44-45[/link]; [link]4:32[/link]), which was practiced at the time of Pentecost, had become a thing of the past at the time the matter here was mentioned, no more than ten years after Pentecost, long before Paul began his ministry to the Gentiles ([link]13:2-4[/link]). This word indicates further that there was no uniformly prescribed way in the early days of the church concerning the believers' giving of material things; rather, it was left to each believer to give out of his own will and his own initiation.

The Greek word here means [i]to[/i] progress favorably, or [i]to go on smoothly;[/i] hence, it denotes to thrive smoothly, to prosper, in an enterprise, an occupation, or other activities. Prosperity is given by God, and it issues in surplus and abundance.
Lit., for a service. Derived from the same Greek word as the word for [i]ministered[/i] in [link]Matt. 4:11[/link].

verse.text: Which also they did, sending [i]it[/i] to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]elders through the hand of [xref]b[/xref]Barnabas and [note]2[/note]Saul.
verse.note: This indicates that in the early days the finances of the church were under the management of the elders (see note [link]3[sup]5[/sup] in 1 Tim. 3[/link]).
Now Saul, through Barnabas, was brought into the service among the churches.

verse.text: Now about that time [note]1[/note]Herod the king laid hands on some from the [xref]a[/xref]church in order to [xref]b[/xref]mistreat them.
verse.note: Herod, Agrippa I, whose successor was King Agrippa (II) in [link]25:13[/link]. Both were different from Herod the tetrarch in [link]13:1[/link]. Thus far the church had suffered persecution only from the Jewish religion. Now Gentile politics began to participate in the persecution in cooperation with the Jewish religion ([link]v. 11[/link]).

verse.text: And he [xref]a[/xref]did away with [xref]b[/xref]James, the brother of John, with the [xref]c[/xref]sword.
And when he saw that it was [xref]a[/xref]pleasing to the Jews, he went on to arrest Peter also (now [i]those[/i] were the days of [xref]b[/xref]Unleavened Bread),

Whom also he [xref]a[/xref]seized and put in [xref]b[/xref]prison, delivering him to four [note]1[/note]quaternions of soldiers to guard him, intending after the [xref]c[/xref]Passover to bring him out to the people.
verse.note: A quaternion was a group of four soldiers.

verse.text: So then Peter was kept in the prison;[separator]but [xref]a[/xref]prayer was being made fervently by the [xref]b[/xref]church to God concerning him.
And when Herod was about to bring him forward, that night Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, [xref]a[/xref]bound with two chains; and guards before the door were keeping the prison.

And behold, an [xref]a[/xref]angel of the Lord [xref]b[/xref]stood by [i]him,[/i] and a light shined in the cell; and he [xref]c[/xref]struck Peter's side and roused him, saying, Rise up quickly. And his [xref]d[/xref]chains fell off his hands.
And the angel said to him, Gird yourself and tie on your [xref]a[/xref]sandals. And he did so. And he said to him, Throw your cloak around [i]you[/i] and follow me.
And he went out and followed [i]him;[/i] yet he did not know that what was taking place through the angel was real, but thought that he was seeing a [xref]a[/xref]vision.

And passing the first guard and the second, they came to the iron gate that leads into the city, which [xref]a[/xref]opened of itself to them. And going out, they went forward one lane; and immediately the angel departed from him.

And Peter [note]1[/note]came to himself and said, Now I know truly that the Lord has sent forth His [xref]a[/xref]angel and [xref]b[/xref]rescued me out of Herod's hand and from all the expectation of the Jewish people.
verse.note: Perhaps Peter felt that he had gone out of himself as in a trance; now he came to himself, that is, became sober. Cf. note [link]10[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: And when he became aware of [i]this,[/i] he went to the house of Mary, the mother of [xref]a[/xref]John, who was surnamed Mark, where there was a considerable number assembled together and [xref]b[/xref]praying.
And when he knocked at the door of the entry, a maiden named Rhoda came to listen.
And when she recognized Peter's voice, she did not open the gate for joy, but ran in and reported that Peter was standing before the entry.
But they said to her, You are crazy! But she insisted that it was so. And they said, It is [note]1[/note]his angel.
verse.note: Not only the apostle Peter had an angel; even the little ones among the believers have their angels ([link]Matt. 18:10[/link]). Angels are servants to the believers who inherit God's salvation (see note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 1[/link]). This is an arrangement in God's eternal economy.

verse.text: But Peter continued knocking; and when they had opened [i]the gate,[/i] they saw him and were beside themselves.

And [xref]a[/xref]motioning to them with his hand to be silent, he related to them how the Lord had led him out of the prison, and he said, Report these things to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]James and the [xref]c[/xref]brothers. And going out, he went to another place.
verse.note: This indicates that James was a leader among the apostles and among the elders of Jerusalem (cf. [link]15:13[/link]; [link]21:18[/link]; [link]Gal. 1:19[/link]; [link]2:9[/link], [link]12[/link]).

verse.text: Now when it became day, there was no small disturbance among the soldiers, [i]they not knowing[/i] what had become of Peter.

And when Herod searched for him and did not find [i]him,[/i][separator]he examined the guards and ordered that they be led off [i]to execution.[/i] And he went down from Judea to [xref]a[/xref]Caesarea and spent time [i]there.[/i]

Now he was furious with the Tyrians and Sidonians. And they came to him with one accord; and having persuaded Blastus, the king's [note]1[/note]chamberlain, they asked for peace, because their country was [xref]a[/xref]fed from the king's [i]country.[/i]
verse.note: One who takes care of the bed chamber.

verse.text: And on an appointed day Herod arrayed himself in royal clothing and sat on the judgment seat; and he delivered a public address to them.
And the populace cried out, The voice of a god and not of a man!
And instantly an [xref]a[/xref]angel of the Lord struck him because he did not give the [xref]b[/xref]glory to God; and he was eaten by [xref]c[/xref]worms and [note]1[/note]expired.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: But the word of [note]1[/note]God [xref]a[/xref]grew and multiplied.
verse.note: Some MSS read, the Lord.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem, having completed the [xref]a[/xref]dispensing; [i]and[/i] they took along with them [xref]b[/xref]John, who was surnamed Mark.
verse.note: [link]Verses 1-24[/link] are a parenthetical section, a record of Peter's persecution. This verse is a continuation of [link]11:30[/link], which, with the preceding verses from [link]11:22[/link], is a narration of Paul's initiation into his apostolic ministry (see note [link]22[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]). The passage from [link]11:19-12:25[/link] is a transitional record between Peter's apostolic ministry to the Jews in [link]chs. 2-11[/link] and Paul's apostolic ministry to the Gentiles in [link]chs. 13-28[/link] (cf. [link]Gal. 2:7-8[/link]).

verse.text: Now there were in [xref]a[/xref]Antioch, in the local [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]church, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]prophets and [note]3[/note]teachers: [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]Barnabas and Simeon, who was called [note]5[/note]Niger, and [note]6[/note]Lucius the Cyrenian, and [note]7[/note]Manaen, the foster brother of [note]8[/note][xref]e[/xref]Herod the tetrarch, and [note]9[/note][xref]f[/xref]Saul.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].
See note [link]28[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Cor. 12[/link].
See note [link]28[sup]4[/sup] in 1 Cor. 12[/link].
A Levite, a Cyprian by birth ([link]4:36[/link]).
Meaning [i]black[/i] and denoting a Negro, probably of African origin.
A Cyrenian from Cyrene in North Africa. He was a Jew if he was the Lucius in [link]Rom. 16:21[/link], a kinsman of Paul.
Herod was governmentally related to the Romans; hence, Manaen, Herod's foster brother, must have been Europeanized.

The one who killed John the Baptist ([link]Luke 9:7-9[/link]). It was the Lord's sovereign doing that the foster brother of John the Baptist's murderer became one of the leading functioning members in the church.

A Jew born in Tarsus and taught by Gamaliel according to the law of Moses ([link]22:3[/link]). The five prophets and teachers recorded here were composed of Jews and Gentiles, each having a different background, education, and status. This indicates that the church is composed of all races and classes of people regardless of their background, and that the spiritual gifts and functions given to the members of the Body of Christ are not based on their natural status.

verse.text: And as they were [note]1[/note]ministering to the Lord and fasting, the [note]2[/note]Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit said, [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Set apart for Me now Barnabas and Saul for the [xref]c[/xref]work to which I have [xref]d[/xref]called them.
verse.note: Not conferring with men and organizing.
As the pneumatic Christ, the Head of the Body.

This was a great step taken by the Lord for the spread of the gospel of His kingdom to the Gentile world. It was begun from Antioch, a Gentile center in Syria, without the organizing of a mission, without the raising of funds, without human ordination, and without any human plan or method. It was initiated by five faithful and seeking members of the Body of Christ, who gave the Head of the Body an opportunity through their ministering and fasting, that He, as the Spirit, might set them apart to carry out His great commission to spread His kingdom for the establishing of His church in the Gentile world through the preaching of His gospel. This major step had nothing to do with the church in Jerusalem organizationally, and it was not under the authority and direction of Peter and the other eleven apostles in Jerusalem. It was begun solely and purely from a Gentile center, far away from the atmosphere and influence of any Judaic background and practice and even from the practice and influence of the church in Jerusalem. It was absolutely a move by the Spirit, in the Spirit, and with the Spirit through the coordination of the faithful and seeking members of the Body of Christ on the earth with the Head in the heavens. Hence, this was not a religious movement with a human schedule. From Antioch the Lord's move on the earth for God's New Testament economy had an entirely new start. Although the flow of the Lord's move began from Jerusalem on the day of Pentecost and later came to Antioch and went on from Antioch to the Gentile world, it had a purified start by the Spirit at its turn in Antioch.

verse.text: Then, when they had [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fasted and prayed and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]laid their hands on [i]them,[/i] they sent them away.
verse.note: Not discussed and decided.

See note [link]14[sup]4[/sup] in 1 Tim. 4[/link]. Here the laying on of hands denotes identification, signifying that they who laid their hands were one with those on whom they laid hands. By this they declared to all that they were one with the sent ones in their going to carry out the Lord's great commission.

verse.text: They then, having been sent out by the Holy [note]1[/note]Spirit,[separator][note]2[/note]went down to Seleucia; and from there they sailed away to [xref]a[/xref]Cyprus.
verse.note: In [link]v. 3[/link] Barnabas and Saul were sent by the other three. But here it says that they were sent out by the Spirit. This proves that the three were one with the Spirit in the Lord's move, and the Spirit honored their sending as His.
This was the start of Paul's first ministry journey, which ended in [link]14:27[/link].

verse.text: And when they were in Salamis, they announced the [xref]a[/xref]word of God [note]1[/note]in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]synagogues of the Jews. And they also had [xref]c[/xref]John as [i]their[/i] [xref]d[/xref]attendant.
verse.note: Barnabas and Saul did not go to attend the Jewish synagogue gathering but to take advantage of that gathering to announce the word of God, just as the Lord did in His ministry on the earth ([link]Matt. 4:23[/link]; [link]Luke 4:16[/link]). See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup][/link].
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link].

verse.text: And when they had passed through the whole island as far as Paphos, they found a certain man, a [xref]a[/xref]magician [i]and[/i] Jewish [xref]b[/xref]false prophet, whose name was Bar-jesus,
Who was with the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]proconsul, Sergius Paulus, an intelligent man; the latter called Barnabas and Saul to [i]him[/i] and sought to hear the word of God.
verse.note: At that time Cyprus was a senatorial province of the Roman Empire, and the head of its local government was the proconsul.

verse.text: But Elymas the [xref]a[/xref]magician (for so his name is translated) [xref]b[/xref]opposed them, seeking to turn the proconsul away from the [note]1[/note]faith.
verse.note: The objective faith, referring to the contents of the gospel, in which the believers in Christ believe (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in 1 Tim. 1[/link]).

verse.text: But Saul, who is also [note]1[/note]Paul, [note]2[/note]filled with the Holy Spirit, looked intently at him
verse.note: The change of name may indicate a change in life. In any case, after Paul was filled with the Holy Spirit here, he took the lead in the apostolic ministry all the way.
The outward filling for power. See note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And said, O [i]you who are[/i] full of all deceit and all unscrupulousness, son of the [xref]a[/xref]devil, enemy of all righteousness, will you not cease perverting the [note]1[/note]straight ways of the Lord?
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Pet. 2[/link].

verse.text: And now, behold, the [xref]a[/xref]hand of the Lord is upon you, and you will be blind, not seeing the sun for a time. And instantly a mist and a darkness fell upon him; and he went about and sought some to lead him by the hand.
Then the proconsul, seeing what had happened, believed, being astonished at the teaching of the Lord.
And putting out to sea from Paphos, Paul and his companions came to [xref]a[/xref]Perga of [xref]b[/xref]Pamphylia; and [xref]c[/xref]John [note]1[/note]departed from them and returned to Jerusalem.
verse.note: Based on [link]15:38[/link], the reason for John's departing must have been negative and hence a discouragement to Paul and his companions. However, he was recovered to Paul in Paul's later ministry ([link]Col. 4:10-11[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:11[/link]).

verse.text: And they passed through from Perga and arrived at Pisidian [xref]a[/xref]Antioch. And they went into the [xref]b[/xref]synagogue [note]1[/note]on the [xref]c[/xref]Sabbath day and sat down.
verse.note: The purpose of the apostles' going to the synagogue on the Sabbath day was not to keep the Sabbath but to grasp the opportunity for preaching the gospel (see note [link]5[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And after the [xref]a[/xref]reading of the [xref]b[/xref]Law and the Prophets, the synagogue [xref]c[/xref]rulers sent [i]word[/i] to them, saying, [note]1[/note]Men, brothers, if you have any word of exhortation for the people, say [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And Paul, rising up and motioning with his hand, said, [note]1[/note]Men of Israel and [note]2[/note]those who [xref]a[/xref]fear God, listen.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].
The Gentiles who were seeking God.

verse.text: The God of this people [xref]a[/xref]Israel [xref]b[/xref]chose our fathers and exalted the people during their sojourn in the land of [xref]c[/xref]Egypt, and with a [note]1[/note]high arm He [xref]d[/xref]led them out of it.
verse.note: I.e., uplifted.

verse.text: And for a time of about [xref]a[/xref]forty years [note]1[/note]He carried them as a [xref]b[/xref]nurse in the wilderness.
verse.note: Other MSS read, He put up with them.

verse.text: And when He had overthrown [xref]a[/xref]seven nations in the land of Canaan, He distributed their land as an [xref]b[/xref]inheritance.
And after these things, for about [note]1[/note]four hundred and fifty years, He gave [i]them[/i] [xref]a[/xref]judges until [xref]b[/xref]Samuel the prophet.
verse.note: The four hundred and fifty years extends from the people's exodus from Egypt ([link]v. 17[/link]) to the time of Samuel the prophet ([link]v. 20[/link]), when David reigned completely, ruling over the whole nation of Israel ([link]2 Sam. 5:3-5[/link]; cf. [link]Judg. 11:26[/link]; [link]1 Kings 6:1[/link]).

verse.text: And afterward they asked for a [xref]a[/xref]king; and God gave them [xref]b[/xref]Saul, the son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.

And when He had [xref]a[/xref]deposed him, He raised up [xref]b[/xref]David for them as king, to whom also He testified and said, I have [xref]c[/xref]found David, the [i]son[/i] of Jesse, a man according to My [note]1[/note]heart, who will do all My [xref]d[/xref]will.
verse.note: David was a man according to God's heart, that is, according to God's heart's desire, not only according to God's words. Such a man will do all God's will.

verse.text: From this man's [xref]a[/xref]seed, God, according to [xref]b[/xref]promise, brought to Israel a [xref]c[/xref]Savior, Jesus,
After [xref]a[/xref]John had proclaimed, [note]1[/note]prior to His public entrance, a [note]2[/note]baptism of [xref]b[/xref]repentance to all the people of Israel.
verse.note: Lit., before the face of His entrance. A Hebraism.
See note [link]4[sup]3[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: Now as John was completing his course, he said, What do you [note]1[/note]suppose that I am? I am [xref]a[/xref]not [i]the Christ.[/i] But behold, One is coming after me, the [xref]b[/xref]sandals of whose feet I am not worthy to untie.
verse.note: To think secretly or conjecture.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Men, brothers, sons of the race of Abraham, and [note]2[/note]those among you who [xref]a[/xref]fear God, to us the [xref]b[/xref]word of this salvation has been sent forth.
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
See note [link]16[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: For those dwelling in Jerusalem and their rulers, being [xref]a[/xref]ignorant of this One and of the [note]1[/note]words of the prophets which are [xref]b[/xref]read every Sabbath, fulfilled [i]them[/i] by [note]2[/note]judging [i]Him.[/i]
verse.note: Lit., voices.
I.e., sentencing Him to death ([link]Luke 24:20[/link]).

verse.text: And though they did [xref]a[/xref]not find one cause of death [i]in Him,[/i] they asked of [xref]b[/xref]Pilate that He be done away with.
And when they had accomplished all that was written concerning Him, they took [i]Him[/i] down from the [xref]a[/xref]tree and laid [i]Him[/i] in a [xref]b[/xref]tomb.
But [note]1[/note]God [xref]a[/xref]raised Him from the dead.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: [i]And[/i] for many days He [xref]a[/xref]appeared to those who had come up with Him from [xref]b[/xref]Galilee to Jerusalem, who are now His [xref]c[/xref]witnesses to the people.
And we [xref]a[/xref]announce to you the gospel of the [xref]b[/xref]promise made to the fathers,

That God has fully fulfilled this [i]promise[/i] to us their children in raising up Jesus, as it is also written in the second Psalm, [xref]a[/xref]"You are My Son; this day have I [note]1[/note]begotten You."
verse.note: Resurrection was a birth to the man Jesus. He was begotten by God in His resurrection to be the firstborn Son of God among many brothers ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]). He was the only begotten Son of God from eternity ([link]John 1:18[/link]; [link]3:16[/link]). After incarnation, through resurrection He was begotten by God in His humanity to be God's firstborn Son.

verse.text: And as to His having [xref]a[/xref]raised Him up from the dead, no longer to return to corruption, He spoke in this way, "I will give you [note]1[/note]the [note]2[/note]holy things of David, the faithful things."
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]the holy things[/i] here is in the plural. The same Greek word is used for [i]Holy One[/i] in the next verse, but in the singular. However, it is not the regular word for [i]holy;[/i] it is a Greek equivalent of the Hebrew word [i]chesed,[/i] which is translated [i]mercies[/i] in [link]Isa. 55:3[/link], and also in [link]2 Chron. 6:42[/link] and [link]Psa. 89:1[/link] in both the Septuagint and the KJV. In [link]Psa. 89[/link], the word [i]mercies[/i] in plural in [link]v. 1[/link] is the same word as for [i]Holy One[/i] in singular in [link]v. 19[/link]. This Holy One is Christ, the Son of David, in whom God's mercies are centered and conveyed. Hence, [i]the holy things of David, the faithful things[/i] refers to the resurrected Christ. This is fully proved by the context, especially by [i]Your Holy One[/i] in the next verse, and by the verse following [link]Isa. 55:3[/link].
See note [link]75[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 1[/link]. So also for [i]Holy[/i] in the next verse.

verse.text: Therefore He also says in another [i]place,[/i] [xref]a[/xref]"You will not [note]1[/note]allow Your Holy One to see corruption."
verse.note: Lit., give.

verse.text: Now David, having [note]1[/note]served his own generation by the [xref]a[/xref]counsel of God, did indeed fall [xref]b[/xref]asleep and was [note]2[/note]buried with his fathers and saw corruption;
verse.note: This indicates that David's reigning as king was a service rendered to his generation by the counsel of God.
Lit., added to.

verse.text: But He whom [note]1[/note]God has [xref]a[/xref]raised did not see corruption.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: Therefore let it be known to you, [note]1[/note]men, brothers, that through this One [xref]a[/xref]forgiveness of sins is announced to you;
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And from all the things from which you were [xref]a[/xref]not able to be justified [note]1[/note]by the law of Moses, in this One everyone who [xref]b[/xref]believes is [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]justified.
verse.note: Lit., in.

To be forgiven of sins is on the negative side ([link]v. 38[/link]) and is for our release from condemnation. To be justified is on the positive side and is for our reconciliation to God and our being accepted by Him.

verse.text: Therefore beware that what is spoken in the prophets does not come upon you:

[xref]a[/xref]"Look, you despisers, and [xref]b[/xref]marvel, and vanish away; for I am doing a work in your days, a work which you will by no means believe, though someone tells [i]it[/i] to you in detail."
And as [i]Paul and Barnabas[/i] were going out, [i]the people[/i] begged that these words would be spoken to them on the next [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath.

And when the synagogue gathering had been dismissed, many of the Jews and the [xref]a[/xref]devout [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]proselytes followed Paul and Barnabas, who spoke to them and urged them to [xref]c[/xref]continue in the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]grace of God.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

verse.text: And on the following Sabbath almost all the city gathered together to hear the word of God.
But when the [xref]a[/xref]Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with [xref]b[/xref]jealousy and contradicted the things being spoken by Paul [i]and[/i] [xref]c[/xref]blasphemed.

And Paul and Barnabas spoke [xref]a[/xref]boldly and said, It was necessary for the [xref]b[/xref]word of God to be spoken to you [xref]c[/xref]first. Since you thrust it away and do [note]1[/note]not judge yourselves [xref]d[/xref]worthy of eternal life, behold, we turn to the [xref]e[/xref]Gentiles.
verse.note: One's thrusting away the word of God is proof that he, by his own judgment, is unworthy of eternal life. See note [link]48[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: For so the Lord has commanded us, "I have set [note]1[/note]you as a [xref]a[/xref]light of the Gentiles, that you would be for salvation unto the [xref]b[/xref]uttermost part of the earth."
verse.note: This word is a quotation from [link]Isa. 49:6[/link], which refers to Christ as God's Servant, whom God made a light to the Gentiles that His salvation might reach to the end of the earth. Because he was one with Christ in carrying out God's salvation in Christ, the apostle Paul applied this prophetic word to himself in his ministry of gospel preaching for the turning of the gospel from the Jews, because of their rejection, to the Gentiles. In His ministry on earth the Lord expressed the same thing to the stubborn Jews in [link]Luke 4:24-27[/link].

verse.text: And the Gentiles, hearing [i]this,[/i] rejoiced and glorified the word of the Lord; and as many as were [note]1[/note]appointed to eternal life [xref]a[/xref]believed.
verse.note: Or, ordained. One's rejecting the gospel is evidence that he is unworthy of eternal life ([link]v. 46[/link]); one's believing it is proof that he was appointed or ordained by God to eternal life. God's ordination, or predestination, for man's salvation is sovereignly of Himself. However, He still leaves man to his own free will. Whether man would believe or reject His salvation is up to man's own decision.

verse.text: And the word of the Lord was carried through the whole region.

But the Jews [xref]a[/xref]incited the [xref]b[/xref]women of high standing who [xref]c[/xref]worshipped God, and the chief men of the city, and [xref]d[/xref]raised up a [xref]e[/xref]persecution against Paul and Barnabas and [xref]f[/xref]cast them out from their borders.
But they [xref]a[/xref]shook off the dust of their feet against them and came to [xref]b[/xref]Iconium.
And the disciples were [note]1[/note]filled with [xref]a[/xref]joy and with the Holy Spirit.
verse.note: Gk. [i]pleroo,[/i] filled inwardly. See note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]. This infilling by the Holy Spirit is essential, being for life, not for power. Joy, being a matter of life, not of power, proves this.

verse.text: And in [xref]a[/xref]Iconium they entered together [note]1[/note]into the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]synagogue of the Jews and spoke in such a way that a great multitude of both Jews and Greeks believed.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link].

verse.text: But the Jews who were [xref]a[/xref]disobedient [xref]b[/xref]stirred up and ill-affected the [note]1[/note]minds of the Gentiles against the [xref]c[/xref]brothers.
verse.note: Lit., souls.

verse.text: Therefore they spent a considerable amount of time speaking with [xref]a[/xref]boldness in the Lord, who [xref]b[/xref]testified to the word of His [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]grace by granting [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]signs and wonders to be done through their hands.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].
See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: But the multitude of the city was [xref]a[/xref]divided, and [xref]b[/xref]some were with the Jews and some with the apostles.
And when a hostile attempt was made by both the Gentiles and Jews with their rulers to treat [i]the apostles[/i] [xref]a[/xref]outrageously and to [xref]b[/xref]stone them,
They became aware of [i]it[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]fled to the cities of Lycaonia, [xref]b[/xref]Lystra and [xref]c[/xref]Derbe, and the surrounding region.
And there they [xref]a[/xref]announced the gospel.
And in Lystra a certain man was sitting, without strength in his feet, [xref]a[/xref]lame from his mother's womb, who had never walked.
This man heard Paul speaking, who, looking intently at him and seeing that he had [xref]a[/xref]faith to be [note]1[/note]healed,
verse.note: Or, saved.

verse.text: Said with a loud voice, Stand upright on your feet. And he [xref]a[/xref]leaped up and began to walk.
And when the crowds saw what Paul had done, they lifted up their voice, saying in Lycaonian, The [xref]a[/xref]gods have become like men and have come down to us.
And they called Barnabas, [note]1[/note]Zeus, and Paul, [note]2[/note]Hermes, since he was the one who took the lead in the discourse.
verse.note: Jupiter in Roman mythology. (See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 28[/link].) So also in [link]19:35[/link].
Mercury in Roman mythology.

verse.text: And the priest of Zeus, whose [i]temple[/i] was before the city, brought bulls and garlands to the gates and wanted to offer a sacrifice with the crowds.
But when the apostles, Barnabas and Paul, heard [i]this,[/i] they [xref]a[/xref]tore their garments and rushed out into the crowd, crying out

And saying, [note]1[/note]Men, why are you doing these things? We also are [xref]a[/xref]men of [xref]b[/xref]like feeling as you, [i]and[/i] [xref]c[/xref]announce the gospel to you that you should turn from these [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]vain things [xref]e[/xref]to the [xref]f[/xref]living God, who [xref]g[/xref]made heaven and earth and the sea and all things in them;
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].
Referring to idols and idolatry.

verse.text: Who in the generations [xref]a[/xref]gone by [xref]b[/xref]allowed all the nations to go their ways.

And yet He did [xref]a[/xref]not leave Himself without witness, in that He did good by giving you [xref]b[/xref]rain from heaven and fruitful seasons, filling your [xref]c[/xref]hearts with [xref]d[/xref]food and gladness.
And saying these things, they restrained the crowds [i]only[/i] with difficulty from offering sacrifices to them.

But [xref]a[/xref]Jews from Antioch and Iconium came there; and having [xref]b[/xref]persuaded the crowds, they [xref]c[/xref]stoned Paul and dragged [i]him[/i] outside the city, supposing that he was dead.
But as the disciples surrounded him, he rose up and entered into the city. And on the next day he went out with Barnabas to [xref]a[/xref]Derbe.

And when they had [xref]a[/xref]announced the gospel to that city and had made a considerable number of [xref]b[/xref]disciples,[separator]they returned to [xref]c[/xref]Lystra and to [xref]d[/xref]Iconium and to [xref]e[/xref]Antioch,

[xref]a[/xref]Establishing the [note]1[/note]souls of the disciples, exhorting [i]them[/i] to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]continue in the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]faith and [i]saying[/i] that through many [xref]d[/xref]tribulations we must enter into the [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: Man's soul is composed of his mind, emotion, and will. To establish the souls of the disciples is to establish them (1) in their mind, that they may know and understand the Lord and the things concerning Him ([link]1 Cor. 2:16[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:10[/link]); (2) in their emotion, that they may love the Lord and have a heart for the Lord's interest ([link]Mark 12:30[/link]; [link]Rom. 16:4[/link]); and (3) in their will, that they may be strong to remain with the Lord and do the things that please the Lord ([link]11:23[/link]; [link]Col. 1:10[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:1[/link]).
Lit., remain, persevere; i.e., stand firm and not depart from the faith, into which they had entered.
See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And when they had appointed [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]elders for them [note]2[/note]in every [xref]b[/xref]church and had prayed with [xref]c[/xref]fastings, they [xref]d[/xref]committed them to the Lord into whom they had believed.
verse.note: All the churches here in which elders were appointed by the apostles had been established within less than one year. Hence, the elders appointed in these churches could not have been fully mature. They must have been considered elders because they were comparatively the most mature among the believers. They were not voted in by their congregations but were appointed by the apostles according to their maturity of life in Christ. They were charged by the apostles to care for the leadership and shepherding in their churches (see notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Tim. 3[/link] and [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Pet. 5[/link]).
[i]In every church[/i] equals [i]in every city[/i] in [link]Titus 1:5[/link] (see note [link book="Titus" chapter="1"]5[sup]1[/sup][/link] there).

verse.text: And they passed through Pisidia and came to [xref]a[/xref]Pamphylia.
And when they had spoken the word[note]1[/note] in Perga,[separator]they came down to Attalia.
verse.note: Some MSS add, of the Lord.

verse.text: And from there they sailed away to [xref]a[/xref]Antioch, where they had been commended to the [note]1[/note]grace of God for the work which they fulfilled.
verse.note: See notes [link book="1 Cor." chapter="15"]10[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link].

verse.text: And when they [note]1[/note]arrived and [note]2[/note]gathered the [xref]a[/xref]church together, they [xref]b[/xref]declared the things that God had done with them and that He had [xref]c[/xref]opened a door of faith to the [xref]d[/xref]Gentiles.
verse.note: This was the end of Paul's first ministry journey, which began in [link]13:4[/link].
For fellowship regarding God's move in the spreading of His gospel, not for a report concerning their mission.

verse.text: And they spent no little time [i]there[/i] with the disciples.

And certain men [note]1[/note]came down from [xref]a[/xref]Judea and began to teach the [xref]b[/xref]brothers, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Unless you are [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]circumcised according to the [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]custom of Moses, you cannot be saved.
verse.note: With a strong purpose to exercise the Judaic influence on the Gentile believers.

This is an annulling of the faith in God's New Testament economy, and it is a real heresy. Hence, the "certain men" who taught the Christian brothers this heresy might have been those whom Paul in [link]Gal. 2:4[/link] considered false brothers.
See notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link] and [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link]. In God's New Testament economy, to be circumcised is to make Christ of no profit to the believers.

To keep the custom of Moses, that is, to practice the outward ordinances of the law, is not only to nullify the grace of God and make Christ's death of no effect ([link]Gal. 2:21[/link]) but also to bring the believers, whom Christ has set free, back to the slavery of law ([link]Gal. 5:1[/link]; [link]2:4[/link]).

verse.text: And when no little [note]1[/note]dissension and discussion with them came about through Paul and Barnabas, [i]the brothers[/i] directed Paul and Barnabas and certain others among them to go up to the apostles and [xref]a[/xref]elders in [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem concerning this question.
verse.note: This was Paul and Barnabas's contending for the faith ([link]Jude 3[/link]) against one of the greatest heresies, that the truth of the gospel might remain with the believers ([link]Gal. 2:5[/link]).

It was not because Jerusalem was the headquarters of God's move, or because the church in Jerusalem was the head church controlling other churches, that Paul, Barnabas, and certain others went to the apostles and elders in Jerusalem. It was because Jerusalem was the source from which the heretical teaching concerning circumcision came. In order to solve the problem and uproot the trouble, they needed to go to the source. Unlike the situation with the Roman Catholic Church, according to God's New Testament economy there is no headquarters for God's move on earth and no head church that controls other churches. The headquarters of God's move in His New Testament economy is in the heavens ([link]Rev. 4:2-3[/link]; [link]5:1[/link]), and the One who rules over all the churches is Christ, the Head of the church ([link]Col. 1:18[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:1[/link]).

verse.text: They therefore, having been [xref]a[/xref]sent forward by the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]church, passed through both Phoenicia and Samaria, telling in detail about the turning of the [xref]c[/xref]Gentiles; and they brought great joy to all the [xref]d[/xref]brothers.
verse.note: The going up to Jerusalem by Paul, Barnabas, and certain others was the move of the church, not the move of themselves as individuals. They did not act individualistically apart from the church, but corporately in and with the church. This was the move of the Body of Christ.

verse.text: And when they arrived in Jerusalem, they were [xref]a[/xref]received by the [xref]b[/xref]church and the apostles and the elders, and they [xref]c[/xref]declared the things that God had done with them.

But certain men from the [xref]a[/xref]sect of the [note]1[/note]Pharisees who had believed rose up from among [i]them,[/i] saying, It is [xref]b[/xref]necessary to [note]2[/note]circumcise them and to charge [i]them[/i] to [note]3[/note]keep the [xref]c[/xref]law of Moses.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].
See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup][/link].
See note [link]1[sup]4[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And the apostles and the elders were [note]1[/note]gathered together to see about this matter.
verse.note: This was a unique conference held by the apostles of the universal church and the elders of the local church in Jerusalem. These two groups were the leading ones in the Lord's New Testament move on earth. The conference had no chairman; the presiding One was the Spirit ([link]v. 28[/link]), the pneumatic Christ, the Head of the church ([link]Col. 1:18[/link]) and the Lord of all ([link]10:36[/link]). [i]Much discussion had taken place[/i] ([link]v. 7[/link]) indicates that everyone in the conference had the freedom to speak. The decision was made based on (1) the testimony shared by Peter ([link]vv. 7-11[/link]), (2) the facts related by Barnabas and Paul ([link]v. 12[/link]), and (3) the concluding word given by James ([link]vv. 13-21[/link]), who was the leading one among the apostles and elders in Jerusalem ([link]12:17[/link]; [link]21:18[/link]; [link]Gal. 1:19[/link]; [link]2:9[/link]) because of the influence he exercised over the believers by his piety (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in James 1[/link]).

verse.text: And when much discussion had taken place, Peter rose up and said to them, [note]1[/note]Men, brothers, you know that from the [note]2[/note]early days God [xref]a[/xref]chose [i]from[/i] among you that through my mouth the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles should hear the word of the [xref]c[/xref]gospel and believe.
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
Lit., ancient, old.

verse.text: And God, the Knower of [xref]a[/xref]hearts, bore witness to them, giving [i]them[/i] the Holy [xref]b[/xref]Spirit even [xref]c[/xref]as also to us;
And He made [xref]a[/xref]no distinction between us and them, [xref]b[/xref]cleansing their [note]1[/note]hearts by faith.
verse.note: Indicating that God does not care for outward legalistic ordinances, which cannot cleanse man's inward being; He cares for the inward cleansing of man's heart. This corresponds with the Lord's emphasis in [link]Mark 7:1-23[/link]. The cleansing of man's heart can be accomplished only by the Holy Spirit with the divine life, not by outward ordinances of dead letters.

verse.text: Therefore why are you now [xref]a[/xref]testing God by placing a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]yoke upon the neck of the disciples which neither our fathers nor we were able to bear?
verse.note: The yoke of the law, which was a bondage under slavery ([link]Gal. 5:1[/link] and note 4). To require people to keep the law of slavery not only enslaves people but also tests God. Even God could not and would not make man keep the law of dead letters.

verse.text: But we believe that through the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of the Lord Jesus we are [xref]b[/xref]saved in the same way also as they are.
verse.note: This grace comprises the Lord's person (see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 2[/link]) and His redemptive work ([link]Rom. 3:24[/link]). Peter and the Jewish believers were saved by this grace, not by keeping the law of Moses. As far as God's salvation is concerned, to keep the law means nothing to either the Jews or the Gentiles.

verse.text: And all the multitude became silent, and they listened to Barnabas and Paul [xref]a[/xref]relating all the [xref]b[/xref]signs and wonders God had done among the [xref]c[/xref]Gentiles through them.
And when they [note]1[/note]finished speaking, [xref]a[/xref]James answered, saying, [note]2[/note]Men, brothers, listen to me.
verse.note: Lit., became silent.
See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Simeon has related how God first visited the Gentiles to take out from [i]them[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]people for His name.
verse.note: I.e., Simon ([link]John 1:40[/link], [link]42[/link]).

verse.text: And with this the words of the prophets agree, even as it is written,
[xref]a[/xref]"After these things I will return, and I will rebuild the [note]1[/note]tabernacle of David which has fallen; and I will rebuild its ruins and erect it again,
verse.note: The kingdom of Israel. To rebuild the tabernacle of David is to restore the kingdom of Israel ([link]1:6[/link]).

verse.text: So that the remainder of men may [xref]a[/xref]seek out the Lord, even all the Gentiles [note]1[/note]upon whom My [xref]b[/xref]name has been called,
verse.note: Or, who have been called by My name.

verse.text: Says the Lord, who is making these things known [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]from of old."
verse.note: Or, from the foundation of the world.

verse.text: Therefore I judge that we do not harass those from the Gentiles who are [xref]a[/xref]turning to God,
But that we write to them to abstain from the [xref]a[/xref]contaminations of [xref]b[/xref]idols and [xref]c[/xref]fornication and what is strangled and [xref]d[/xref]blood.
For [note]1[/note]Moses from ancient generations has in every city those who proclaim him in the [note]2[/note]synagogues, he being [xref]a[/xref]read every Sabbath.
verse.note: This indicates that the concluding word given by James was still under the influence of the Mosaic law because of James's heavy Judaic background (see notes [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in James 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link]). The influence of this background remained, even at the time Paul paid his last visit to Jerusalem ([link]21:20-26[/link]).
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link].

verse.text: It then seemed good to the apostles and the elders with the whole [xref]a[/xref]church to choose men from among them to send to Antioch together with Paul and Barnabas: Judas, who is called [xref]b[/xref]Barsabbas, and [xref]c[/xref]Silas, leading men among the brothers,

Writing [i]to them and sending[/i] by their hand [i]the following:[/i] The apostles and the elder brothers, to the [xref]a[/xref]brothers throughout Antioch and [xref]b[/xref]Syria and Cilicia who are of the Gentiles, rejoice.
Since we have heard that certain ones who went out from among us have [xref]a[/xref]troubled you with [i]their[/i] words, unsettling your souls, to whom we gave no instruction,
It seemed good to us, having become of [xref]a[/xref]one accord, to choose men to send to you together with our [xref]b[/xref]beloved Barnabas and Paul,
Men who have [note]1[/note]risked their [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]lives for the [xref]b[/xref]name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: Lit., given over, given up.
Lit., souls. Referring not only to their lives but also to their very beings, which they had given up for the name of the Lord.

verse.text: Therefore we have sent Judas and [xref]a[/xref]Silas, who themselves will report the same things by word [i]of mouth.[/i]
For it seemed good to the Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit and to us to lay upon you no greater [xref]b[/xref]burden than these necessary things:

To abstain from things that have been sacrificed to [xref]a[/xref]idols and blood and things strangled and fornication, from which if you carefully keep yourselves, you will do well. May you be strong.
So when they had been sent away, they went down to Antioch; and when they had gathered the multitude together, they handed [i]them[/i] the letter.
And when they read [i]it,[/i] they rejoiced at the encouragement.
And Judas and Silas, also being [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prophets themselves, exhorted the brothers through much speaking and [xref]b[/xref]confirmed [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]28[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Cor. 12[/link].

verse.text: And when they had spent some time [i]there,[/i] they were sent away with [xref]a[/xref]peace from the brothers to those who had sent them.
[note]1[/note]But it seemed good to Silas to remain there.
verse.note: Some MSS omit this verse.

verse.text: And Paul and Barnabas stayed in [xref]a[/xref]Antioch, teaching and [xref]b[/xref]announcing the word of the Lord as the gospel with many others also.
Now after some days Paul said to Barnabas, Let us return now and visit the brothers in [xref]a[/xref]every city in which we announced the word of the Lord, [i]and see[/i] how they are doing.
And Barnabas intended to take [xref]a[/xref]John, who is called Mark, along with [i]them[/i] also;
But Paul did not consider it suitable to take with [i]them[/i] this one who [xref]a[/xref]withdrew from them in Pamphylia and did not go with them to the work.
And there was a [note]1[/note]sharp contention, so that they separated from each other; and Barnabas, taking Mark along, sailed away to [xref]a[/xref]Cyprus.
verse.note: Barnabas and Paul were men who had given up their lives for the name of the Lord ([link]v. 26[/link]), yet immediately after their victory in contending for the faith against the heresy concerning circumcision, there arose such a sharp contention between them concerning a relative of one of them that they separated from each other. The responsibility for the problem should rest with Barnabas, because after this incident he no longer appears in the divine record in Acts concerning the Lord's move in God's New Testament economy. The reason for his failure might have been his natural relationship with Mark, his cousin ([link]Col. 4:10[/link]), who left Barnabas and Paul in a negative way in their first ministry journey ([link]13:13[/link] and note 1). Mark was later recovered to Paul's ministry ([link]2 Tim. 4:11[/link]; [link]Philem. 24[/link]), but Barnabas was not. Disputes that arise among the co-workers because of personal relationships are terrible! Remember this well!

verse.text: But Paul chose [xref]a[/xref]Silas and [note]1[/note]went out, having been commended to the [xref]b[/xref]grace of the Lord by the brothers.
verse.note: This was the start of Paul's second ministry journey, which ended in [link]18:22[/link].

verse.text: And he passed through [xref]a[/xref]Syria and Cilicia, [xref]b[/xref]confirming the [xref]c[/xref]churches.

And he came also to [xref]a[/xref]Derbe and to Lystra. And behold, a certain disciple named [xref]b[/xref]Timothy was there, the son of a [xref]c[/xref]Jewish woman [i]who was[/i] a believer, but of a Greek father;
He was well attested to by the [xref]a[/xref]brothers in [xref]b[/xref]Lystra and [xref]c[/xref]Iconium.

Paul wanted this one to go forth with him; and he took [i]him[/i] and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcised him [note]2[/note]because of the [xref]b[/xref]Jews who were in those places, for they all knew that his father was a Greek.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

This indicates that the strong influence of the Judaic background remained among the Jewish believers. It disturbed and frustrated the move of the Lord's gospel (see note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link]).

verse.text: And as they went through the cities, they delivered to them the [xref]a[/xref]decrees to keep which had been decided upon by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem.
And so the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]churches were strengthened in the [xref]b[/xref]faith and [xref]c[/xref]increased in number [xref]d[/xref]daily.
verse.note: See notes [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: And they passed through the region of [xref]a[/xref]Phrygia and Galatia, having been forbidden [note]1[/note]by the Holy [xref]b[/xref]Spirit to speak the word in Asia.
verse.note: As in the evangelistic work of Philip ([link]8:29[/link], [link]39[/link]), the move of the apostle Paul and his co-workers for the spread of the gospel was not according to their decision and preference or according to any schedule made by human council, but by the Holy Spirit according to God's counsel. They intended to speak the word in Asia, but the Holy Spirit forbade them. Forbidding is a part of the Holy Spirit's leading.

verse.text: And when they had come to Mysia, they tried to go into Bithynia, yet the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit of Jesus did [note]2[/note]not allow them.
verse.note: [i]The Spirit of Jesus[/i] and [i]the Holy Spirit[/i] in the preceding verse are used interchangeably, revealing that the Spirit of Jesus is the Holy Spirit. [i]The Holy Spirit[/i] is a general title of the Spirit of God in the New Testament; [i]the Spirit of Jesus[/i] is a particular expression concerning the Spirit of God and refers to the Spirit of the incarnated Savior who, as Jesus in His humanity, passed through human living and death on the cross. This indicates that in the Spirit of Jesus there is not only the divine element of God but also the human element of Jesus and the elements of His human living and His suffering of death as well. Such an all-inclusive Spirit was needed for the apostle's preaching ministry, a ministry of suffering carried out among human beings and for human beings in the human life.

The Holy Spirit's forbidding them to go to the left, to Asia ([link]v. 6[/link]), and the Spirit of Jesus' not allowing them to go to the right, to Bithynia, indicated a straightforward direction for the apostle and his co-workers. Thus, they went in a direct course to Macedonia through Mysia and Troas ([link]v. 8[/link]).

verse.text: And bypassing Mysia, they came down to [xref]a[/xref]Troas.

And a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vision appeared to Paul during the night: A certain man, a Macedonian, was standing and entreating him and saying, Come over into [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Macedonia and help us.
verse.note: Not a dream or a trance. See note [link]10[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].
A province of the Roman Empire in southeastern Europe by the Aegean Sea between Thrace and Achaia.

verse.text: And when he had seen the vision, [note]1[/note]we immediately [note]2[/note]endeavored to go forth into Macedonia, [note]3[/note]concluding that God had called us to announce the gospel to them.
verse.note: [i]We[/i] is used here for the first time to include the writer, Luke. This indicates that from Troas, Luke joined the apostle Paul in his ministry journey.

Lit., sought. This was a major step in the Lord's move for the spreading of His kingdom to another continent, Europe. It explains the intention of the Holy Spirit's forbidding, the Spirit of Jesus' not allowing, and the coming of the vision in the night. To carry out this particular leading in the Lord's strategic move required the endeavoring of the apostle and his co-workers. This they did immediately.

After seeing the vision from God, they needed to conclude, that is, to understand what it meant, by exercising the mind — a mind saturated and directed by the spirit ([link]Eph. 4:23[/link]) — according to the actual situation and environment.

verse.text: And putting out to sea from [note]1[/note]Troas, we ran a straight course to [note]2[/note]Samothrace, and on the following day to [note]3[/note]Neapolis,
verse.note: A seaport on the Aegean Sea at the northwest corner of Asia Minor, opposite Macedonia.
An island in the Aegean Sea between Troas and Philippi.
The seaport of Philippi.

verse.text: And from there to [xref]a[/xref]Philippi, which is the leading city of that part of Macedonia, a [i]Roman[/i] [note]1[/note]colony; and we spent some days in this city.
verse.note: A fortified outpost of the Roman Empire in a foreign country, where the citizens had equal rights with those in the capital, Rome. Hence, Philippi was a strategic point for the spread of the gospel at its beginning in Europe.

verse.text: And on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sabbath day we went outside the gate by the [xref]b[/xref]river, where we supposed there would be a place of [note]2[/note]prayer; and we sat down and spoke to the women who had come together.
verse.note: Indicating how widespread Judaism and its influence were, even in Europe.
Man's prayer to God affords Him an opportunity for His move among men on the earth.

verse.text: And a certain woman named Lydia, a seller of purple-dyed goods from the city of [xref]a[/xref]Thyatira who [xref]b[/xref]worshipped God, was listening, whose heart the [note]1[/note]Lord [xref]c[/xref]opened to give heed to the things being spoken by Paul.
verse.note: The Lord here, who opened the heart of Lydia to give heed to the preaching of the gospel, must be the Spirit, who is the Lord Himself ([link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]).

verse.text: And when she was [note]1[/note]baptized, as well as her [xref]a[/xref]household, she entreated [i]us,[/i] saying, If you have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, [note]2[/note]come into my [note]3[/note]house and abide. And she constrained us.
verse.note: Baptism immediately followed their believing, as the Lord commanded in [link]Mark 16:16[/link].

Lydia, after believing and being baptized, entered into fellowship with the apostle and his co-workers — the fellowship of the Body of Christ — as evidence of her salvation. This is truly an expression of the fact that she had received grace.
The first house that the Lord gained in Europe through His gospel and for His gospel ([link]v. 40[/link]).

verse.text: And as we were going to the place of prayer, a certain slave girl having a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit of [note]2[/note]Python met us, who brought her masters much profit by [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]divining.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].
Used in reference to a prophesying demon, and also in reference to a fortuneteller.
The art or practice that seeks to foresee or foretell future events or discover hidden knowledge by the aid of supernatural powers.

verse.text: This woman followed after Paul and us and [xref]a[/xref]cried out, saying, These men are [xref]b[/xref]slaves of the [xref]c[/xref]Most High God, who announce to you a way of salvation.

And she did this for many days. But Paul was greatly disturbed; and turning, he said to the spirit, I charge you in the [xref]a[/xref]name of Jesus Christ to come out of her. And it [xref]b[/xref]came out that very hour.

But when her masters saw that their hope of [xref]a[/xref]profit had gone out, they laid hold of Paul and [xref]b[/xref]Silas and [xref]c[/xref]dragged [i]them[/i] into the marketplace before the rulers.
And when they had brought them to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]magistrates, they said, These men, being Jews, are [xref]b[/xref]throwing our city into confusion,
verse.note: The Roman praetors.

verse.text: And they are announcing [xref]a[/xref]customs which are not lawful for us, being [xref]b[/xref]Romans, to accept or do.
And the crowd rose up together against them, and the magistrates tore off their garments and ordered [i]some[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]beat [i]them[/i] with rods.
And when they had laid many stripes upon them, they threw [i]them[/i] into [xref]a[/xref]prison, charging the jailer to keep them securely,
Who, having received such a charge, threw them into the inner prison and secured their feet in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]stocks.
verse.note: Lit., timber; an instrument of torture with holes to hold the prisoner's wrists, ankles, and neck. The same word is used in reference to the cross in [link]5:30[/link]; [link]10:39[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:13[/link]; and [link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link].

verse.text: And about [xref]a[/xref]midnight Paul and Silas, while praying, sang hymns of praise to God; and the prisoners were listening to them.

And suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison house were [xref]a[/xref]shaken. And instantly all the doors were [xref]b[/xref]opened and everyone's [xref]c[/xref]bonds were unfastened.
And the jailer, waking up out of his sleep and seeing the doors of the prison opened, drew his sword and was about to [xref]a[/xref]do away with himself, supposing that the prisoners had escaped.
But Paul called out with a loud voice, saying, Do no harm to yourself, for we are all here.
And [i]the jailer[/i] asked for lights and rushed in; and trembling, he [xref]a[/xref]fell down before Paul and Silas.
And leading them outside, he said, Sirs, [xref]a[/xref]what must I do to be saved?
And they said, [xref]a[/xref]Believe on the Lord Jesus, and you shall be [xref]b[/xref]saved, you and your [note]1[/note]household.
verse.note: Indicating that the family of the believer is a complete unit for God's salvation, like the family of Noah ([link]Gen. 7:1[/link]), the families partaking of the passover ([link]Exo. 12:3-4[/link]), the family of the harlot Rahab ([link]Josh. 2:18-19[/link]), the family of Zaccheus ([link]Luke 19:9[/link]), the family of Cornelius ([link]Acts 11:14[/link]), the family of Lydia ([link]v. 15[/link]), the family of the jailer here, and the family of Crispus in [link]18:8[/link].

verse.text: And they spoke the word of God to him together with all those in his house.
And he took them with [i]him[/i] in that [i]very[/i] hour of the night and washed their wounds. And he was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]baptized immediately, he and all his [i]household.[/i]
verse.note: Again baptism was practiced immediately after someone believed. See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup][/link]. This must have been done in the bathing pool at the place where they were, which, according to the word [i]up[/i] in the next verse, must have been downstairs. This shows and testifies to us that the believers in the early days did not have any regulation or ritual; rather, they took appropriate measures in accordance with local conditions.

verse.text: And he brought them [note]1[/note]up [note]2[/note]into his house and [xref]a[/xref]set a table before [i]them;[/i] and he [xref]b[/xref]exulted because he had believed in God with all his household.
verse.note: See note [link]33[sup]1[/sup][/link].

After believing and being baptized, the jailer did not care for the officials who were his superiors or for the criminals. He too came into fellowship with the apostles, the fellowship of the Body of Christ, as a token of his salvation. See note [link]15[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Now when day came, the magistrates sent the [note]1[/note]lictors, saying, Release those men.
verse.note: The Roman lictors, those who held the rod to clear the way for the magistrates and to execute punishment on the criminals.

verse.text: And the jailer reported these words to Paul: The magistrates have sent that you may be released. Now therefore come out and go in peace.

But Paul said to them, They have beaten us publicly, uncondemned, men who are [xref]a[/xref]Romans, and have thrown [i]us[/i] into prison; and now secretly they are thrusting us out? No indeed! But let them come themselves and bring us out.
And the lictors reported these words to the magistrates. And they became [xref]a[/xref]frightened when they heard that they were Romans.
And they came and entreated them. And when they had brought [i]them[/i] out, they asked [i]them[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]depart from the city.
And they went out from the prison and entered the [xref]a[/xref][i]house[/i] of Lydia; and when they saw the [xref]b[/xref]brothers, they exhorted [i]them[/i] and went forth.
And they traveled through Amphipolis and Apollonia and came to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Thessalonica, where there was a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]synagogue of the Jews.
verse.note: Another leading city, situated on a gulf in the province of Macedonia.
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link].

verse.text: And according to his [xref]a[/xref]custom Paul [note]1[/note]went in to them, and on three Sabbaths he reasoned with them from the [xref]b[/xref]Scriptures,
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link] (so also in [link]17:10[/link]).

verse.text: Opening and setting before [i]them[/i] that the Christ had to [xref]a[/xref]suffer and [xref]b[/xref]rise from the dead, and [i]saying,[/i] This is the [xref]c[/xref]Christ, the Jesus whom I announce to you.

And [xref]a[/xref]some of them were persuaded and [note]1[/note]were joined to Paul and [xref]b[/xref]Silas, as well as a great multitude of the [xref]c[/xref]devout [xref]d[/xref]Greeks, and of the chief [xref]e[/xref]women not a few.
verse.note: Lit., were allotted to.

verse.text: But the Jews, becoming [xref]a[/xref]jealous and taking along some evil men from among the loafers in the marketplace, gathered a crowd and [xref]b[/xref]set the city in an uproar; and coming upon the house of [xref]c[/xref]Jason, they sought to bring them to the populace.

But when they did not find them, they [xref]a[/xref]dragged Jason and some brothers before the city officials, shouting, These men who have [xref]b[/xref]upset the [note]1[/note]world have come here also,
verse.note: Lit., the inhabited earth.

verse.text: Whom Jason has welcomed; and these all act contrary to the decrees of [xref]a[/xref]Caesar, saying that there is another [xref]b[/xref]king, Jesus.
And they stirred up the crowd and the city officials, who listened to these things.
And when they had taken bail from Jason and the rest, they released them.
And the [xref]a[/xref]brothers immediately sent Paul and Silas away during the night to Berea, who, when they arrived, went off into the [xref]b[/xref]synagogue of the Jews.

Now these people were more [note]1[/note]noble than those in Thessalonica, for they received the word with all eagerness, [xref]a[/xref]examining the Scriptures daily [i]to see[/i] whether these things were so.
verse.note: I.e., open-minded.

verse.text: Therefore many of them believed, and [i]there were[/i] not a few Greek [xref]a[/xref]women of high standing and men.
But when the Jews from Thessalonica found out that the word of God had been announced by Paul in Berea also, they came there as well, [xref]a[/xref]agitating and stirring up the crowds.
And immediately the [xref]a[/xref]brothers then sent Paul off, to [xref]b[/xref]go as far as the sea; and Silas and [xref]c[/xref]Timothy remained there.

And those who conducted Paul brought [i]him[/i] as far as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Athens; and receiving a command for Silas and [xref]b[/xref]Timothy to come to him as quickly as possible, they went off.
verse.note: The capital of Achaia, a province of the Roman Empire. It was the center of enlightenment in science, literature, and art for the ancient world. Through the apostle Paul's visit to such a center, the gospel of the kingdom of God reached the people of the highest culture.

verse.text: And while Paul was waiting for them in Athens, [xref]a[/xref]his [note]1[/note]spirit was provoked within him as he beheld that the city was [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]full of idols.
verse.note: Paul's human spirit ([link]Zech. 12:1[/link]; [link]Job 32:8[/link]; [link]Prov. 20:27[/link]), regenerated by the Spirit of God ([link]John 3:6[/link]), indwelt by the Lord the Spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:10-11[/link]), and acting with the Spirit ([link]Rom. 8:16[/link]), in which spirit he worshipped and served God ([link]John 4:24[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:9[/link]). Such a spirit was provoked by the many idols in Athens.

Even the highest culture did not prevent these people from worshipping idols. Within them, as within all mankind, was a God-worshipping spirit created by God for man to seek and worship Him (cf. [link]v. 22[/link]). However, because of their blindness and ignorance, they took the wrong objects for their worship ([link]v. 23[/link]). Now the very true God, who created the universe and them, sent His apostle to announce the true object whom they should worship ([link]vv. 23-29[/link]).

verse.text: He reasoned therefore in the [xref]a[/xref]synagogue with the Jews and the [xref]b[/xref]devout, and in the marketplace every day with those who happened to be [i]there.[/i]

And some of the [note]1[/note]Epicurean and [note]2[/note]Stoic philosophers also confronted him. And some said, What would this [note]3[/note]babbler wish to say? And others, He seems to be an announcer of foreign [note]4[/note]deities — because he was [xref]a[/xref]announcing Jesus and the [xref]b[/xref]resurrection as the gospel.
verse.note: The Epicurean philosophers were the followers of the Greek philosopher Epicurus (341-270 B.C.), whose philosophy was materialism. They did not recognize the Creator and His providence over the world but sought sensuous pleasures, especially in eating and drinking. Some of Paul's words to the Philippians ([link]Phil. 3:18[/link] and note 1) and the Corinthians ([link]1 Cor. 15:32[/link] and note 3) referred to the Epicureans.

The Stoic philosophers were members of a school of philosophy founded by Zeno (340-265 B.C.). They were pantheists who believed that everything was governed by fate and that all happenings were the result of the divine will, and therefore that man should calmly accept them, free from all passion, grief, or joy. They emphasized that the highest good is virtue and that virtue is the reward given to the soul. Some of the words in Paul's Epistle to the Philippians referred to the Stoics ([link]Phil. 4:11[/link] and note 1).
The Greek word means [i]"seed-picker:[/i] a bird which picks up seeds in the streets and markets; hence one who picks up and retails scraps of news" (Vincent).
Lit., demons.

verse.text: And they took hold of him and led [i]him[/i] to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Areopagus, saying, May we know what this [xref]b[/xref]new teaching is which is being spoken by you?
verse.note: Mars' Hill (in Athens), the seat of the ancient and venerable Athenian Court, which judged the most solemn problems of religion.

verse.text: For you are bringing [xref]a[/xref]strange things to our ears. We intend to know therefore [note]1[/note]what these things mean.
verse.note: Lit., what these things want to be.

verse.text: (Now all the Athenians and the foreigners sojourning [i]there[/i] spent their time on nothing other than telling or hearing something new.)
And Paul stood in the midst of the Areopagus and said, [note]1[/note]Men of Athens, I observe that in every way you [note]2[/note]very much revere your deities.
verse.note: Lit., Men, Athenians. More dignified and solemn than simply "Athenians."
The Greek word here means fearing a demon, a supernatural spirit; hence, given up to demon worship, very much revering the deities. The same word is used in noun form in [link]25:19[/link].

verse.text: For while I was passing through and carefully observing the objects of your [xref]a[/xref]worship, I even found an altar on which was inscribed, TO AN UNKNOWN GOD. What therefore you worship [xref]b[/xref]without knowing, this I announce to you.
The [note]1[/note]God who [xref]a[/xref]made the world and all things in it, this One, being [xref]b[/xref]Lord of heaven and earth, does [xref]c[/xref]not dwell in temples made with hands;
verse.note: The apostle's word in [link]vv. 24-25[/link] was a very strong inoculation to both the atheistic Epicureans, who did not recognize the Creator and His providence over the world, and the pantheistic Stoics, who submitted themselves to the will of many gods concerning their fate (cf. [link]v. 18[/link]).

verse.text: Neither is He served by human hands as though He needed anything in addition, since He Himself gives to all life and [xref]a[/xref]breath and all things.

And He made from [note]1[/note]one [xref]a[/xref]every nation of men to dwell on all the [xref]b[/xref]face of the earth, determining beforehand [i]their[/i] [note]2[/note]appointed seasons and the [xref]c[/xref]boundaries of their dwelling,
verse.note: Adam. Some ancient MSS read, one blood.
The migrations to America in their times and with their boundaries are strong proof of this word and the first part of the succeeding verse.

verse.text: That they might [xref]a[/xref]seek God, if perhaps they might grope for Him and find [i]Him,[/i] even though He is [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]not far from each one of us;
verse.note: Because God is the omnipresent Spirit.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]in Him we live and move and are, as even some [note]2[/note]poets among you have said, For we are also [note]3[/note]His [note]4[/note]race.
verse.note: Denoting that man's life and existence and even his actions are in God. This does not mean that unbelievers have God's life and live, exist, and act in God like the believers in Christ, who are born of God, possess His divine life and nature, and live, exist, and act in His divine person.
Probably referring to Aratus (about 270 B.C.) and Cleanthes (about 300 B.C.), both of whom uttered these same words in their poems to Zeus (Jupiter), whom they considered the supreme God.
In the writings of the two poets [i]His[/i] refers to Zeus as the supreme God.

Just as Adam was thought to be the son of God ([link]Luke 3:38[/link] and note 2). Since God is the Creator, the source, of all men, He is the Father of them all ([link]Mal. 2:10[/link]) in a natural sense, not in the spiritual sense in which He is the Father of all the believers ([link]Gal. 4:6[/link]), who are regenerated by Him in their spirit ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]; [link]John 3:5-6[/link]).

verse.text: Being then the race of God, we ought not to suppose that [note]1[/note]what is divine is like [xref]a[/xref]gold or silver or stone, [i]like[/i] an engraving of art and [note]2[/note]thought of man.
verse.note: Gk. [i]theion,[/i] meaning [i]that which is divine.[/i] It is not the same as [i]theiotes[/i] in [link]Rom. 1:20[/link], which denotes the characteristics of divinity, nor is it the same as [i]theotes[/i] in [link]Col. 2:9[/link], which denotes the Godhead, God Himself. [i]Theion[/i] is a more vague and abstract word than [i]theiotes[/i] and is not as definite as [i]theotes,[/i] which is definite in denoting the Godhead, God Himself. Cf. note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link].
Or, imagination, device.

verse.text: Therefore, having overlooked the [xref]a[/xref]times of [xref]b[/xref]ignorance, God now [note]1[/note]charges all men everywhere to [xref]c[/xref]repent,
verse.note: Some MSS read, declares to.

verse.text: Because He has set a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]day in which He is to [xref]b[/xref]judge the world in righteousness by the man whom He has designated, having furnished [note]2[/note]proof to all by [xref]c[/xref]raising Him from the dead.
verse.note: The day when Christ will judge living men, i.e., the nations on the earth at His coming back, on the throne of His glory before the millennium ([link]Matt. 25:31-46[/link]). This probably does not include the day when He will judge dead men at the great white throne after the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]), as in [link]10:42[/link] (see note there), [link]2 Tim. 4:1[/link], and [link]1 Pet. 4:5[/link], because on the day mentioned here He will judge the world, which should refer only to living men. This day of Christ's judgment on earth will be brought in by His coming back. He was designated by God to execute this judgment, and God's raising Him from the dead is strong proof of this. In their preaching to the Gentiles, both Peter in [link]10:42[/link] and Paul here and in [link]24:25[/link] stressed the coming judgment of God.

Or, faith, assurance, guarantee. The resurrection of Christ is proof and assurance that He is coming back to judge all the inhabitants of the earth. This is guaranteed that we may have faith in it and that it may lead us to repent ([link]v. 30[/link]).

verse.text: And when they heard of a [xref]a[/xref]resurrection of the dead, some [xref]b[/xref]scoffed; and others said, We will hear you yet [xref]c[/xref]again concerning this.
Thus Paul went out from their midst.
But some men [xref]a[/xref]joined him and believed, among whom also was Dionysius the [xref]b[/xref]Areopagite and a woman named Damaris and others with them.
After these things he departed from [xref]a[/xref]Athens and came to [xref]b[/xref]Corinth.

And having found a certain Jew named [xref]a[/xref]Aquila, a native of [xref]b[/xref]Pontus, recently come from [xref]c[/xref]Italy, and Priscilla his wife (because [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]Claudius had ordered all the Jews to depart from [xref]e[/xref]Rome), he went to them.
verse.note: A Caesar of the Roman Empire. What he did here was used by the Lord for the carrying out of His ministry of the building up of His church, just as what Caesar Augustus did was used by God for the fulfillment of the prophecy concerning the birthplace of Christ ([link]Luke 2:1-7[/link]).

verse.text: And because he was of the same trade, he remained with them and [xref]a[/xref]worked; for they were tentmakers by trade.
And he reasoned [note]1[/note]in the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]synagogue every [note]3[/note]Sabbath, persuading Jews and [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]Greeks.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link] (so also in [link]vv. 19[/link], [link]26[/link]).
See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link].
Indicating that some Greeks were attending the Jewish synagogues ([link]Mark 1:21[/link] and note 1) to listen to the word of God.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]when both Silas and [xref]a[/xref]Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was [note]2[/note]constrained by the word, solemnly [xref]b[/xref]testifying to the Jews that Jesus was the [xref]c[/xref]Christ.
verse.note: It was at this time in Corinth that Paul wrote his first Epistle to the church in Thessalonica ([link]1 Thes. 1:1[/link]), after Silas and Timothy had come from Macedonia with information concerning the church there ([link]1 Thes. 3:6[/link] and note 1).
Or, pressed by.
