verse.text: But when they resisted and [xref]a[/xref]blasphemed, he [xref]b[/xref]shook out his garments and said to them, Your [xref]c[/xref]blood be upon your head; I am clean. From now on I will [note]1[/note]go to the [xref]d[/xref]Gentiles.
verse.note: See note [link]47[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link].

verse.text: And he left there and went into the house of one named Titius Justus, one who [xref]a[/xref]worshipped God, whose house was next to the synagogue.

And [xref]a[/xref]Crispus, the ruler of the synagogue, believed in the Lord with his whole [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]household; and many of the Corinthians, when they heard, believed and were baptized.
verse.note: See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: And the Lord said to Paul in the [xref]a[/xref]night by a [note]1[/note]vision, Do [xref]b[/xref]not be afraid, but speak and do not be silent;
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: Because I Myself am [xref]a[/xref]with you, and no one will assail you to harm you, because I have many [xref]b[/xref]people in this city.
And he [note]1[/note]remained [i]there[/i] a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.
verse.note: Lit., sat.

verse.text: But while Gallio was [xref]a[/xref]proconsul of Achaia, the [xref]b[/xref]Jews rose up against Paul with one accord and [xref]c[/xref]brought him to the judgment seat,
Saying, This man incites men to worship God contrary to the law.
But when Paul was about to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews, If it were a matter of wrongdoing or some wicked crime, O Jews, I would for that reason tolerate you;
But if there are [xref]a[/xref]questions concerning words and names and your own [xref]b[/xref]law, look [i]after it[/i] yourselves. A judge of these things I do not intend to be.
And he drove them away from the judgment seat.
And they all laid hold of [note]1[/note]Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and beat [i]him[/i] in front of the judgment seat. And Gallio was not concerned about any of these things.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Cor. 1[/link].

verse.text: And Paul, having remained [i]there[/i] yet a considerable number of days, took leave of the brothers and sailed away to Syria, and with him Priscilla and [xref]a[/xref]Aquila, having [xref]b[/xref]shorn his head in [xref]c[/xref]Cenchrea, for he had a [note]1[/note]vow.
verse.note: A private vow for thanksgiving performed in any place by the Jews, with the shearing of the hair. It differed from the Nazarite vow, which had to be carried out in Jerusalem with the shaving of the head ([link]21:24[/link] and note 3; [link]Num. 6:1-5[/link], [link]18[/link]; cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:6[/link], where it is shown that there is a difference between shearing and shaving). Paul was a Jew and kept the vow, but he would not and did not impose it on the Gentiles. According to the principle of his teaching concerning God's New Testament economy, Paul should have given up all the Jewish practices, which belonged to the Old Testament dispensation. However, he still had this vow, and it seems that God tolerated it, probably because it was a vow carried out in private outside Jerusalem and would not have had much effect on the believers.

verse.text: And they arrived at [xref]a[/xref]Ephesus, and he left them there; but he [note]1[/note]entered into the [xref]b[/xref]synagogue and reasoned with the Jews.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link].

verse.text: And when they asked [i]him[/i] to remain for a longer time, he did not consent;
But taking leave of [i]them[/i] and saying, I will come back to you again, God [xref]a[/xref]willing,[separator]he put out to sea from Ephesus.
And coming down to Caesarea, he went up [i]to Jerusalem[/i] and greeted the [xref]a[/xref]church and [note]1[/note]went down to [xref]b[/xref]Antioch.
verse.note: This was the end of Paul's second ministry journey, which began in [link]15:40[/link].

verse.text: And when he had spent some time [i]there,[/i] he [note]1[/note]went off, passing through the country of [xref]a[/xref]Galatia and Phrygia in order, [xref]b[/xref]confirming all the disciples.
verse.note: This was the start of Paul's third ministry journey, which ended in [link]21:17[/link].

verse.text: And a certain Jew named [xref]a[/xref]Apollos, a native of Alexandria, an eloquent man, arrived at Ephesus, [i]and[/i] he was powerful in the Scriptures.

This man was instructed in the [note]1[/note]way of the Lord, and being [xref]a[/xref]fervent in spirit, he spoke and taught accurately the things concerning Jesus, though he knew [note]2[/note]only the [xref]b[/xref]baptism of John.
verse.note: Not the doctrine concerning the Lord but the practical way in which the New Testament believers should walk. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

This indicates that Apollos did not have a complete revelation of God's New Testament economy, although he had been instructed in the way of the Lord. Hence, there was a deficiency in the result of his ministry ([link]19:2[/link] and note 2).

verse.text: And this man began to speak boldly in the synagogue. And when Priscilla and [xref]a[/xref]Aquila heard him, they took him to [i]themselves[/i] and expounded the [xref]b[/xref]way of God to him more accurately.

And when he intended to pass through into Achaia, the brothers encouraged [i]him[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]wrote to the disciples to welcome him; and when he arrived [i]there,[/i] he helped much through [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]grace those who had believed;
verse.note: Lit., the grace; indicating the particular grace which Apollos enjoyed in the Lord. This grace is just God Himself in Christ as the portion to the believers in Christ (see notes [link]14[sup]6[/sup] in John 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link]).

verse.text: For he vigorously confuted the Jews publicly, showing by the [xref]a[/xref]Scriptures that Jesus was the [xref]b[/xref]Christ.
Now while [xref]a[/xref]Apollos was in Corinth, Paul, having passed through the upper districts, came down to [xref]b[/xref]Ephesus and found some disciples,

And he said to them, Did you [note]1[/note]receive the Holy Spirit when you believed? And they [i]said[/i] to him, On the contrary, we did [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]not even hear whether there is a Holy Spirit.
verse.note: See note [link]38[sup]7[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 2[/link].
This was the deficiency in the result of Apollos's ministry, a ministry which lacked a complete revelation of God's New Testament economy. See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 18[/link].

verse.text: And he said, Into what then were you baptized? And they said, Into [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]John's baptism.
verse.note: This is the last mention of John the Baptist in the New Testament. "Here at last, he wholly gives place to Christ" (Bengel). There was in John's disciples a thought of rivalry between John and Christ ([link]John 3:26[/link]). John's ministry was to introduce Christ ([link]v. 4[/link]). Once Christ had been introduced, John's ministry should have ceased and been replaced by Christ. John should have decreased, and Christ should have increased ([link]John 3:30[/link]).

verse.text: And Paul said, John baptized with a [xref]a[/xref]baptism of repentance, telling the people that they should believe into the One coming [xref]b[/xref]after him, that is, into Jesus.
And when they heard [i]this,[/i] they were baptized [note]1[/note]into the name of the Lord Jesus.
verse.note: See notes [link]38[sup]3[/sup], point 2, in ch. 2[/link] and [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: And when Paul [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]laid his hands on them, the Holy [xref]b[/xref]Spirit came [note]2[/note]upon them, and they [note]3[/note]spoke in [xref]c[/xref]tongues and [xref]d[/xref]prophesied.
verse.note: See notes [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and [link]47[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].
See note [link]17[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See note [link]46[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: And there were in all about twelve men.

And he [note]1[/note]entered into the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]synagogue and spoke boldly for three months, reasoning and [xref]b[/xref]persuading [i]them[/i] in the things concerning the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link].
See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: But when some were hardened and would not be persuaded, [xref]a[/xref]speaking evil of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Way before the multitude, he withdrew from them and separated the disciples, reasoning daily in the school of [note]2[/note]Tyrannus.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

He might have been a teacher, and Paul might have rented his school and used it as a meeting hall, apart from the opposing Jews' synagogue, to preach and teach the word of the Lord to both Jews and Greeks for two years ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: And this took place for [xref]a[/xref]two years, so that all those dwelling in [xref]b[/xref]Asia heard the word of the Lord, both Jews and [xref]c[/xref]Greeks.
And God did [note]1[/note]works of power of no ordinary kind through the [xref]a[/xref]hands of Paul,
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: So that even handkerchiefs or aprons were carried away from his [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]body to the sick, and their diseases left them, and the evil [note]2[/note]spirits [xref]b[/xref]went out.
verse.note: Referring to the surface, the skin, of the body. A medical term used at that time. Luke, the author, was a medical doctor.
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link].

verse.text: But some of the Jewish [xref]a[/xref]exorcists who also went about took it upon themselves to name over those who had evil spirits the [xref]b[/xref]name of the Lord Jesus, saying, I adjure you by the Jesus whom Paul preaches.
And there were seven sons of a certain Sceva, a Jewish chief priest, doing this.
And the evil spirit answered and said to them, Jesus I know of, and with Paul I am acquainted; but who are you?
And the man in whom the evil spirit was leaped upon them, subdued both [i]of them,[/i] and overpowered them, so that they escaped out of that house naked and wounded.
And this became known to all, both Jews and Greeks, dwelling in Ephesus; and [xref]a[/xref]fear fell upon them all, and the [xref]b[/xref]name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.
And many of those who had believed came, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]confessing and making known their [note]2[/note]practices.
verse.note: [i]Confessing and making known[/i] denotes the most thorough and most open confession.
This word has also the technical meaning of [i]magic spells,[/i] and that may be the meaning here.

verse.text: And a considerable number of those who practiced magic brought their books together and [note]1[/note]burned [i]them[/i] before all; and they counted up the price of them and found [i]it to be[/i] fifty thousand [note]2[/note]pieces of silver.
verse.note: This was to clear up their past life, which was sinful and demonic.
Each piece was approximately a day's wage.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Thus, the word of the Lord [xref]a[/xref]grew mightily and prevailed.
verse.note: Or, Thus, by the might of the Lord the word grew and was strong.

verse.text: And when these things were fulfilled, Paul [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]purposed in his [note]2[/note]spirit to pass through [xref]b[/xref]Macedonia and Achaia and [note]3[/note]go to [xref]c[/xref]Jerusalem, saying, After I have been there, I must also [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]see Rome.
verse.note: The purpose was to carry out Paul's loving concern for the need of the poor saints in Jerusalem. At that time Paul was in Ephesus on his third ministry journey, busy with a heavy burden to carry out his ministry in Asia ([link]1 Cor. 16:8-9[/link]) and in Macedonia and Achaia ([link]1 Cor. 16:5-7[/link]; [link]Acts 20:1-3[/link]). Nonetheless, he still had a burden to spare part of his time for the needy saints in Jerusalem. When he arrived in Corinth, he wrote his Epistle to the saints in Rome, expressing the purpose of his trip and begging them to pray for him concerning this purpose ([link]Rom. 15:25-31[/link]). Although he was an apostle set apart by God for the Gentiles ([link]22:21[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:8[/link]), Paul was still concerned for the Lord's interest among the Jews. His primary concern was for the Body of Christ universally, not merely for his part of the New Testament ministry among the Gentiles.[br][br]Besides this, his purpose in going to Jerusalem at this juncture might also have been to fellowship with James and the other apostles and elders in Jerusalem regarding the Judaic influence on the church there. According to Paul's teachings in the Epistles to the Galatians and the Romans, the decision made by the conference of the apostles and elders in [link]ch. 15[/link] to resolve the problem concerning circumcision must not have been fully satisfactory to him. This undoubtedly troubled him because of his concern for God's New Testament economy, which is to build up the Body of Christ. James's word in [link]21:20-22[/link], after Paul had arrived in Jerusalem ([link]21:17-18[/link]), and his proposal that Paul participate in the four Jewish believers' Nazarite vow ([link]21:23-24[/link]) seem to confirm this view.

Since the Lord the Spirit dwelt in Paul's spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:10-11[/link]), Paul must have purposed according to the leading of the Lord the Spirit. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].
Paul did go to Jerusalem ([link]21:17[/link]), and he did see Rome ([link]28:14[/link], [link]16[/link]).
This desire of Paul's was fulfilled by the Lord when He brought Paul to Rome through his appeal to Caesar ([link]23:11[/link]; note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 25[/link]).

verse.text: And having sent into Macedonia two of those who [xref]a[/xref]served him, [xref]b[/xref]Timothy and [note]1[/note]Erastus, he himself [note]2[/note]stayed in Asia for a time.
verse.note: A city treasurer of Corinth ([link]Rom. 16:23[/link]; cf. [link]2 Tim. 4:20[/link]), of high rank, who probably had been converted by Paul's preaching in Corinth (cf. [link]18:8[/link]) and had become an attendant to Paul.

It was at this time, in Ephesus, that the apostle wrote his first Epistle to the church in Corinth ([link]1 Cor. 16:3-10[/link], [link]19[/link], and note [link]8[sup]1[/sup][/link]; [link]4:17[/link]; cf. [link]Acts 19:20-23[/link], [link]8-10[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]20:1[/link]).

verse.text: And about that time no small [xref]a[/xref]disturbance took place concerning the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Way.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: For a certain man named [note]1[/note]Demetrius, a silversmith who [note]2[/note]made silver shrines of [note]3[/note]Artemis, afforded no little business to the craftsmen.
verse.note: Not the Demetrius in [link]3 John 12[/link].
A dirty and demonic trade. Those who practiced such a trade cooperated with the demons to possess and usurp people for Satan's evil kingdom ([link]Matt. 12:26[/link]).
Artemis was the Ephesian goddess. To the Romans she was the goddess Diana (Latin).

verse.text: These he [note]1[/note]assembled together with the workmen of similar trades as well and said, [note]2[/note]Men, you know that from this business we have [i]our[/i] [xref]a[/xref]prosperity.
verse.note: Behind the idol worship were demons, who instigated the uproar against the apostle to disturb and frustrate the preaching of the gospel. This was Satan's fighting against God's spreading of His kingdom on the earth.
See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: And you observe and hear that not only at Ephesus but in almost all of Asia this Paul has persuaded and perverted a considerable number, saying that the gods being made by [xref]a[/xref]hands are no gods [i]at all.[/i]

And not only is there danger that our trade will come into disrepute, but also that the temple of the [xref]a[/xref]great goddess Artemis will be counted as nothing and that the magnificence of her whom the whole of Asia and the inhabited earth worships will also be overthrown.
And when they heard [i]this,[/i] they became full of rage and began to cry out, saying, Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!

And the city was filled with confusion; and they rushed with one accord into the theater, seizing [note]1[/note]Gaius and [xref]a[/xref]Aristarchus of Macedonia, Paul's traveling [xref]b[/xref]companions.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in 3 John[/link].

verse.text: And when Paul intended to enter into the populace, the disciples would not allow him.
And some of the [note]1[/note]Asiarchs also, who were his friends, sent to him and entreated [i]him[/i] not to venture into the theater himself.
verse.note: Principal persons of the province of Asia.

verse.text: So then some were [xref]a[/xref]crying out one thing, and some another; for the assembly was in confusion, and the majority did not know for what cause they had come together.
And they drew [note]1[/note]Alexander out of the crowd, the Jews having pushed him forward; and Alexander, [xref]a[/xref]motioning with his hand, wanted to make a defense to the populace.
verse.note: Probably not because Alexander was a convert of Paul's preaching. (This Alexander was not the one in [link]1 Tim. 1:20[/link] and [link]2 Tim. 4:14[/link].)

verse.text: But when they realized that he was a Jew, one voice arose from all for about two hours, crying out, [xref]a[/xref]Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!

And the town clerk, having quieted the crowd, said, [note]1[/note]Men of Ephesus, which of [i]you[/i] men is there then who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is the temple keeper of the great Artemis and of the [i]image[/i] [note]2[/note]fallen from [xref]a[/xref]Zeus?
verse.note: Lit., Men, Ephesians. More dignified and solemn than simply "Ephesians."
I.e., fallen from heaven.

verse.text: Since these things therefore cannot be disputed, you ought to be quiet and do nothing rash;
For you have brought forth these men [i]who are[/i] neither temple [xref]a[/xref]robbers nor blasphemers of our goddess.
If then Demetrius and the craftsmen with him have a matter against anyone, courts are being conducted and there are [xref]a[/xref]proconsuls; let them bring charges against one another.
But if you seek after anything further, it shall be settled in the [note]1[/note]legal assembly.
verse.note: Or, regular assembly.

verse.text: For indeed we are in danger of being charged with [xref]a[/xref]insurrection for today's affair, since there is no reason [i]for it; and[/i] with reference to it we will not be able to give an account concerning this disorderly gathering.
And when he had said these things, he [note]1[/note]dismissed the assembly.
verse.note: This was the sovereignty of the Lord; it preserved His apostle from the demonic uproar.

verse.text: And after the uproar had ceased, Paul, having sent for the disciples and having exhorted [i]them,[/i] took leave [i]of them[/i] and went off to go into [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Macedonia.
verse.note: It was there that Paul wrote his second Epistle to the church in Corinth ([link]2 Cor. 2:13[/link] and note 2; [link]7:5-6[/link]; [link]8:1[/link]; [link]9:2[/link], [link]4[/link]).

verse.text: And when he had passed through those parts and had exhorted them with many words, he came into Greece,

And spent [note]1[/note]three months [i]there. And[/i] when a [xref]a[/xref]plot was made against him by the [xref]b[/xref]Jews as he was about to set sail for Syria, he [note]2[/note]resolved to return through Macedonia.
verse.note: During that time, in Corinth, the apostle wrote his Epistle to the saints in Rome ([link]Rom. 15:22-32[/link]; cf. [link]Acts 19:21[/link]; [link]20:1-3[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 16:3-7[/link]).

Paul had originally intended to go to Jerusalem through Syria from Achaia in Greece ([link]19:21[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 16:3-7[/link]). Because of the Jews' plot against him, he changed his route, going northward to Macedonia. From there he returned to Jerusalem. He knew that the Jews were plotting against him and that he would suffer because of this ([link]v. 19[/link]). Therefore, he begged the saints in Rome to pray for him concerning his return to Jerusalem ([link]Rom. 15:25-26[/link], [link]30-31[/link]). This might also have been the reason that he was bound in his spirit to go to Jerusalem ([link]v. 22[/link]). Eventually, after returning to Jerusalem, he was seized by the Jews ([link]21:27-30[/link]), who sought to kill him ([link]21:31[/link]; [link]23:12-15[/link]).

verse.text: And Sopater of Berea, [i]the son[/i] of Pyrrhus, accompanied him, as well as [xref]a[/xref]Aristarchus and Secundus of the Thessalonians and [note]1[/note]Gaius of [xref]b[/xref]Derbe and [xref]c[/xref]Timothy and the Asians, [xref]d[/xref]Tychicus and [xref]e[/xref]Trophimus.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in 3 John[/link].

verse.text: These had gone on ahead and were waiting for us at Troas.
And we sailed away from [xref]a[/xref]Philippi after the days of [xref]b[/xref]Unleavened Bread and in five days came to them in [xref]c[/xref]Troas, where we spent seven days.

And on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]first day of the week, when [note]2[/note]we gathered together to [xref]b[/xref]break bread, Paul conversed with them since he was to go forth on the next day; and he extended his message until midnight.
verse.note: The Lord's Day ([link]Rev. 1:10[/link]). Paul stayed in Troas for seven days ([link]v. 6[/link]), but it was only on the first day of the week that they gathered together to break bread in remembrance of the Lord. This indicates that at that time the apostle and the church considered the first day of the week a day to meet together for the Lord.
Including the writer, Luke.

verse.text: And there were a considerable number of lamps in the [xref]a[/xref]upper room where we were gathered together.

And a certain young man named Eutychus was sitting in the window and began to sink into deep sleep while Paul conversed longer; [i]and[/i] when he had been overcome by sleep, he fell down from the third story and was taken up dead.
But Paul went down and fell [xref]a[/xref]upon him, and embracing [i]him,[/i] he said, Do not make a commotion, for his soul is in him.
And when he had gone up and [xref]a[/xref]broken the bread and [note]1[/note]eaten and had spoken for a considerable time, until daybreak, he therefore went forth.
verse.note: Or, tasted.

verse.text: And they brought the boy alive and were comforted, [i]and that[/i] not moderately.
But we, going ahead onto the ship, set sail for Assos, from there intending to pick up Paul, for so he had arranged [i]it,[/i] himself intending to go by foot.
And when he met us in Assos, we picked him up and came to Mitylene.
And sailing away from there, on the following day we arrived opposite Chios; and on the next day we put in at Samos. And on the day following we came to Miletus,

For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus so that he might not have to spend time in Asia; for he was hurrying [i]so that[/i] if possible he might be in [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem on the [note]1[/note]day of [xref]b[/xref]Pentecost.
verse.note: Probably to meet people from different countries who came to Jerusalem on that day (cf. [link]2:1[/link], [link]5[/link]).

verse.text: And from Miletus he sent [i]word[/i] to Ephesus and called for the [xref]a[/xref]elders of the [xref]b[/xref]church.
And when they came to him, he said to them, You yourselves know, from the first day that I set foot in [xref]a[/xref]Asia, [xref]b[/xref]how I was with you all the time,
[xref]a[/xref]Serving the Lord as a slave with all [xref]b[/xref]humility and [xref]c[/xref]tears and [xref]d[/xref]trials which came upon me by the [xref]e[/xref]plots of the Jews;
How I did not [xref]a[/xref]withhold any of those things that are profitable by not declaring [i]them[/i] to you and by [i]not[/i] teaching you publicly and from [xref]b[/xref]house to house,
Solemnly [xref]a[/xref]testifying both to Jews and to [xref]b[/xref]Greeks [xref]c[/xref]repentance unto God and [xref]d[/xref]faith [note]1[/note]in our Lord Jesus[note]2[/note].
verse.note: Lit., into. The same word for [i]unto[/i] in this verse.
Some MSS add, Christ.

verse.text: And now, behold, I am going [note]1[/note]bound in the [note]2[/note]spirit to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, not knowing what will meet me [note]3[/note]there,
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup][/link].

Paul's regenerated spirit, in which he served God (see note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link]). In his spirit, a spirit joined to the Lord the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]), Paul sensed beforehand that something would happen to him in Jerusalem, and the Holy Spirit testified this to him ([link]v. 23[/link]).
Lit., in it.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Except that the Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit solemnly testifies to me in city after city, saying that [xref]b[/xref]bonds and [xref]c[/xref]afflictions await me.
verse.note: Paul did not know what he would encounter in Jerusalem ([link]v. 22[/link]), but he did know one thing: the Holy Spirit was solemnly testifying to him that bonds and afflictions awaited him. The Holy Spirit's testifying was only a prophecy, a foretelling, not a charge. Hence, he must not have taken it as a command but as a warning. See notes [link chapter="21"]4[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].

verse.text: But I [note]1[/note]consider my [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]life of no account [i]as if[/i] precious to myself, in order that I may finish my [xref]b[/xref]course and the [xref]c[/xref]ministry which I have received from the Lord Jesus to solemnly [xref]d[/xref]testify of the [xref]e[/xref]gospel of the [xref]f[/xref]grace of God.
verse.note: Implying that Paul sensed he was going to be martyred.
Or, soul.

verse.text: And now, behold, I know that you all, among whom I have gone about proclaiming the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom, will see my [xref]b[/xref]face [note]2[/note]no more.
verse.note: The kingdom of God. See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
Indicating that Paul realized beforehand that he would be martyred.

verse.text: Therefore I testify to you [note]1[/note]on [xref]a[/xref]this day that [note]2[/note]I am clean from the [xref]b[/xref]blood of all men,
verse.note: Lit., on today's day. A very forceful expression.
I.e., I am free from blame if any of you should suffer death.

verse.text: For I did not [xref]a[/xref]shrink from declaring to you all the [xref]b[/xref]counsel of God.

[xref]a[/xref]Take heed to yourselves and to all the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]flock, among whom the Holy [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Spirit has [xref]d[/xref]placed you as [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]overseers to [note]4[/note][xref]f[/xref]shepherd the [xref]g[/xref]church of God, which He [xref]h[/xref]obtained through [note]5[/note]His own [xref]i[/xref]blood.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Pet. 5[/link].

The apostles appointed the elders in every church ([link]14:23[/link]). But here Paul, the leading one, who did the appointing, said that the Holy Spirit did it, indicating that the Holy Spirit was one with the apostles in their appointing of the elders, and that the apostles did it according to the leading of the Holy Spirit.

I.e., the elders of the church ([link]v. 17[/link]), proving that [i]overseer[/i] and [i]elder[/i] are synonymous terms denoting the same person. To make an overseer a bishop of a district to rule over the elders of various localities in that district is grossly erroneous. That is what Ignatius did. His erroneous teaching became the basis for the establishing of rank and brought in the hierarchy (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Tim. 3[/link]).

The main responsibility of the elders as overseers is not to rule over but to shepherd, to take all-inclusive tender care of the flock, the church of God (see notes [link book="1 Pet." chapter="5"]2[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Pet. 5[/link]).

Indicating the precious love of God for the church and the preciousness, the exceeding worth, of the church in the eyes of God. Here the apostle did not touch the divine life and nature of the church as in [link]Eph. 5:23-32[/link], but the value of the church as a treasure to God, a treasure which He acquired with His own precious blood. Paul expected that the elders as overseers would treasure the church as God did.[br][br]Both the Holy Spirit and God's own blood are divine provisions for the church that He treasures. The Holy Spirit is God Himself, and God's own blood denotes God's work. God's redemptive work acquired the church; now God Himself, the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), cares for the church through the overseers.[br][br]God's own blood is the blood of Jesus Christ. This implies that the Lord Jesus is God.

verse.text: I know that after my departure fierce [xref]a[/xref]wolves will come in among you, not [note]1[/note]sparing the flock.
verse.note: The apostle did not care for his own life, but he was very concerned for the future of the church, which was a treasure to him as well as to God.

verse.text: And from among you yourselves men will rise up, speaking perverted things to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]draw away the disciples after them.
verse.note: The perverted ones among the believers in the church are always used by the devil, who hates the church, to draw the sheep away to form another flock.

verse.text: Therefore [xref]a[/xref]watch, remembering that for [xref]b[/xref]three years, night and day, I did not cease admonishing each one with [xref]c[/xref]tears.

And now I [xref]a[/xref]commit you to [note]1[/note]God and to the word of His [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]grace, which is able to [xref]c[/xref]build [i]you[/i] up and to give [i]you[/i] the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]inheritance among all those who have been [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]sanctified.
verse.note: Some MSS read, the Lord.
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].
The Greek word here refers to the legal inheritance of a share of an estate. Cf. note [link]18[sup]6[/sup] in ch. 26[/link].
To participate in God's inheritance requires us to be sanctified, and to be sanctified requires the word of God's grace ([link]John 17:17[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: I have [xref]a[/xref]coveted no one's silver or gold or clothing.
You yourselves know that these [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]hands have ministered to my needs and to those who are with me.
verse.note: Making tents ([link]18:3[/link]).

verse.text: In all things I have shown you by example that [xref]a[/xref]toiling in this way we ought to support [note]1[/note]the [xref]b[/xref]weak and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, that He Himself said, [note]2[/note]It is more blessed to [xref]c[/xref]give than to receive.
verse.note: Or, the infirm. Referring to those who were weak physically ([link]1 Cor. 11:30[/link]); hence, the poor ones.
This word is not recorded in the Gospels; it must have been received by oral communication.

verse.text: And when he had said these things, he [xref]a[/xref]knelt down with them all and prayed.
And there was considerable weeping by all; and [xref]a[/xref]falling on Paul's neck, they kissed him affectionately,
Especially pained over the word which he had spoken, that they would no longer behold his [xref]a[/xref]face. And they [xref]b[/xref]escorted him to the ship.
And when we parted from them and set sail, we took a straight course and came to Cos, and on the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
And having found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, we went on board and set sail.
And when we sighted [xref]a[/xref]Cyprus and left it on the left, we sailed to [xref]b[/xref]Syria and came down to Tyre; for there the ship was to unload its cargo.
And when we had sought out the disciples, we remained there seven days. These [note]1[/note]told Paul through the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit [xref]b[/xref]not to set foot in [xref]c[/xref]Jerusalem.
verse.note: In [link]20:23[/link] the Holy Spirit made known to Paul that bonds and afflictions awaited him in Jerusalem (see note 1 there). Now the Spirit took a further step to tell him, through some members of the Body of Christ, not to go to Jerusalem. Since Paul practiced the Body life, he should have taken this word and obeyed it as a word from the Head.

verse.text: And when we completed the days, we went forth and went on our way, with all [i]of them,[/i] including the women and children, [xref]a[/xref]escorting us until [i]we were[/i] outside the city. And when we had [xref]b[/xref]knelt down on the beach and prayed,
We took leave of one another and went on board the ship; and they returned home.
And when we finished the voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais; and we greeted the [xref]a[/xref]brothers and remained with them one day.

And on the next day we went forth and came to [xref]a[/xref]Caesarea; and entering into the [note]1[/note]house of [xref]b[/xref]Philip the [xref]c[/xref]evangelist, who was [i]one[/i] of the [xref]d[/xref]seven, we remained with him.
verse.note: Wherever Paul went, he visited the brothers and stayed with them ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]7[/link]). He was actually practicing the Body life of the church, living according to what he taught concerning the Body of Christ.

verse.text: Now this man had four virgin daughters who [xref]a[/xref]prophesied.
And while we remained [i]there[/i] many days, a certain prophet named [xref]a[/xref]Agabus came down from Judea.

And he came to us and took Paul's [xref]a[/xref]belt; and having bound his own feet and hands, he said, Thus [note]1[/note]says the Holy Spirit, In this way will the Jews in Jerusalem [xref]b[/xref]bind the man whose belt this is and [xref]c[/xref]deliver [i]him[/i] into the hands of the Gentiles.
verse.note: Again, the Holy Spirit told Paul beforehand, indirectly through a member of the Body of Christ, what would befall Paul in Jerusalem (see note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 20[/link]). This was again a warning in the nature of a prophecy, not a charge. It was again the Head speaking through His Body (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Since Paul practiced the Body life, he should have listened to this speaking.

verse.text: And when we heard these things, both [note]1[/note]we and those in that place entreated him [xref]a[/xref]not to [xref]b[/xref]go up to Jerusalem.
verse.note: Including Luke, the writer. Here the Body of Christ, through many members, expressed its feeling, entreating Paul not to go to Jerusalem. But because of his strong will, manifested in his readiness even to sacrifice his life for the Lord ([link]v. 13[/link]), he would not be persuaded, forcing the members of the Body of Christ to leave this matter to the will of the Lord ([link]v. 14[/link]).

verse.text: Then Paul answered, What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound, but also to [xref]a[/xref]die in Jerusalem for the [xref]b[/xref]name of the Lord Jesus.
And since he would not be persuaded, we became silent, saying, The [xref]a[/xref]will of the Lord be done.
And after these days we gathered our baggage and went up to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem.

And [i]some[/i] of the disciples from [xref]a[/xref]Caesarea also went with us, bringing [i]us[/i] to a certain Mnason of [xref]b[/xref]Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we were to [note]1[/note]lodge.
verse.note: In Jerusalem.

verse.text: And when we had [note]1[/note]come to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem, the [xref]b[/xref]brothers [xref]c[/xref]welcomed us gladly.
verse.note: This was the end of Paul's third ministry journey, which began in [link]18:23[/link].

verse.text: And on the following day Paul went in with us to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]James, and all the [xref]b[/xref]elders were present.
verse.note: See notes [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link] and [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 1[/link].

verse.text: And having greeted them, he [xref]a[/xref]related one by one the things which God did among the Gentiles through his [xref]b[/xref]ministry.

And when they heard [i]it,[/i] they [xref]a[/xref]glorified God and said to him, You observe, brother, how many [note]1[/note]thousands there are among the Jews who have believed; and all are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]zealous for the [xref]c[/xref]law.
verse.note: Or, myriads, ten thousands.

Indicating that the Jewish believers in Jerusalem still kept the law of Moses, remained in the Old Testament dispensation, and were strongly under the Judaic influence, mixing God's New Testament economy with the outdated Old Testament economy (see notes [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in James 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in James 2[/link]).

verse.text: And they have been informed concerning you that you are [xref]a[/xref]teaching all the Jews throughout the nations [note]1[/note]apostasy from Moses, telling them [xref]b[/xref]not to circumcise their children, nor to walk according to the [xref]c[/xref]customs.
verse.note: To forsake the law of Moses, not to circumcise, and not to walk according to the customs of dead letters are actually according to God's New Testament economy. But these were considered by the unbelieving Jews, and even by the Jewish believers in Christ, to be apostasy from God's Old Testament dispensation.

verse.text: What then is [i]to be done?[/i] [note]1[/note]They will certainly hear that you have come.
verse.note: Some MSS read, A multitude must certainly gather, for they will hear that you have come.

verse.text: Therefore do this that we tell you: We have four men who have a [note]1[/note]vow on themselves;
verse.note: Referring to the Nazarite vow ([link]Num. 6:2-5[/link]).

verse.text: Take these and be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]purified with them, and pay their [note]2[/note]expenses that they may [note]3[/note]shave their heads. And all will know that there is nothing to the things that they have been informed of concerning you, but that you yourself also walk orderly, keeping the [xref]b[/xref]law.
verse.note: To be purified with the Nazarites was to become a Nazarite with them, joining them in the fulfilling of their vow. The same word is used in the Septuagint in [link]Num. 6:3[/link] in describing the Nazarite's duties. To take the Nazarite vow was a purification before God.

The cost of the offerings, which a Nazarite had to pay for the completion of his purification ([link]Num. 6:13-17[/link]). This was very expensive for the poor Nazarites. It was a custom among the Jews, and was considered proof of great piety, that a rich person would pay for the poor the expenses of the offerings.
To be done at the completion of the Nazarite vow ([link]Num. 6:18[/link]). This shaving differed from the shearing in [link]18:18[/link] (see note 1 there), which was for a private vow.

verse.text: But concerning the Gentiles who have believed, we have [i]already[/i] written, having decided that they should keep themselves from [xref]a[/xref]idol sacrifices and blood and anything strangled and fornication.

Then Paul took the men [i]and[/i] on the following day, [note]1[/note]being purified with them, entered into the temple, giving notice of the [note]2[/note]completion of the days of the purification, until the [xref]a[/xref]offering was offered for each one of them.
verse.note: I.e., participating in their Nazarite vow (see note [link]24[sup]1[/sup][/link]). To do this Paul had to enter into the temple and remain there with the Nazarites until the completion of the seven days of the vow; then the priest would offer the offerings for each one of them, including him. Surely he was clear that such a practice was of the outdated dispensation, which, according to the principle of his teaching in the New Testament ministry, should be repudiated in God's New Testament economy. Yet he went through with it, probably because of his Jewish background, which had also been manifested earlier in his private vow in [link]18:18[/link], and probably because he was practicing his word in [link]1 Cor. 9:20[/link]. However, his toleration jeopardized God's New Testament economy; this God would not tolerate. At this point he must have felt that he was in a predicament, and he must have been deeply troubled, longing to be delivered from it. Just at the time when their vow was to be concluded, God allowed an uproar to rise up against him, and what they intended to accomplish was blown away ([link]v. 27[/link]). Moreover, by God's sovereignty Paul was rescued out of his predicament.[br][br]The mixing of Judaic practices with God's New Testament economy was not only erroneous in relation to God's dispensation but also abominable in the eyes of God. This gross mixture was terminated by Him a mere ten years or so later with the destruction of Jerusalem and the temple, the center of Judaism, through Titus and his Roman army. This rescued and absolutely separated the church from the devastation of Judaism.[br][br]God might have tolerated Paul's carrying out of a private vow in [link]18:18[/link], but He would not allow Paul, a vessel chosen by Him not only for the completing of His New Testament revelation ([link]Col. 1:25[/link]) but also for the carrying out of His New Testament economy ([link]Eph. 3:2[/link], [link]7-8[/link]), to participate in the Nazarite vow, a strict Judaic practice. In going to Jerusalem, Paul's intention might have been to clear up the Judaic influence on the church there (see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 19[/link]), but God knew that the church there was incurable. Hence, in His sovereignty God allowed Paul to be arrested by the Jews and imprisoned by the Romans that he might write his last eight Epistles (see note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 25[/link]), which completed the divine revelation ([link]Col. 1:25[/link]) and gave the church a clearer and deeper view concerning God's New Testament economy ([link]Eph. 3:3-4[/link]). Thus, God left the Judaism-influenced church in Jerusalem to remain as it was until the devastating mixture was terminated with the destruction of Jerusalem. For Paul to write his last eight Epistles to complete God's New Testament revelation was far more important and necessary than for him to accomplish some outward works for the church.
I.e., the completion of the Nazarite vow ([link]Num. 6:13[/link]).

verse.text: And when the seven days were about to be concluded, the [xref]a[/xref]Jews from [xref]b[/xref]Asia saw him in the temple and [xref]c[/xref]threw all the crowd into confusion; and they [xref]d[/xref]laid their hands on him,

Crying out, [note]1[/note]Men of Israel, help! This is the man who [xref]a[/xref]teaches all men everywhere [xref]b[/xref]against the [note]2[/note]people and the law and [note]3[/note]this place; and further, he has even brought Greeks into the temple and has [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]profaned this [note]5[/note]holy place.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

God's New Testament teaching according to His New Testament economy was indeed against the Jews, who opposed God's New Testament economy ([link]Matt. 21:41[/link], [link]43-45[/link]; [link]22:7[/link]; [link]23:32-36[/link]; [link]Acts 7:51[/link]; [link]13:40-41[/link]), against the law of dead letters ([link]Rom. 3:20[/link], [link]28[/link]; [link]6:14[/link]; [link]7:4[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:19[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]5:4[/link]), and against the holy place, the temple ([link]Matt. 23:38[/link] and note 1; [link]24:2[/link]; [link]Acts 7:48[/link]). Since Paul's ministry was to carry out God's New Testament economy, it could not please the Jews, who were possessed and usurped by Satan, the enemy of God, and were instigated by him to oppose and ravage God's New Testament move. Hence, it offended the Jews and was opposed to the law and the temple, for which they were zealous, and it stirred up their jealousy and hatred to the uttermost, so that they made a plot ([link]20:3[/link]) to do away with Paul ([link]vv. 31[/link], [link]36[/link]).
The holy place, the temple.
Lit., made common.
The temple. See note [link]15[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link].

verse.text: For they had previously seen [xref]a[/xref]Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him, whom they supposed Paul had brought into the temple.

And the whole city was stirred, and the people ran together; and they [xref]a[/xref]laid hold of Paul and [xref]b[/xref]dragged him [xref]c[/xref]outside the temple; and immediately the doors were shut.
And as they were seeking to [xref]a[/xref]kill him, a report came up to the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]commander of the [note]2[/note]cohort that all Jerusalem was in confusion.
verse.note: A chiliarch, in command of one thousand troops or a cohort.
See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: And he at once took soldiers and centurions and ran down to them. And when they saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
Then the commander drew near and laid hold of him and ordered [i]him[/i] to be [xref]a[/xref]bound with two [xref]b[/xref]chains. And he inquired who he might be and what he had done.

And some among the crowd were [xref]a[/xref]shouting one thing, and some another. And since he could not find out the facts because of the uproar, he ordered him to be brought into the [xref]b[/xref]barracks.
And when Paul came to the stairs, it so happened that he was being carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the crowd;
For the multitude of the people were following and crying out, [xref]a[/xref]Away with him!
And when he was about to be brought into the barracks, Paul said to the commander, Am I allowed to say anything to you? And he said, You know Greek?
You are not then the Egyptian who some days ago revolted and led out the four thousand men of the Assassins into the wilderness?
But Paul said, I am a [xref]a[/xref]Jewish man of [xref]b[/xref]Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no insignificant city, and I beg you, permit me to speak to the people.

And when he had given him permission, Paul stood on the stairs and [xref]a[/xref]motioned with his hand to the people. And when there was a great silence, he addressed [i]them[/i] in the [xref]b[/xref]Hebrew [note]1[/note]dialect, saying,
verse.note: I.e., Aramaic, the language then used in Palestine.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Men, [xref]a[/xref]brothers and fathers, hear my [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]defense [i]which[/i] I now [i]make[/i] to you.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

Paul faced his opponents in a way different from Christ's way. For the accomplishing of His redemption, Christ was like a lamb brought to the slaughter; and like a sheep dumb before its shearer, He did not open His mouth when judged by men ([link]Isa. 53:7[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:62-63[/link]; [link]27:12[/link], [link]14[/link]). But as a faithful and bold apostle sent by the Lord, Paul needed to make a defense and exercise his wisdom to save his life from his persecutors that he might fulfill the course of his ministry. Although he was willing and ready to sacrifice his life for the Lord ([link]20:24[/link]; note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link]; [link]21:13[/link]), he still endeavored to live longer that he might carry out the Lord's ministry as much as possible. See notes [link chapter="22"]25[sup]2[/sup][/link] in this chapter and [link chapter="23"]3[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]6[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 23[/link].

verse.text: And when they heard that he addressed them in the Hebrew [note]1[/note]dialect, they became more quiet. And he said,
verse.note: See note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].

verse.text: I am [note]1[/note]a [xref]a[/xref]Jew, born in Tarsus of Cilicia but brought up in this city and trained at the feet of [xref]b[/xref]Gamaliel, according to the [xref]c[/xref]strictness of the law of our fathers, being [xref]d[/xref]zealous [xref]e[/xref]for God, even as you all are today.
verse.note: Lit., a man, a Jew.

verse.text: And I [xref]a[/xref]persecuted this [note]1[/note]Way unto death, binding and delivering to [xref]b[/xref]prisons both men and women,
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: As also the [xref]a[/xref]high priest and all the [note]1[/note]assembly of the elders testify for me; from whom I also received [xref]b[/xref]letters to the brothers and went to [xref]c[/xref]Damascus to bring those also who were there bound to Jerusalem that they might be punished.
verse.note: Referring to the presbytery, the eldership (of the Sanhedrin). Hence, the Sanhedrin. See note [link]22[sup]6[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: And as I journeyed and [xref]a[/xref]drew near to Damascus about midday, suddenly a great light flashed out of heaven around me;
And I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting [note]1[/note]Me?
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: And I answered, Who are You, [note]1[/note]Lord? And He said to me, I am Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene, whom you persecute.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: And those who were with me beheld the light, but did not [note]1[/note]hear the voice of the One who was speaking to me.
verse.note: I.e., understand, as in [link]Mark 4:33[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 14:2[/link]. They heard the voice but did not understand it, just as they beheld the light but saw no one ([link]9:7[/link]).

verse.text: And I said, [xref]a[/xref]What shall I do, Lord? And the Lord said to me, Rise up and go into Damascus, and there it [note]1[/note]will be told to you concerning all the things which have been appointed to you to do.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: And as I could [note]1[/note]not see because of the glory of that light, I was led by the hand by those who were with me and came into Damascus.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: And a certain [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Ananias, a devout man according to the law, [xref]b[/xref]well attested to by all the Jews dwelling [i]there,[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: Came to me, and standing by, said to me, Saul, brother, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]receive your sight! And in that very hour I looked up at him.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: And he said, The [xref]a[/xref]God of our fathers has previously [xref]b[/xref]appointed you to know His [xref]c[/xref]will and to see the [xref]d[/xref]righteous One and to hear the voice from His mouth;
For you will be a [xref]a[/xref]witness to Him unto all men of the things which you have [xref]b[/xref]seen and heard.
And now, why do you delay? Rise up and [note]1[/note]be [xref]a[/xref]baptized and wash away your sins, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]calling on [note]3[/note]His [xref]c[/xref]name.
verse.note: See notes [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 16[/link].

See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]. Calling on the Lord's name here was a means for Paul to wash away his sins committed in arresting so many of the believers who called on the Lord's name. All the believers knew that he had considered calling on the Lord's name a sign of those whom he should arrest ([link]9:14[/link], [link]21[/link]). Now he had turned to the Lord. In order for Paul to wash away, before God and before all the believers, the sins that he had committed in persecuting and arresting the Lord's callers, he was charged by Ananias to call on the name that he had formerly abhorred. He had to do this — an act contrary to his former practice — at his baptism, in which he made a public confession of the Lord whom he had persecuted.
[i]His[/i] is significant here, pointing particularly to the name of the One whom Paul had hated and persecuted ([link]v. 8[/link]).

verse.text: And when I returned to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem and was praying in the [xref]b[/xref]temple, I went into a [note]1[/note]trance;
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: And I saw Him saying to me, Hurry, and go quickly out of Jerusalem, because they will not accept your [xref]a[/xref]testimony concerning Me.
And I said, Lord, they know that I was [xref]a[/xref]imprisoning and beating from [xref]b[/xref]synagogue to synagogue those who believe on You;

And when the [xref]a[/xref]blood of Your [xref]b[/xref]witness Stephen was being [xref]c[/xref]shed, I myself also was standing by and [xref]d[/xref]approving and keeping the garments of those who did away with him.
And He said to me, Go, for I will send you forth [xref]a[/xref]far away to the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles.
And they listened to him up to this word, and [i]then[/i] they lifted up their voice, saying, [xref]a[/xref]Away from the earth with such a man, for it is [xref]b[/xref]not fitting for him to live!
And as they were crying out and casting off their garments and throwing dust in the air,

The [note]1[/note]commander ordered him to be brought into the [xref]a[/xref]barracks, saying that he should be [xref]b[/xref]examined by scourging in order that he might [xref]c[/xref]ascertain for what cause they were shouting against him so.
verse.note: See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].

verse.text: But as they stretched him out [note]1[/note]with the thongs, Paul [note]2[/note]said to the centurion standing by, Is it lawful for you to scourge a man [i]who is[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]Roman and uncondemned?
verse.note: Or, for the lashes.
This was Paul's wisdom, to utilize his Roman citizenship to save himself from suffering persecution. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And when the centurion heard [i]this,[/i] he went to the commander and reported, saying, What are you about to do? For this man is a Roman.
And the commander came and said to him, Tell me, are you a Roman? And he said, Yes.
And the commander answered, With a large sum of money I acquired this citizenship. And Paul said, But I was even born [i]a Roman.[/i]

Immediately therefore those who were about to [xref]a[/xref]examine him withdrew from him; and the [xref]b[/xref]commander also was [xref]c[/xref]afraid, realizing that he was a [xref]d[/xref]Roman and that he had [xref]e[/xref]bound him.

And on the next day he, intending to find out for certain why he was accused by the Jews, released him and ordered the chief priests and all the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin to come together; and having brought Paul down, he had [i]him[/i] stand before them.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And Paul, looking intently at the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin, said, [note]2[/note]Men, brothers, I have conducted myself in all good [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]conscience before God until this day.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].
See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

After man's fall and his being sent out of the garden of Eden ([link]Gen. 3:23[/link]), God in His dispensation wanted man to be responsible to his own conscience. But man failed to live and walk according to his conscience and fell further into wickedness ([link]Gen. 6:5[/link]). After the judgment of the flood, God ordained that man should be under human government ([link]Gen. 9:6[/link]). Man failed in this also. Then, before fulfilling His promise to Abraham concerning the blessing of the nations in his seed, Christ ([link]Gen. 12:3[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:8[/link]), God put man under the test of the law ([link]Rom. 3:20[/link]; [link]5:20[/link]). Man failed this test utterly. All these failures indicate that man has fallen from God to his conscience, from his conscience to human government, and from human government to lawlessness; that is, man has fallen to the uttermost. Hence, to conduct oneself in all good conscience before God, as Paul did, was a great return to God from man's fall. Paul spoke this word to vindicate himself before those who accused him of being a lawless and even reckless person. In his defense he referred again to his conscience in [link]24:16[/link]. This showed his high standard of morality, in contrast to the hypocrisy of the Jewish religionists and the crookedness of the Roman (Gentile) politicians. See notes [link chapter="23"]12[sup]1[/sup][/link] in this chapter, [link chapter="24"]2[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link chapter="24"]24[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link chapter="24"]26[sup]1[/sup][/link], and [link]27[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 24[/link], and [link chapter="25"]9[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 25[/link].

verse.text: And the high priest [xref]a[/xref]Ananias commanded those who stood by him to [xref]b[/xref]strike him on the mouth.

Then Paul [note]1[/note]said to him, God is going to strike you, you [xref]a[/xref]whitewashed [xref]b[/xref]wall. And do you sit to [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]judge me according to the law, and contrary to the law you order me to be struck?
verse.note: This was Paul's straightforwardness and boldness in dealing with his persecutors. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].
Or, condemn.

verse.text: And those standing by said, Do you revile the [xref]a[/xref]high priest of God?
And Paul said, I did not know, brothers, that he is the high priest; for it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"You shall not [xref]b[/xref]speak evilly of the ruler of your people."

And Paul, knowing that one part was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sadducees and the other [note]2[/note]Pharisees, [note]3[/note]cried out in the [xref]b[/xref]Sanhedrin, [note]4[/note]Men, brothers, I am a [xref]c[/xref]Pharisee, a son of Pharisees; concerning the [xref]d[/xref]hope and [xref]e[/xref]resurrection of the dead I am being [note]5[/note]judged!
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].
See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].
Here again Paul exercised his wisdom to avoid suffering persecution. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].
See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
Or, condemned.

verse.text: And when he spoke this, a dissension took place between the Pharisees and Sadducees; and the multitude was divided.
For the Sadducees say that there is [xref]a[/xref]no resurrection, neither angel nor spirit; but the Pharisees confess both.

And there was a great outcry; and some of the [xref]a[/xref]scribes of the Pharisees' party rose up and contended, saying, We find [xref]b[/xref]nothing evil in this man. And what if a spirit has spoken to him, or an [xref]c[/xref]angel?

And when much [xref]a[/xref]dissension had taken place, the [note]1[/note]commander, fearing that Paul might be torn to pieces by them, [note]2[/note]ordered the detachment of soldiers to go down and seize him from their midst and bring [i]him[/i] into the [xref]b[/xref]barracks.
verse.note: See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].

This was the Lord's sovereignty exercised to rescue Paul from the hand of the Jews. Through the riot of the Jews in Jerusalem, God delivered Paul out of the predicament into which he fell when he took James's compromising proposal and participated in the Nazarite vow. Now, through the commander of the Roman cohort, God in His sovereignty again rescued Paul, this time from the hand of the rioting Jews, who had attempted to kill him, that He might separate him from all the dangerous situations and entrapments and send him to a quiet prison. This was to afford him a quiet environment and give him time, whether in Caesarea ([link]24:27[/link]) or in the city of Rome ([link]28:16[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]30[/link]), that through his last Epistles he might release exhaustively to the church throughout the generations the revelation of the mystery of God's New Testament economy that he received from the Lord. The benefit and profit that the church throughout the generations has received from these Epistles will take eternity to measure.

verse.text: But in the [xref]a[/xref]night [note]1[/note]following, the Lord [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]stood by him and said, Take [xref]c[/xref]courage, for as you have [note]3[/note]solemnly [xref]d[/xref]testified to the things concerning Me in Jerusalem, so also you must [note]4[/note]testify in [note]5[/note]Rome.
verse.note: According to the Jewish calendar, sundown is the beginning of the next day.

The Lord was living all the time in Paul essentially ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]). Now, to strengthen and encourage him, the Lord stood by him economically. This showed the Lord's faithfulness and good care for His servant.
The Lord admitted that the apostle did bear a solemn testimony concerning Him in Jerusalem. A testimony differs from mere teaching (see note [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]).

To carry out His heavenly ministry for the propagating of Himself that the kingdom of God might be established for the building up of the churches as His fullness, the ascended Christ wanted to use not a group of preachers trained by man's teaching to do a preaching work, but a body of His witnesses, martyrs, who bore a living testimony of the incarnated, crucified, resurrected, and ascended Christ (see notes [link]8[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 26[/link]). Satan could instigate the Jewish religionists and utilize the Gentile politicians to bind the apostles and their evangelistic ministry, but he could not bind Christ's living witnesses and their living testimonies. The more they bound the apostles and their evangelistic ministry, the stronger and brighter these martyrs of Christ and their living testimonies became. In His appearing to the apostle, the Lord indicated that He would not rescue him immediately from his bonds but would leave him in bonds and bring him to Rome that he might testify concerning Him, as he had done in Jerusalem. The Lord encouraged Paul to do this.
This was to fulfill Paul's desire in [link]19:21[/link]. See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 27[/link].

verse.text: And when it became day, the [xref]a[/xref]Jews formed a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]plot and [note]2[/note]put themselves under a curse, saying that they would neither eat nor drink until they had [xref]c[/xref]killed Paul.
verse.note: The plot in [link]vv. 12-15[/link] manifested the falsehood and satanic hatred ([link]John 8:44[/link]; [link]Matt. 23:34[/link]) in the hypocritical Jewish religionists. See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup][/link].
To put themselves under a curse means that they would keep their vow, and that if they were to break the vow, they were willing to be cursed. (So also in [link]v. 21[/link].)

verse.text: And there were more than forty who swore to this conspiracy.
They came to the chief priests and the elders and said, [note]1[/note]We have bound ourselves with a curse to taste nothing until we kill Paul.
verse.note: Lit., We have cursed ourselves with a curse. This means that they were bound under a curse and could not break their vow. It is a very strong expression.

verse.text: Now therefore you, with the Sanhedrin, notify the commander to bring him down to you, as though you were going to [note]1[/note]determine more accurately the things concerning him; and we, before he draws near, are ready to [xref]a[/xref]do away with him.
verse.note: I.e., determine by thorough investigation (see also [link]24:22[/link]).

verse.text: But the son of Paul's sister [note]1[/note]heard of the [xref]a[/xref]ambush, and he came and entered into the [xref]b[/xref]barracks and reported [i]it[/i] to Paul.
verse.note: This too was the Lord's sovereignty exercised to secretly rescue Paul's life.

verse.text: And Paul called one of the centurions to [i]him[/i] and said, Bring this young man to the [xref]a[/xref]commander, for he has something to report to him.

So he took him and brought [i]him[/i] to the commander and said, The [xref]a[/xref]prisoner Paul called me to [i]him[/i] and asked [i]me[/i] to bring this young man to you, because he has something to tell you.
And the commander took him by the hand and, withdrawing privately, inquired, What is it that you have to report to me?
And he said, The Jews have [xref]a[/xref]agreed to ask you to bring Paul down tomorrow to the [xref]b[/xref]Sanhedrin, as though they were going to inquire somewhat more accurately concerning him.

So you should not be persuaded by them, for more than forty of their men are lying in ambush for him; they have put themselves under a curse neither to eat nor to drink until they have [xref]a[/xref]done away with him. And now they are ready, awaiting the promise from you.
So the commander dismissed the young man, charging [i]him,[/i] Do not tell anyone that you have informed me of these things.

And he called to [i]him[/i] a certain two of the centurions and said, Prepare two hundred soldiers to go as far as Caesarea, as well as seventy horsemen and two hundred [note]1[/note]spearmen, by the [note]2[/note]third hour of the night;
verse.note: Or, slingers; lightly armed soldiers.

verse.text: And [i]they were also to[/i] provide mounts to put Paul on and bring [i]him[/i] safely to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Felix the [xref]b[/xref]governor.
verse.note: The Roman governor of the province of Judea.

verse.text: And he wrote a letter having this form:
Claudius Lysias, to his [xref]a[/xref]Excellency, Governor Felix, [xref]b[/xref]rejoice.

This man, having been [xref]a[/xref]seized by the Jews and about to be [xref]b[/xref]done away with by them, I came upon with my detachment of soldiers and rescued, when I learned that he was a [xref]c[/xref]Roman.
And intending to [xref]a[/xref]ascertain the cause for which they were accusing him, I brought [i]him[/i] down to their Sanhedrin,
[i]And[/i] found him to be accused concerning [xref]a[/xref]questions of their [xref]b[/xref]law, but having nothing [xref]c[/xref]worthy of death or of bonds laid to his charge.

And when it was [xref]a[/xref]disclosed to me that there was a [xref]b[/xref]plot against the man, I sent [i]him[/i] at once to you, charging the [xref]c[/xref]accusers also to speak the things against him before you.
So the soldiers, according to what they had been directed, took up Paul and brought [i]him[/i] by night to [note]1[/note]Antipatris.
verse.note: A place about forty Roman miles from Jerusalem and about twenty-six from Caesarea.

verse.text: And on the next day, leaving the horsemen to depart with him, they returned to the [xref]a[/xref]barracks.
And when they entered into [xref]a[/xref]Caesarea and handed over the letter to the governor, they presented Paul also to him.
And when he had read [i]it,[/i] he asked from what province he was; and learning that [i]he was[/i] from [xref]a[/xref]Cilicia,
He said, I will hear your case fully when your [xref]a[/xref]accusers also arrive. And he ordered him to be guarded in Herod's [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]praetorium.
verse.note: The palace of the former kings, built by Herod the Great. It became the official residence of the governor of the Roman province of Judea. Paul was guarded there leniently, not confined in the common prison.

verse.text: And after five days the high priest [xref]a[/xref]Ananias came down with some elders and a certain [note]1[/note]orator, Tertullus; and they gave their information against Paul to the [xref]b[/xref]governor.
verse.note: I.e., a spokesman, one who knew Roman legal procedure.

verse.text: And when [i]Paul[/i] was called, Tertullus began to accuse [i]him,[/i] saying, [note]1[/note]Since we have obtained much peace through you, and since reforms are being carried out for this nation through your forethought
verse.note: Tertullus's word from here to the end of [link]v. 3[/link] displayed his baseness, his lack of any ethical standard. See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 23[/link].

verse.text: Both in every way and everywhere, we welcome [i]it,[/i] most [xref]a[/xref]excellent [xref]b[/xref]Felix, with all thankfulness.
But that I may not detain you further, I entreat you to hear us briefly in your forbearance.

For we have found this man a pest and an [xref]a[/xref]agitator of [xref]b[/xref]insurrections among all the Jews throughout the inhabited earth and a ringleader of the [xref]c[/xref]sect of the [xref]d[/xref]Nazarenes,
Who has also tried to [xref]a[/xref]profane the temple. Him also we laid hold of [note]1[/note]and wanted to judge according to our law,
verse.note: Many ancient MSS omit the section from this word through [i]come to you[/i] in [link]v. 8[/link].

verse.text: But Lysias the commander came by and with much force took [i]him[/i] away from our hands

And ordered his accusers to come to you. When you have examined [i]this man[/i] yourself concerning all these things, you will be able to [xref]a[/xref]ascertain from him the things which we accuse him of.
And the Jews also joined in the attack, affirming that these things were so.

And when the governor nodded for him to speak, Paul answered: Knowing that for many years you have been a judge to this nation, I gladly make my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]defense for the things concerning myself,
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].

verse.text: Since you can realize that it is not more than twelve days since I went up to [xref]a[/xref]worship in [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem.
And [xref]a[/xref]neither in the [xref]b[/xref]temple did they find me disputing with anyone nor stirring up a crowd, nor in the synagogues, nor throughout the city.
[xref]a[/xref]Neither are they able to prove to you the things which they now accuse me of.

But I confess this to you, that according to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Way, which they call a [xref]b[/xref]sect, so I [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]serve the [xref]d[/xref]God of our fathers, believing all the things that are written in the [xref]e[/xref]Law and in the Prophets;
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].
Lit., serve as a priest.

verse.text: Having [xref]a[/xref]hope toward God, which these themselves also look for, that there is to be a [note]1[/note]resurrection of both the righteous and the unrighteous.
verse.note: The resurrection of the righteous will occur before the millennium at the Lord's coming back ([link]1 Cor. 15:23[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]). This will be the resurrection of life ([link]John 5:28-29a[/link] and notes; [link]Dan. 12:2a[/link]) and the resurrection of reward ([link]Luke 14:14[/link]), which includes the first, or the best, resurrection ([link]Rev. 20:4-6[/link] and notes [link]5[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]6[sup]2[/sup][/link]), the out-resurrection ([link]Phil. 3:11[/link] and note 2). The resurrection of the unrighteous will occur after the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:5[/link]). This will be the resurrection of judgment ([link]John 5:29b[/link] and notes) and of shame and everlasting contempt ([link]Dan. 12:2b[/link]), and will be for the judgment of eternal perdition upon the unrighteous ([link]Rev. 20:12-15[/link] and note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link]). It was concerning this judgment that the apostle warned the unrighteous Felix in [link]v. 25[/link] (see note 2 there).

verse.text: Because of this I also [xref]a[/xref]exercise myself to always have a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]conscience without offense toward God and men.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 23[/link].

verse.text: Now after [xref]a[/xref]many years I came bringing [xref]b[/xref]alms to my [xref]c[/xref]nation and offerings;
In which they found me [note]1[/note]purified in the temple, with no crowd or uproar. But certain Jews from [xref]a[/xref]Asia,
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].

verse.text: Who should have been present before you and made [xref]a[/xref]accusation if they had anything against me —
Or else let these men themselves say what wrongdoing they found when I stood before the [xref]a[/xref]Sanhedrin,
[i]Other[/i] than concerning this one sound which I cried out while standing among them, Concerning the [xref]a[/xref]resurrection of the dead I am being judged today before you.
But Felix, knowing more accurately the things concerning the [xref]a[/xref]Way, deferred them, saying, When Lysias the [xref]b[/xref]commander comes down, I will determine your affairs.
And he directed the centurion to [xref]a[/xref]keep him [i]in custody,[/i] and that he should have some [xref]b[/xref]liberty and that no one should prevent his own people from attending to him.
But after some days, Felix arrived with [note]1[/note]Drusilla his wife, who was a Jewess, and he sent for Paul and heard him concerning the [xref]a[/xref]faith in Christ Jesus.
verse.note: A daughter of King Herod Agrippa. She was persuaded by Felix, who became enamored of her, to forsake her husband and marry him. This showed the intemperance and corruption of Felix, a Roman politician. See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 23[/link].

verse.text: And as he was [note]1[/note]reasoning concerning [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]righteousness and [xref]b[/xref]self-control and the [xref]c[/xref]judgment to come, Felix became afraid and answered, Go for the present, and when I have an opportunity, I [xref]d[/xref]will call for you;
verse.note: Lit., saying thoroughly, discussing (in argument or exhortation), disputing. The same as in [link]17:2[/link]; [link]18:4[/link], [link]19[/link].

Realizing Felix's unrighteousness ([link]vv. 26-27[/link]) and intemperance (see note [link]24[sup]1[/sup][/link]), the apostle reasoned with Felix regarding righteousness and self-control, the control of passions and desires, especially, here, sexual desires. The coming judgment is related to the resurrection of the unrighteous, which the apostle preached in [link]v. 15[/link] (see note 1 there). The apostle reasoned with Felix regarding the coming judgment also; this was a warning to Felix. Through this, Felix became afraid. See notes [link]42[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link] and [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: Hoping at the same time also that [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]money would be given to him by Paul. Therefore he also sent for him more frequently and conversed with him.
verse.note: This indicated the Roman politician's corruption. See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 23[/link].

verse.text: And when [note]1[/note]two years were completed, Felix was succeeded by Porcius [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Festus; and wanting to [note]3[/note]gain [xref]b[/xref]favor with the Jews, Felix [xref]c[/xref]left Paul [xref]d[/xref]bound.
verse.note: Luke does not disclose what the apostle did during these two years. He might have used the time to be with the Lord for His move on earth. If so, this might have influenced the Epistles he wrote during the time of his appeal in Rome — Colossians, Ephesians, and Philippians — which are the most mysterious, most profound, and richest in the divine revelation. The supply that they have brought to the church throughout the generations cannot be fully told.
Felix's successor as the governor of Judea.
Lit., grant favor to; i.e., grant favor to gain favor. This again showed the corruption of Roman politics.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Festus therefore, having come into the province, after three days went up to Jerusalem from [xref]b[/xref]Caesarea.
And the [xref]a[/xref]chief priests and leading men of the Jews gave their information to him against Paul; and they entreated him,
Asking for a favor against him, that he would summon him to Jerusalem, [i]they themselves[/i] setting an [xref]a[/xref]ambush to [xref]b[/xref]do away with him on the way.
Festus therefore answered that Paul was being kept [i]in custody[/i] in Caesarea, and that he himself was about to proceed [i]there[/i] shortly.
Therefore, he said, let [note]1[/note]influential men from among you go down with [i]me,[/i] and if there is anything [note]2[/note]wrong in the man, let them [xref]a[/xref]accuse him.
verse.note: Lit., powerful.
Or, out of place, amiss.

verse.text: And having stayed among them not more than eight or ten days, he went down to Caesarea; and on the next day he sat on the [xref]a[/xref]judgment seat and ordered Paul to be brought.
And when he arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing many serious [xref]a[/xref]charges against [i]him,[/i] which they were [xref]b[/xref]not able to prove,

While Paul said in his [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]defense, [xref]b[/xref]Neither against the [xref]c[/xref]law of the Jews nor against the [xref]d[/xref]temple nor against [xref]e[/xref]Caesar have I sinned in anything.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].

verse.text: But Festus, wanting to [note]1[/note]gain [xref]a[/xref]favor with the Jews, answered Paul and said, Are you willing to go up to [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem and be judged there before me concerning these things?
verse.note: This exposed the corruption of another Roman politician. See notes [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 23[/link] and [link]27[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 24[/link].

verse.text: And Paul said, I am standing before Caesar's [xref]a[/xref]judgment seat, where I ought to be judged. I have done [xref]b[/xref]nothing wrong to the Jews, as you also very well know.

If therefore I am doing wrong and have committed anything [xref]a[/xref]worthy of death, I do not refuse to die; but if there is nothing to the things which these [xref]b[/xref]accuse me of, no one can hand me over to them. I [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]appeal to [note]2[/note]Caesar.
verse.note: For his defense Paul wanted to appeal to Caesar (see notes [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 22[/link] and [link]32[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 26[/link]). This would allow him to fulfill his desire to see Rome for the furtherance of the Lord's testimony ([link]19:21[/link]) and was according to the Lord's indication to him ([link]23:11[/link]). Without this appeal he would have been killed by the Jews who plotted against him (cf. [link]23:12-15[/link]; [link]25:1-3[/link], [link]9[/link]) and would not have been able to write his last eight Epistles. Before his appeal to Rome, he had written only six Epistles: 1 and 2 Thessalonians, Galatians, Romans, and 1 and 2 Corinthians. During his first imprisonment in Rome he wrote Colossians, Ephesians, Philippians, and Philemon. After that imprisonment he wrote 1 Timothy, Titus, and Hebrews. Then, during his second imprisonment he wrote 2 Timothy. Without these last eight Epistles, what a lack the divine revelation would have and what a loss the church would have suffered! His appeal did render great profit and benefit to the Lord's interest.
Caesar Nero.

verse.text: Then when Festus had conferred with the [note]1[/note]council, he answered, To Caesar you have appealed; to Caesar you shall go.
verse.note: The council of a Roman province, composed of the councilors or assessors chosen by the governor of the province, with whom the governor usually consulted concerning an appeal like Paul's.

verse.text: Now when some days had passed, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Agrippa the king and [note]2[/note]Bernice arrived at [xref]b[/xref]Caesarea and greeted Festus.
verse.note: Herod Agrippa II, who reigned over the region north and east of Galilee, a Jew by religion, the son of the Herod in [link]ch. 12[/link].
