The sister of Drusilla, Felix's wife ([link]24:24[/link]). She was also a sister of Agrippa, with whom she lived incestuously. This again showed the corruption of the politicians in the circle of Roman politics. See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 23[/link].

verse.text: And while they were staying some additional days there, Festus laid before the king the matters regarding Paul, saying, There is a certain man who has been [xref]a[/xref]left a [xref]b[/xref]prisoner by [xref]c[/xref]Felix,
Concerning whom, when I was in Jerusalem, the [xref]a[/xref]chief priests and the elders of the Jews gave information and asked for a sentence against him.

To them I answered that it is not the [xref]a[/xref]custom with Romans to hand over any man before he who is [xref]b[/xref]accused meets the [xref]c[/xref]accusers face to face and has an opportunity for a [xref]d[/xref]defense concerning the charge.
So when they had come together here, I made no delay; on the next day, sitting on the [xref]a[/xref]judgment seat, I ordered the man to be brought.
Concerning him the accusers stood and brought no [xref]a[/xref]charge of the evil things I was suspecting.
But they had certain [xref]a[/xref]questions against him concerning their own [note]1[/note]religion and concerning a certain Jesus who had died, whom Paul affirmed to be [xref]b[/xref]alive.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]being at a loss [i]as to how there should be[/i] an inquiry concerning these things, I asked [i]him[/i] if he was willing to go to [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem and be judged there concerning these things.
verse.note: Or, being perplexed; i.e., not knowing what to do.

verse.text: But when Paul appealed to be kept [i]in custody[/i] for the decision of [note]1[/note]the [xref]a[/xref]Emperor, I ordered him to be kept [i]in custody[/i] until I should send him up to Caesar.
verse.note: Lit., the Augustus; a title of the Roman emperor. So also in [link]v. 25[/link].

verse.text: And Agrippa [i]said[/i] to Festus, I myself also would like to hear the man. Tomorrow, said [i]Festus,[/i] you shall hear him.

Therefore on the next day, when [xref]a[/xref]Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp and entered into the hall of audience together with the [note]1[/note]commanders and prominent men of the city, and when Festus had given the order, Paul was brought.
verse.note: See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].

verse.text: And Festus said, King Agrippa, and all you men who are present with us, you behold this man, concerning whom all the multitude of [xref]a[/xref]Jews have petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought [xref]b[/xref]not to live any longer.
But I found that he had done nothing [xref]a[/xref]worthy of death; and since he himself [xref]b[/xref]appealed to the Emperor, I [note]1[/note]decided to send [i]him.[/i]
verse.note: This was the sovereignty of the Lord.

verse.text: Concerning him I have nothing definite to write to my lord; therefore I have brought him before [note]1[/note]you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that when the examination has taken place, I may have something to write.
verse.note: Plural, referring to the commanders and prominent men who were present ([link]v. 23[/link]).

verse.text: For it seems unreasonable to me, in sending a [xref]a[/xref]prisoner, not to also signify the charges against him.
And Agrippa said to Paul, You are permitted to speak for yourself. Then Paul stretched out his hand and made his [xref]a[/xref]defense:
Concerning all the things which I am [xref]a[/xref]accused of by the Jews, [xref]b[/xref]King Agrippa, I consider myself blessed that I am to make my [note]1[/note]defense before you today,
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Especially since you are [note]2[/note]familiar with all the [xref]a[/xref]customs and [xref]b[/xref]questions among the Jews; therefore I beg [i]you[/i] to listen to me patiently.
verse.note: Or, Since you are especially expert in.
Lit., a knower of, one who is acquainted with.

verse.text: The manner of my life from youth, which from the beginning was among my [i]own[/i] [xref]a[/xref]nation and in Jerusalem, all the Jews know,

Since they have previously known about me from the first, if they were willing to testify, that according to the [xref]a[/xref]strictest [xref]b[/xref]sect of our [note]1[/note]religion I lived as a [xref]c[/xref]Pharisee.
verse.note: Or, zealous worship to God. See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in James 1[/link].

verse.text: And now I stand [i]here[/i] being judged for the [xref]a[/xref]hope of the promise made by God to our fathers,
To which our [xref]a[/xref]twelve tribes, earnestly serving [xref]b[/xref]night and day, hope to attain. Concerning this hope I am [xref]c[/xref]accused by the Jews, O king.
Why is it judged incredible among you if God [xref]a[/xref]raises the dead?
Well then, I thought to myself that I ought to do many things [xref]a[/xref]contrary to the name of Jesus the [xref]b[/xref]Nazarene,

Which also I did in Jerusalem; and I both shut up many of the saints in [xref]a[/xref]prison when I had received [xref]b[/xref]authority from the chief priests and [xref]c[/xref]cast a vote against them when they were being done away with.

And in all the [xref]a[/xref]synagogues I punished them often and tried to compel [i]them[/i] to blaspheme; and being exceedingly enraged at them, I [xref]b[/xref]persecuted [i]them[/i] even as far as [note]1[/note]foreign cities.
verse.note: Lit., outside.

verse.text: [i]Engaged[/i] in these things, I [xref]a[/xref]journeyed to Damascus with authority and a commission from the chief priests.
At midday, on the way, I saw, O king, a light from heaven beyond the brightness of the sun, shining around me and those who journeyed with me.

And when we all fell to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in the [xref]a[/xref]Hebrew dialect, Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting [note]1[/note]Me? It is hard for you to kick against the [note]2[/note]goads.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

A goad on a plow is a sharp-pointed stick used to subdue and prod an ox yoked to the plow. The Lord's word here signifies that Saul was already yoked to the plow and had no choice but to take the Lord's yoke obediently for the carrying out of the Lord's commission. It was hard for him to kick against the goads on the Lord's plow.

verse.text: And I said, Who are You, [note]1[/note]Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus, whom you persecute.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: But rise up and stand on your feet; for I have appeared to you for this [i]purpose,[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]appoint you as a minister and a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]witness both of the things in which you have [xref]c[/xref]seen Me and of the things in which I will appear to you;
verse.note: Not only a minister but also a witness. A minister is for the ministry; a witness, for the testimony. The ministry is related mainly to the work, to what a minister does; a testimony is related to the person, to what a witness is (see notes [link]8[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]11[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 23[/link]).

verse.text: Delivering you [xref]a[/xref]from the people and from the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles, to whom I send you,

To [note]1[/note]open their [xref]a[/xref]eyes, to turn [i]them[/i] from [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]darkness to [xref]c[/xref]light and [i]from[/i] the [note]3[/note]authority of Satan [note]4[/note]to God, that they may receive [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]forgiveness of sins and [note]6[/note]an [xref]e[/xref]inheritance among those who have been [note]7[/note]sanctified by faith in Me.
verse.note: This was to carry out the fulfillment of God's jubilee, the acceptable year of the Lord, proclaimed by the Lord Jesus in [link]Luke 4:18-21[/link] (see note [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 4[/link]) according to God's New Testament economy. The first item of the spiritual and divine blessings of the New Testament jubilee, which are the blessings of the gospel of God, is to open the eyes of those who are fallen and turn them from darkness to light, that they may see the divine things in the spiritual realm. To see these things requires spiritual sight and divine light.
Darkness is a sign of sin and death; light, a sign of righteousness and life ([link]John 1:4[/link]; [link]8:12[/link]).
The authority of Satan is Satan's kingdom, which belongs to darkness ([link]Matt. 12:26[/link] and note 1).
I.e., to the authority of God, to God's kingdom, which belongs to light.
The base of all the blessings of the New Testament jubilee.

Lit., a portion; referring to a portion of an inheritance. This inheritance is the Triune God Himself with all He has, all He has done, and all He will do for His redeemed people. The Triune God is embodied in the all-inclusive Christ ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), who is the portion allotted to the saints as their inheritance ([link]Col. 1:12[/link]). The Holy Spirit, who has been given to the saints, is the foretaste, the pledge, and the guarantee of this divine inheritance ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:14[/link]), which we are sharing and enjoying today as a foretaste in God's New Testament jubilee, and which we will enjoy in full in the coming age and for eternity ([link]1 Pet. 1:4[/link]). In the type of the jubilee in [link]Lev. 25:8-13[/link], the main blessings are the liberty proclaimed and the returning of every man to his own possession. In the fulfillment of the jubilee here, liberation from the authority of darkness and the receiving of the divine inheritance are the primary blessings (cf. note [link]32[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 20[/link]).

Not only positionally but also dispositionally ([link]Rom. 6:19[/link] and note 2, [link chapter="6"]22[/link]). To be sanctified positionally is only to have a change in position and purpose; to be sanctified dispositionally is to be transformed in nature by and with the holy nature of God ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]). To be sanctified is to be saturated with God as our possession for our enjoyment today. Our sanctification will consummate in our maturity in the divine life that we may resemble God and be qualified to fully possess and enjoy Him as our inheritance in the coming age and for eternity.

verse.text: Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly [note]1[/note]vision,
verse.note: Not a doctrine, a theory, a religious creed, or any theology, but a heavenly vision, in which the apostle saw the divine things concerning the dispensing of the Triune God into His chosen, redeemed, and transformed people. All his preaching in this book and his writing in his fourteen Epistles, from Romans through Hebrews, are a detailed description of this heavenly vision seen by Paul.

verse.text: But declared both to those in [xref]a[/xref]Damascus first and in [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem and throughout [xref]c[/xref]all the country of Judea and to the [xref]d[/xref]Gentiles that they should [xref]e[/xref]repent and [xref]f[/xref]turn to God, doing works [xref]g[/xref]worthy of repentance.
Because of these things [i]certain[/i] Jews [xref]a[/xref]seized me while I was in the temple and tried to slay [i]me.[/i]

Having therefore obtained the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]help which is from God, I have [xref]b[/xref]stood unto this day, [xref]c[/xref]testifying both to small and great, saying nothing apart from the things which both the [xref]d[/xref]prophets and [xref]e[/xref]Moses have said would take place,
verse.note: Or, assistance. The Greek word originally meant [i]alliance.[/i] This implies that the apostle was allied with God and realized God's assistance in this alliance.

verse.text: That the Christ would [xref]a[/xref]suffer [i]and[/i] that He, being the first [note]1[/note]to [xref]b[/xref]rise from the dead, would announce [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]light both to the people and to the Gentiles.
verse.note: Lit., out of the resurrection of the dead.

Indicating the enlightenment of God, who is light ([link]1 John 1:5[/link]), shining in Christ, who is the light of the world ([link]John 8:12[/link]; [link]9:5[/link]), through the preaching of the gospel of the glory of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 4:4[/link], [link]6[/link]).

verse.text: And as he was saying these things in his defense, Festus said with a loud voice, You are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]insane, Paul. Much learning is driving you [note]1[/note]insane.
verse.note: Or, raving mad (so also in the next verse).

verse.text: But Paul said, I am not insane, most [xref]a[/xref]excellent [xref]b[/xref]Festus, but I am uttering words of [xref]c[/xref]truth and [xref]d[/xref]soberness.

For the king [note]1[/note]knows about these things, to whom also I speak [note]2[/note]freely, for I am persuaded that none of these things have escaped his notice; for this has not been done in a corner.
verse.note: Agrippa, a Jew by religion, knew the things of the Old Testament and of resurrection.
Or, boldly, plainly.

verse.text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe.
And Agrippa [i]replied[/i] to Paul, By so little are you trying to persuade me to become a [xref]a[/xref]Christian?

And Paul [i]said,[/i] I would to God that both by little and by much, not only you, but also all those who hear me today might become even such [xref]a[/xref]as I am, except for these [xref]b[/xref]bonds.
And the king rose up, and the [xref]a[/xref]governor and [xref]b[/xref]Bernice and [xref]c[/xref]those sitting with them;
And when they had withdrawn, they spoke to one another, saying, This man is doing nothing [xref]a[/xref]worthy of death or of bonds.
And [xref]a[/xref]Agrippa said to Festus, [note]1[/note]This man could have been [xref]b[/xref]released, had he [note]2[/note]not [xref]c[/xref]appealed to Caesar.
verse.note: In this section, [link]21:27-26:32[/link], a long narration of the Jews' final persecution of the apostle, the genuine characteristics of all the involved parties were made manifest: (1) the darkness, blindness, hatred, and hypocrisy of the Jewish religion; (2) the injustice and corruption of Roman politics; (3) the transparency, brightness, faithfulness, and courage of the apostle; and (4) the Lord's encouraging care for His witness and His sovereignty over the entire situation for the carrying out of His divine purpose.

But without his appeal to Caesar, the apostle might have been killed by the Jews through Festus's unjust handling of him ([link]25:9[/link]), and thus his life might not have been preserved to that day. See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 25[/link].

verse.text: And when it was decided that [note]1[/note]we should sail to [xref]a[/xref]Italy, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion named Julius of the [note]2[/note]Augustan [note]3[/note]cohort.
verse.note: Including the writer, Luke.
Perhaps an imperial cohort named by Caesar Augustus (cf. [link]Luke 2:1[/link]).
See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: And going on board an Adramyttian ship which was about to sail to places along [i]the coast of[/i] Asia, we [note]1[/note]put out to sea, [xref]a[/xref]Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, being with us.
verse.note: This was the beginning of the apostle's fourth ministry journey, which ended in [link]28:31[/link].

verse.text: And on the next day we landed at Sidon; and Julius, treating Paul [xref]a[/xref]kindly, allowed [i]him[/i] to go to his friends to receive care.
And from there we put out to sea and sailed under the shelter of Cyprus because the winds were contrary.
And having sailed across the open sea which [i]lies[/i] off Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came down to Myra of Lycia.
And there the centurion found an [xref]a[/xref]Alexandrian ship sailing for Italy, and he put us onto it.
And when we had sailed slowly for a considerable number of days and came with difficulty off Cnidus, the wind not permitting us to go on, we sailed under the shelter of Crete, off Salmone.
And coasting along it with difficulty, we came to a certain place called Fair Havens, near which was the city of Lasea.
And when considerable time had passed and the voyage was now dangerous, [i]and[/i] also because the [note]1[/note]Fast had already gone by, Paul advised [i]them,[/i]
verse.note: I.e., the Day of Expiation ([link]Lev. 16:29-31[/link]; [link]23:27-29[/link]; [link]Num. 29:7[/link]).

verse.text: Saying to them, [note]1[/note]Men, I perceive that the voyage is to be with damage and much loss, not only of the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: But the centurion was persuaded by the navigator and the ship's [xref]a[/xref]owner rather than by the things that were being said by Paul.

And as the harbor was not suitable for wintering, the majority gave counsel to put out to sea from there, if somehow they might be able to reach Phoenix, a harbor of Crete [note]1[/note]facing northeast and southeast, and spend the winter [i]there.[/i]
verse.note: Or, down the southwest wind and down the northwest wind.

verse.text: And when a south wind blew gently, supposing that they had obtained their purpose, they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete close inshore.
But not long afterward there beat down from [note]1[/note]the island a hurricane [xref]a[/xref]wind called [note]2[/note]Euraquilo.
verse.note: Lit., it.
I.e., the Northeasterner.

verse.text: And when the ship was caught [i]by it[/i] and was not able to face the wind, we gave way [i]to it[/i] and were driven along.
And running under the shelter of a certain little island called Clauda, we were hardly able to [note]1[/note]get control of the [xref]a[/xref]small boat.
verse.note: I.e., to secure on deck the small boat, which in calm weather was attached by a rope to the vessel's stern (Vincent).

verse.text: And when they had hoisted it up, they [note]1[/note]used supports to undergird the ship. And because they [xref]a[/xref]feared that they might run aground on [note]2[/note]Syrtis, they [note]3[/note]lowered the gear and so were driven along.
verse.note: I.e., passed cables around the body of the ship.
A shoal by this name, southwest of the island of Crete.
Or, dropped the sea anchor.

verse.text: The next day, as we were being violently storm-tossed, they began to [xref]a[/xref]jettison the cargo;
And on the third day they threw the ship's [note]1[/note]gear [i]overboard, even[/i] with their own hands.
verse.note: Or, furniture.

verse.text: And when neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and while no small storm was assailing [i]us,[/i] from then on all hope that we might be saved was being abandoned.

And when they had been a long time without food, Paul then stood in their midst and said, O [note]1[/note]men, you [note]2[/note]should have listened to me and not set sail from Crete and gained this damage and loss.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

Although Paul was a prisoner in bonds, his behavior displayed much ascendancy with dignity. Luke's narration, as an account of the Lord's move on earth, stresses not doctrine but the testimony of the Lord's witnesses ([link]1:8[/link]). Hence, in his narration there are no details related to doctrine; rather, there are details regarding the things that happened to His witnesses, in order to portray the testimonies in their lives. This is especially so with Paul's voyage in the last two chapters of this book.

verse.text: And now I advise you to [xref]a[/xref]cheer up, for there will be [xref]b[/xref]no loss of life among you, but [i]only[/i] of the ship.
For this very [xref]a[/xref]night an [xref]b[/xref]angel of the God whose I [xref]c[/xref]am and whom I [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]serve [xref]e[/xref]stood by me,
verse.note: Lit., serve as a priest.

verse.text: Saying, Do [xref]a[/xref]not fear, Paul; you must [note]1[/note]stand before Caesar. And behold, God has [xref]b[/xref]granted you all those who are sailing with you.
verse.note: This was to fulfill the Lord's promise in [link]23:11[/link] and the apostle's desire in [link]19:21[/link].

verse.text: Therefore, [xref]a[/xref]cheer up, [note]1[/note]men, for I [xref]b[/xref]believe God that it shall be so, even in the way in which it has been [xref]c[/xref]spoken to me.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: But we must run [xref]a[/xref]aground on a certain [xref]b[/xref]island.
But when the fourteenth night came, as we were being driven about in the Adriatic Sea, about the middle of the night the sailors suspected that some land was approaching them.

And they [note]1[/note]took soundings and found [i]it to be[/i] twenty [note]2[/note]fathoms; and when they had gone a little farther, they sounded again and found [i]it to be[/i] fifteen [note]2[/note]fathoms.
verse.note: To let down a lead into the sea to determine the depth.
One fathom is about six feet.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]fearing that we might run [xref]b[/xref]aground somewhere on [note]1[/note]rocky places, they threw four anchors from the stern and wished for day to come.
verse.note: Lit., rough.

verse.text: And when the sailors sought to flee from the ship, having lowered the [xref]a[/xref]small boat into the sea under pretense of intending to lay out anchors from the bow,
Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, Unless these men remain in the ship, you cannot be saved.
Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the small boat and let it fall away.
And until day was about to come, Paul encouraged [i]them[/i] all to take some food, saying, Today is the fourteenth day that you have continued watching without food, taking nothing.
Therefore I encourage you to take some food, for this is for your salvation; for not a [xref]a[/xref]hair from the head of any one of you shall perish.
And when he had said these things and had taken bread, he gave [xref]a[/xref]thanks to God before all; and he broke [i]it[/i] and began to [xref]b[/xref]eat.
And all became [xref]a[/xref]cheerful, and they also took food.
Now we were in all two hundred and seventy-six souls in the ship.
And when they were satisfied with food, they began to lighten the ship, [xref]a[/xref]throwing out the wheat into the sea.
And when day came, they could not recognize the land, but they noticed a certain bay, which had a beach, into which they took counsel to drive the ship, if they were able.

And casting off the anchors, they left [i]them[/i] in the sea, at the same time loosening the bands of the rudders; and hoisting the foresail to the blowing of the wind, they held course for the beach.
But striking a sandbar with the sea on both sides, they ran the vessel aground; and the bow stuck fast and remained immovable, but the stern was [xref]a[/xref]broken up by the violence of the waves.
And the counsel of the soldiers was that they should [xref]a[/xref]kill the prisoners, lest anyone swim away and escape;

But the centurion, [note]1[/note]intending to bring Paul safely through, prevented them from their intention and ordered those who were able to swim to throw themselves overboard first and get to the land,
verse.note: This was again the sovereignty of the Lord exercised to save His servant's life.

verse.text: And the rest [i]to follow,[/i] some on planks, and others on some of the things from the ship. And so it happened that all were brought [xref]a[/xref]safely through onto the land.
And having been brought safely through, we recognized then that the [xref]a[/xref]island was called [note]1[/note]Malta.
verse.note: Or, Melita.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]natives showed us uncommon [xref]a[/xref]kindness, for they kindled a fire and took us all in because of the rain coming on and because of the cold.
verse.note: Or, barbarians (so also in [link]v. 4[/link]); those who spoke neither Greek nor Latin but were not necessarily uncivilized.

verse.text: But when Paul had collected a bundle of sticks and put [i]them[/i] on the fire, a [xref]a[/xref]viper came out because of the heat and fastened onto his hand.

And when the natives saw the [note]1[/note]snake hanging from his hand, they said to one another, Undoubtedly this man is a murderer, whom, though he has been brought safely out of the sea, [note]2[/note]Justice has not allowed to live.
verse.note: Lit., beast. Medical writers used this term to denote poisonous snakes. (The same word is used in [link]v. 5[/link].)
Gk. [i]Dike,[/i] perhaps a reference to the goddess in Greek mythology, who was in charge of meting out justice.

verse.text: However he shook off the [xref]a[/xref]snake into the fire and suffered no harm;

And they expected that he would swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But when they had waited for a long time and beheld nothing unusual happening to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]god.
verse.note: The apostle was not a god, in contrast to what the curious natives believed in their superstition. Rather, in his living and ministry he expressed the very true God, who in Jesus Christ had gone through the processes of incarnation, human living, crucifixion, and resurrection, and who, as the all-inclusive Spirit, was then living in him and through him.

verse.text: Now in the vicinity of that place were the lands of the leading man of the island, named Publius, who welcomed us and gave [i]us[/i] hospitality three days in a [xref]a[/xref]friendly way.
And the father of Publius was lying down sick with [xref]a[/xref]fever and dysentery. Paul went in to him, and having [xref]b[/xref]prayed and [xref]c[/xref]laid his hands on him, healed him.
And when this happened, the rest also in the island who had sicknesses came to [i]him[/i] and were [note]1[/note]healed.
verse.note: On the sea in the storm, the Lord had made the apostle not only the owner of his fellow voyagers ([link]27:24[/link]) but also their life-guarantor and comforter ([link]27:22[/link], [link]25[/link]). Now, on the land in peace, the Lord made him furthermore not only a magical attraction in the eyes of the superstitious people ([link]vv. 3-6[/link]) but also a healer and a joy to them ([link]vv. 8-9[/link]). All during the apostle's long and unfortunate imprisonment-voyage, the Lord kept the apostle in His ascendancy and enabled him to live a life far beyond the realm of anxiety. This life was fully dignified, with the highest standard of human virtues expressing the most excellent divine attributes, a life that resembled the one that the Lord Himself had lived on the earth years before. This was Jesus living again on the earth in His divinely enriched humanity! This was the wonderful, excellent, and mysterious God-man, who lived in the Gospels, continuing to live in the Acts through one of His many members! This was a living witness of the incarnated, crucified, resurrected, and God-exalted Christ! Paul in his voyage lived and magnified Christ ([link]Phil. 1:20-21[/link]). It is no wonder that the people honored him and his companions with many honors ([link]v. 10[/link]), that is, with the greatest respect and highest regard! An ambassador sent by God should be treated by men with such respect and regard.

verse.text: They also honored us with many honors; and as we put out to sea, they put on [i]board[/i] the things for our needs.

And after [i]it had been[/i] three months, we put out to sea in an [xref]a[/xref]Alexandrian ship which had wintered in the island, with the [note]1[/note]twin sons of [xref]b[/xref]Zeus for [i]its[/i] figurehead.
verse.note: Gk. [i]Dioskouroi,[/i] the twin sons of Zeus, Castor and Pollux, the guardian deities of sailors. A figure of these two was affixed to the stern.

verse.text: And having landed at Syracuse, we remained three days.
From there we sailed around and arrived at Rhegium. And after one day a south wind came on, and the second day we came to Puteoli,
Where, having found [xref]a[/xref]brothers, we were urged to remain with them seven days. And thus we came to Rome.

And from [note]1[/note]there the [note]2[/note]brothers, having heard about the things concerning us, came as far as the [note]3[/note]Market of Appius and [note]4[/note]Three Inns to meet us; [i]and[/i] when Paul saw them, he thanked God and [note]5[/note]took courage.
verse.note: I.e., Rome.

The warm welcome of the brothers from Rome and the loving care of those in Puteoli ([link]vv. 13-14[/link]) show the beautiful Body life that existed in the early days among the churches and apostles. This life was a part of the heavenly kingdom life on the Satan-darkened and man-inhabited earth. Apparently, the apostle, as a prisoner in bonds, had entered the region of the dark capital of the Satan-usurped empire; actually, as the ambassador of Christ with His authority ([link]Eph. 6:20[/link]; [link]Matt. 28:18-19[/link]), he had come into another part of the participation in the Body life of Christ's church in the kingdom of God on earth. While he was suffering the persecution of religion in the empire of Satan, he was enjoying the church life in the kingdom of God. This was a comfort and an encouragement to him.
A place more than forty miles from Rome.
A place more than thirty miles from Rome.

This indicates that the apostle was quite human. Although he had been encouraged by the Lord directly ([link]23:11[/link]) and was very courageous throughout his voyage ([link]27:22-25[/link], [link]33-36[/link]), he still took courage at the brothers' warm welcome. It was in his uplifted humanity with its human virtues that Christ with His divine attributes was expressed during his voyage. He magnified Christ continually in his adverse situation ([link]Phil. 1:20[/link]).

verse.text: And when we entered into Rome, Paul was permitted to remain by himself with the soldier who was [xref]a[/xref]guarding him.

And after three days he called together those who were the leading men of the Jews; and when they came together, he said to them, [note]1[/note]Men, brothers, though I have done [xref]a[/xref]nothing against the people or the [xref]b[/xref]customs of our fathers, I have been delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans,
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Who, having examined me, intended to [xref]a[/xref]release [i]me,[/i] because there was not one [xref]b[/xref]cause of death in me.
But when the Jews spoke against [i]this,[/i] I was compelled to [xref]a[/xref]appeal to Caesar, not that I have anything to accuse my [xref]b[/xref]nation of.
For this cause therefore, I have entreated you to see [i]me[/i] and speak with [i]me;[/i] for on account of the [xref]a[/xref]hope of Israel I have this [xref]b[/xref]chain around [i]me.[/i]
And they said to him, We have neither received [xref]a[/xref]letters from Judea concerning you, nor have any of the brothers come and reported or spoken anything evil concerning you.
But we think it is fitting to hear from you what you think, for concerning this [xref]a[/xref]sect it is indeed known to us that it is [xref]b[/xref]spoken against everywhere.

And once they had appointed a day for him, many came to him at his lodging, to whom he [xref]a[/xref]expounded [i]these matters,[/i] solemnly [xref]b[/xref]testifying of the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]kingdom of God and [xref]d[/xref]persuading them concerning Jesus from both the Law of [xref]e[/xref]Moses and the [xref]f[/xref]Prophets, from morning until evening.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]some were persuaded by the things which were said, but others did not believe.
And when they disagreed with one another, they departed, Paul saying one word [i]to them,[/i] Well has the Holy Spirit spoken through Isaiah the prophet to your fathers,
Saying, [note]1[/note]"Go to this people and say, In hearing you shall hear and by no means understand, and seeing you will see and by no means perceive;
verse.note: God the Father spoke this word to the stubborn children of Israel in [link]Isa. 6:9-10[/link]. God the Son quoted this word to the rejecting Jews in [link]Matt. 13:14-15[/link]. And now God the Spirit through the apostle repeated this word as He spoke to the hardhearted people. This indicates that in all the moves of the Divine Trinity the children of Israel were disobedient to the God of grace. Thus, He turned to the Gentiles for the carrying out of His New Testament economy in the spreading of His kingdom for the building up of the churches through the propagation of the resurrected and ascended Christ ([link]v. 28[/link]).

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]heart of this people has become [note]1[/note]fat, and with their ears they have heard heavily, and their [xref]b[/xref]eyes they have closed, lest they perceive with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart, and they turn around, and I will heal them."
verse.note: I.e., dull.

verse.text: Let it be known to you therefore that this [xref]a[/xref]salvation of God has been sent to the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles; they will also [xref]c[/xref]hear [i]it.[/i]
[note]1[/note]And when he had spoken these things, the Jews departed, having much dispute among themselves.
verse.note: Many MSS omit this verse.

verse.text: And he remained [note]1[/note]two whole years in [i]his[/i] own rented dwelling and [note]2[/note]welcomed all those who came to him,
verse.note: During this time the apostle wrote the Epistles to the Colossians (cf. [link]Col. 4:3[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]18[/link]), Ephesians (cf. [link]Eph. 3:1[/link]; [link]4:1[/link]; [link]6:20[/link]), and Philippians (cf. [link]Phil. 1:7[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]17[/link]), and the Epistle to Philemon (cf. [link]Philem. 1[/link], [link]9[/link]). In [link]Phil. 1:25[/link]; [link]2:24[/link]; and [link]Philem. 22[/link], he was expecting to be released from imprisonment. Probably after these two years he was released and visited Ephesus and Macedonia ([link]1 Tim. 1:3[/link]). In addition, he visited Crete ([link]Titus 1:5[/link]), Nicopolis ([link]Titus 3:12[/link]), Troas, and Miletus ([link]2 Tim. 4:13[/link], [link]20[/link]). See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in 2 Tim. 4[/link].
I.e., received by welcoming, as in [link]Luke 8:40[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Proclaiming the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God and teaching the things concerning the Lord Jesus Christ with all [xref]b[/xref]boldness, unhindered.
verse.note: This was the end of the apostle's fourth ministry journey, which began in [link]27:2[/link].

The kingdom of God is one of the matters emphasized in this book. Luke's writing here both begins ([link]1:3[/link]) and ends with the kingdom of God.[br][br]This book was not actually ended; rather, it was left open that more may be added. The reason for this must have been that the work of the Holy Spirit in preaching Christ for His propagation, multiplication, and spread through the believers of Christ was not yet completed and needed to be continued for a long period of time. Such an evangelistic work for Christ's propagation, multiplication, and spread is according to God's New Testament economy for the producing of many sons for God ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]) that they might be the members of Christ to constitute His Body ([link]Rom. 12:5[/link]) for the carrying out of God's eternal plan and the fulfillment of His eternal will. This is revealed in detail in the twenty-one Epistles and the book of Revelation, which follow this book. The church produced by Christ's propagation and multiplication is the sphere in which God is expressed and in which He reigns in Christ; hence, the church becomes the kingdom of God. The kingdom of God, along with Christ's propagation and multiplication, grows out of and spreads from God's life. Acts is a record of the spreading of Christ; it is also a record of the kingdom of God, because the kingdom of God is the expansion of Christ. The gospel that is widely preached in this book is the very Christ as the gospel ([link]5:42[/link]), the gospel of Christ, and it is also the kingdom of God as the gospel ([link]8:12[/link]), the gospel of the kingdom of God. The preaching of such a gospel will continue and advance until the whole earth becomes the kingdom of Christ ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]).[br][br]In the four Gospels God was incarnated, passed through human living, died, and resurrected, thus completing Christ, the embodiment of the Triune God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]). In Acts this embodiment of God, as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), spreads Christ into His believers, i.e., works the processed Triune God into His chosen, redeemed, and transformed people to make them the constituents of the church, through which God may be expressed. The ultimate issue of the church will be the New Jerusalem in eternity future as God's full and eternal expression, which will also be God's eternal kingdom as the sphere in which He reigns in His divine life in eternity forever and ever. This should be the reality and goal of all gospel preaching today.
